urn:contentItem:3XD7-B1W0-009B-G448-00000-00Nasdaq Falls as Investors' Worries About Inflation Grow; Dollar Sinks to New Low Against Yen; Price of Oil Jumps to 31-Month High1999-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30 pm ETBusinessSHOW99091300V19Nasdaq Falls as Investors' Worries About Inflation Grow; Dollar Sinks to New Low Against Yen; Price of Oil Jumps to 31-Month HighStuart Varney, Willow Bay, Rhonda Schaffler, Bruce Francis, Steve Young, Allan Dodds Frank, Kelli Arena, Bill Dorman, Fred Katayama

Fears about inflation in the U.S. economy held investors in check today as the Nasdaq retreated from its Friday record, falling 42 points to 2,844, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose slightly to 11,030. Today, the dollar lost more of its value relative to the yen. The exchange rate of 106 yen to the dollar is a three-year low. The price of a barrel of oil grew to $24.21, which is a 31-month high and more than double January's price. Florida is bracing for potential catastrophe tonight as Hurricane Floyd whips itself into a massive category 4 storm with winds maxing out at 155 miles per hour. Floyd is currently located 450 miles off the coast of Florida, moving west at 16 miles an hour. Evacuation orders have been given for low-lying areas and building materials and food staples have flown off the shelves.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight, two disturbing trends throw Wall Street for a loop, the dollar plunges again and oil takes another dizzying surge.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: You've got trouble. Why stock in America Online and a host of other Net giants lost momentum.

VARNEY: In Florida, escape from Hurricane Floyd. As one meteorologist put it, this is Andrew's big brother.

BAY: And the lifestyles of the rich and powerful played out in a New York courtroom. We'll hear from the ex-wife of Revlon chief Ron Perelman.

ANNOUNCER: This is the MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR. Reporting tonight from New York, Willow Bay and Stuart Varney.

VARNEY: Good evening, everyone, and welcome to MONEYLINE. Well, hopes that tech stocks would build on Friday's record run faded fast.

BAY: The Nasdaq today retreated from its lofty levels: that as the greenback today sunk to a new three-year low against the yen. The dollar downdraft, along with another spike in oil prices, fueled more fears of inflation and rising interest rates.

Rhonda Schaffler has more in today's "Street Sweep."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): A market held hostage: That's how one strategist described the day on Wall Street. Investors, hamstrung by interest rate fears and the dollar slide. The greenback tumbled again, pressuring stocks and bonds.

Blue chips treaded water all day, ending up less than two points. The big loser was last week's winner: The Nasdaq, retreating from Friday's record, down 42 points to 2,844.

Interest rate concerns hit "big board" financials and tech stocks on both the Dow and Nasdaq.

PETER HENDERSON, HENDERSON BROTHERS: Not a lot to sink your teeth into today. And the fact that the techs and the financials were very weak and the Standard & Poor's was down, you really can't look at the industrial average and say, well, it was a pretty much of a neutral day, because the market does not act well today.

And short term, I would predict that we see a follow through of not great trading tomorrow.

SCHAFFLER: Among today's high-tech decliners, IBM, Hewlett- Packard, Dell and Microsoft. Net stocks took bigger dives. AOL, one of the big board's most active, was off sharply on negative comments in this week's "Barron's."

On the Nasdaq, eBay, Yahoo! and CMGI all pulled back.

One big fear going forward, that the Fed will have to hike interest rates to support the sagging dollar. Some say that fear is overblown.

JOHN LONSKI, MOODY'S INVESTOR SERVICE: I think this would be more of a problem for Federal Reserve policy-makers and for financial markets if dollar weakness was broader-based. Thus far, the dollar still holds up quite well against the euro.

However, if as expected European economies do quicken, then I would look for the dollar perhaps to soften against the euro later in the year.

SCHAFFLER: Also sure to figure into the Fed's thinking, two key reports out over the next few days.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

Tomorrow will bring retail sales for August. On Wednesday -- the one Wall Street is really waiting for -- the latest reading on consumer prices -- Willow.

BAY: Thanks, Rhonda: Rhonda Schaffler from the New York Stock Exchange.

VARNEY: Aside from those economic numbers, the Fed will clearly factor the weakening dollar into its deliberations. Today, the currency lost more than two yen, trading at 106 yen. That's a new three-year low. That as Japan failed to intervene, as it did last week.

At the same time, oil shot to a 31-month high: at $24.21 a barrel, more than double what it was in January of this year.

Now, considering the inflation threats, bonds were relatively resilient. The 30-year issue fell five ticks. The yield at 6.04 percent.

Wall Street has been surprisingly resilient as well, considering the dollar's recent slide, that is. But our guest tonight warns that investors may not be taking the dollar doldrums seriously enough.

He remembers some lessons from 1987. Hugh Johnson of First Albany joins us now.

Hugh, welcome back to MONEYLINE.

HUGH JOHNSON, FIRST ALBANY SECURITIES: Thanks, Willow, Stuart.

VARNEY: Let's deal with 1987 in a moment. But first of all, this question. If the dollar does keep on falling, does Wall Street sell off big time?

JOHNSON: Yes. There have been a lot of studies done about the relationship between currencies and stock markets, and they're pretty strong relationships. When you see the dollar sag, it presents all sorts of problems to a Federal Reserve that has plenty of problems right now.

So it really implies that inflation down the road is going to be a little bit higher. They can't sit by and preserve their credibility. They will need to raise short-term interest rates if we get further weakness in the dollar. I hope we don't, but if we do, it gives them a problem.

BAY: Inflation, interest rates, a concern. How concerned should we be about foreign investors moving their money out of the stock market, of course, but then the bond market.

JOHNSON: Well, Willow, you know, we have to remember that foreign investors now own 34 percent of all U.S. Treasuries. So if they start to exit our markets, they can drive bond prices down, interest rates up. They own 7 percent of U.S. stocks. So any way you look at it, the dollar declines and it dissuades investors from our markets -- it's going to have an impact on our markets.

BAY: How likely is that to happen, given what you're seeing right now?

JOHNSON: You know, I kind of go along with the idea that the strength in the economies abroad, particularly in Europe, is not going to be quite what everybody expects it to be. So I'm not looking for a dollar crisis, but believe me, I think everybody has to stay tuned and watch very carefully.

VARNEY: Let's regurgitate 1987, shall we? Do you think we're in a similar situation right now?

JOHNSON: It's not quite as bad. In 1987, we had significant weakness in the dollar. And as you remember, Paul Volcker said enough is enough. All of the countries, Western countries, got together, decided to take steps to support the dollar.

They were raising interest rates. We had, quite frankly, a stronger threat of inflation, and then we had cooperation between Germany and the United States break down, and that led to the real problem. So it's not at the crisis level of 1987. It's a dangerous level but it's not a crisis level.

VARNEY: Hugh Johnson, First Albany, thanks for being back with us again on MONEYLINE.

JOHNSON: My pleasure.

VARNEY: OK -- Willow.

BAY: Thanks.

Now, let's take a quick look at what some of MONEYLINE's other reporters are working on for the rest of the show. We begin with Bruce Francis -- Bruce.

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Thanks, Willow. 3Com is cutting off the Palm that feeds it. Will investors be satisfied with what's left of the struggling networking giant? I'll have that story.

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Steve Young. Wall Street today whacked Motorola stock and General Instrument, too, on news Motorola is ready to acquire the biggest set-top box maker. I'll explain why analysts still say the deal makes sense.

ALLAN DODDS FRANK, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Allan Dodds Frank. I'll have the latest on a bitter child custody battle between New York's richest man, Ronald Perelman, and his former wife, Patricia Duff.

BAY: Thanks, Allan. We'll have much more on those stories coming up in the hour.

VARNEY: But first, our top story outside the world of business. Florida is bracing for potential catastrophe tonight as Hurricane Floyd whips itself into a massive category 4 storm with winds maxing out at 155 miles per hour. Floyd is currently located 450 miles off the coast of Florida, moving west at 16 miles an hour. Evacuation orders have been given for low-lying areas and building materials and food staples have flown off the shelves.

Question: Why such great concern? Well, there's one word in the answer and that's Andrew.

In 1992, that category 4 storm smashed into Florida, taking 65 lives and causing $26 billion worth of damage. Floyd is also fierce and three to four times as big.

Obvious question: Will Floyd make landfall? Well, joining us now to talk about where Floyd may be going is Max Mayfield, director of the National Hurricane Center in Miami.

Sir, welcome to MONEYLINE.

MAX MAYFIELD, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL HURRICANE CENTER: Good evening, Stuart.

VARNEY: Obvious question, Max, is your best judgment, please, on when and where this hurricane could make landfall on the Eastern Seaboard. MAYFIELD: Well, two things. One, as you've already stated, this is a very powerful category 4 hurricane: borderline category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson hurricane scale. Extremely dangerous. If it were to make a direct hit on the Southeastern United States coast, I would expect extreme damage from this hurricane.

Our current forecast track has it turning gradually toward the Northwest into the northern Bahamas. And this time tomorrow night it should be centered somewhere east of Palm Beach, Florida, and then this time on the following night to be very near the South Carolina coast.

However, the timing of this turning north is not at all certain, and therefore, the risks are just too great. So we upgraded the hurricane watch to a hurricane warning for the Florida East Coast.

Now, tonight the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is flying the jet aircraft and two of the P-3 aircraft in environment around the hurricane to initialize the computer models, to get the best estimate of the steering (ph) flow that we possibly can.

So we're doing everything we can to make a good forecast. Even though, we're forecasting the center of this hurricane to remain just off the Florida east coast, it's just too close for comfort here. And so, that's why we have the hurricane warning.

VARNEY: Is it possible to make a judgment as to whether or not this hurricane could be upgraded to a category 5 storm? What's its normal behavior, of a storm of this kind?

MAYFIELD: I think that there is certainly some possibility that could happen. We've only had two category 5 hurricanes to strike the United States this century: the Labor Day hurricane in 1935 in the Florida Keys and Hurricane Camille on the Mississippi coast in 1969.

So it's very unlikely really, if you look at the statistics, that it would become a category 5. But I can assure you a category 4 could cause just extreme damage.

VARNEY: Max Mayfield of the National Hurricane Center in Miami, we thank you for joining us tonight. Thank you, Max.

MAYFIELD: You're welcome.

VARNEY: Willow.

BAY: Thanks, Stuart. Other stories making headlines tonight: In Moscow, another powerful bomb explosion ripped out an entire apartment block early this morning: 66 are dead in the fourth violent blast to rock the Russian capital in two weeks. Two were arrested in connection with the bombing. Russia's interior minister blames Islamic rebels for the attacks.

A strong earthquake claimed six lives and injured more than 320 in Turkey. The magnitude 5.8 jolt struck the same part of Turkey hit by a massive quake in mid-August. More than 15,000 died then. VARNEY: And Australian troops are tonight preparing to lead a peacekeeping mission to East Timor. Officials are meeting at the U.N. to organize the operation.

Hundreds of thousands of East Timorese have gone into hiding or escaped to West Timor. Aid workers say food and supplies are desperately needed.

BAY: Coming up on MONEYLINE, the Palm Pilot cleared for takeoff. 3Com is taking its hand-held computer division to "The Street."

VARNEY: Plus, with billions at stake, the coming battle over genetically modified crops: Are too few companies controlling the course of agriculture? We'll be back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Plans tonight for a spin-off by the No. 2 computer networking firm. 3Com announced today it will sell shares in its popular palm computing unit through an IPO planned for early next year. The market liked it; 3Com stock up 1 5/8.

Bruce Francis has our report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): 3Com is shedding palm computing, one of its fastest growing assets, in order to make sure it thrives.

ERIC BENHAMOU, CEO, 3Com: It was important for us to be able to nurture Palm to a point where there was a thriving hand-held computer industry. The ownership of Palm is not essential to the strategy we pursue.

FRANCIS: But some five million users have found it essential to own a Palm Pilot, now bringing in more than $500 million a year for 3Com. 3Com plans to sell a minority stake in the palm pilot business in a public offering. Then 3Com shareholders will receive stock in the rest of Palm.

BERT HOCHFELD, ANALYST, JOSEPTHAL: 3Com has been attempting to restructure its business to maximize shareholder value since the stumbles that they have had, and this is just part of that strategy. I think it's just -- it's an appropriate time for them to spin this off.

FRANCIS: But even the cash 3Com could raise in an IPO, analysts say as much as $1 billion, won't necessarily fix 3Com. 3Com stock peaked in late 1996 at over $81 a share. Since then, 3Com has lost almost two-thirds of its value. The culprit? Much of its revenue comes from slower growth products like cards that hook personal computers up to networks. Intel entered that market and slashed prices.

MARTIN PYYKKONEN, CIBC WORLD MARKETS: I'm not meaning that I'm optimistic in terms of what they can do in terms of their revenue growth in the existing business, but, you know, there's a day of reckoning where they really have to try to reinvest for growth. But it's going to be tough.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: For those that think that that day of reckoning will come in a merger, 3Com's CEO, Eric Benhamou, says the company's strategy is to remain independent. But, Stuart, as today's news shows, strategies change.

VARNEY: Do they not indeed. Bruce Francis, thank you.

And by the way, later on MONEYLINE, we will speak with the CEO of 3Com, Eric Bienhamou.

BAY: In tonight's "MONEYLINE Movers," IDEC Pharmaceuticals surged more than 14 on an upgrade from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. The stock came under pressure last week on concerns about sales of one of its anti-cancer treatments.

Ziff-Davis up nearly one 1 1/4. The computer trade magazine and online publisher denies reports it's considering a takeover offer from News Corp.

Watson Pharmaceuticals tumbled 3 1/4. A court has blocked sales of its gum to help quit smoking, a ruling that will wipe $10 million off the bottom line.

And Hitachi jumped 7 1/2. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter upgraded the Japanese electronics maker because of its strong chip sales.

VARNEY: Now one of the biggest losers on the Big Board: Motorola. The stock plunged eight -- more than eight points. In fact, that's about 10 percent -- on a report that it is in talks to buy General Instruments. The price there is roughly $10 billion. Shares of General Instruments, which is the leading maker of cable TV set boxes, also fell, down more than 2 3/4 points.

As Steve Young reports, it's Motorola's first big move after a huge restructuring.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Motorola, the maker of cell phones, two-way radios, pagers and business electronic equipment, is ready for growth after tough times. Just a year ago, the company suspended work on its biggest investment ever, a $3 billion advanced chip plant, because of a worldwide slowdown in chip demand.

MONA ERAIBA, GRUNTAL & CO.: Now they are in the position to really construct alliances, have partnerships whether through just a partnership or acquisition. It's a changed company and in a changed market. YOUNG: A company whose stock has climbed nearly 50 percent this year. To get there, Motorola had to do some painful downsizing to get costs into line. The company last year cut its workforce by about 24,000 employees, took a staggering one-time charge of nearly $2 billion, and, as a result, improved its profits by more than $1 billion a year.

The company's $2.2 billion investment in the bankrupt satellite communications system Iridium is one of the few lingering problems. Motorola says it expects Iridium to survive and won't be jolted if it doesn't.

Analysts say General Instrument would fit well with Motorola. It's already invested in cable-modem technology, which will benefit from broadband connections controlled by General Instrument boxes..

DAVID POWERS, EDWARD JONES: If you look in technology right now, one of the fastest growing areas over the next several year is going to be for broadband access. And certainly cable is going to have a large role in that process.

YOUNG: Motorola stock was walloped after news of the pending deal got out, but analysts say that reaction ignored General Instrument's broadband potential.

ERAIBA: A lot of people are really making a judgment on the acquisition based on history rather than the future opportunities.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG: Motorola has wanted to enter the home entertainment business, and if it acquires General Instrument there's one thing analysts today said you can be sure of: playing on the better-known brand, the set-top boxes will carry the Motorola name -- Willow.

BAY: Thanks, Steve. Steve Young reporting.

One of the biggest names in computers today dismissed the idea that Y2K would hurt his business. Michael Dell today told Reuters, after speaking at an Internet conference in Paris, that he expects no slowdown in sales of Dell computers as companies scramble to avoid the millennium bug. Rather, Dell's chief executive predicts a very healthy second half of the year.

VARNEY: Now, still ahead on MONEYLINE, the battle over farming's genetic future.

BAY: It is going to court with billions at stake.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: In California tonight, news of a huge drop in cigarette sales. New state figures show cigarette purchases down a full 30 percent in the first half of this year. Officials say that higher state taxes and an increase in tobacco prices are at least partly responsible for that decrease. But they also believe some smokers are buying out of state, of course, to dodge those higher taxes.

BAY: A multi-billion dollar antitrust battle shaping up tonight for the world's biotech giants. Two U.S. economic and farm groups say they'll file suit in November, claiming the firms use bioengineering techniques to lock up agricultural markets. Among the companies they are challenging: Monsanto, Dupont and Novartis.

Kelli Arena reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KELLI ARENA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Farmers around the world say they're growing more hostile toward an industry they say is exercising too much control.

AARON BUTLER, FARMER: I think the motive is pure and simple profit. I mean, I think it's the ultimate example of greed.

ARENA: There are a handful of companies which produce the seed used to grow most genetically modified crops, an estimated $10 billion market, and growing. They include Monsanto, Novartis, Astrazeneca, Dupont and the soon-to-be-formed Aventis. All five are targets in planned antitrust suits being brought by farmers joined by two distinctly different Washington groups: the Family Farm Coalition, which supports small farmers, and the Foundation on Economic Trends, run by a biotech activist.

MICHAEL HAUSFELD, PLAINTIFFS' ATTORNEY: What the companies are doing are imposing restrictive conditions on the seed. They're either selling it to the farmer and saying to the farmer, you can only purchase this seed for one year, and at the end of the year, you are prohibited from collecting that seed and using it in next year's harvest, and if you do, we'll sue you for it.

ARENA: While not being able to reuse seed is financially hard on farmers, it's not necessarily a violation of antitrust laws.

KEVIN ARQUITT, ROGERS & WELLS: If they're simply accused of restricting the use of their intellectual property, it's hard to imagine how an antitrust case could succeed.

ARENA: What's more, analysts say healthy competition exists, further undercutting the antitrust argument.

WILLIAM YOUNG, DONALDSON, LUFKIN & JENRETTE: During the past year, the price of seed either came down or the farmer was offered a special financing tool by the seed companies so that each one had a chance to gain market share. Of course, they can't all gain market share, but it shows you that it's a very competitive environment.

ARENA: The companies will have more to say once the suit is filed, probably within the next two months.

(on camera): This all comes at a sensitive time for the genetic farming industry, which is facing growing consumer and political resistance. Even so, analysts say the industry represents the future, and predict the companies are strong enough to weather this new storm.

Kelli Arena, CNN Financial News, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: And turning now to a country with a leading edge on Internet growth -- tomorrow's edition of "The Financial Times" says China is warning off overseas companies who want to invest in the country's burgeoning Internet business. "The Times" says it is still unclear how this will affect China.com, which went public in July, and other Chinese Internet content providers.

BAY: MONEYLINE will return in just a moment. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: And before we wrap up this half hour, an after-the-bell deal to tell you about. Solectron, that's an electronics maker, is buying Smart Modular Technologies for about $2 billion in stock. Smart Modular is a computer memory developer and will become a major part of Solectron's new technology solutions unit. Solectron shares tumbled more than $3 from the New York Stock Exchange close.

BAY: Coming up on THE MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR, what's behind the dollar's relentless decline against the yen?

VARNEY: And those fickle technology investors at it again. The Nasdaq pulls back from Friday's all-time high.

BAY: And the latest twist in a high-stakes divorce case.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: The MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR continues. Here again, Stuart Varney and Willow Bay.

BAY: In tonight's headlines, the world watches as the dollar sinks to new depths against the Japanese yen: a temporary blip or a troubling trend. An IPO for the gadget you can't live without: the Palm Pilot. 3Com is spinning it off. We'll find out why from the company's chief executive.

And the divorce battle that has New York and the rest of the business world buzzing: Duff versus Perelman.

VARNEY: But tonight, we begin on Wall Street with the sudden U- turn in technology stocks. The Nasdaq composite reversed Friday's record-setting rally, tumbling 42 points, close to 1 1/2 percent, to finish at 2,844 on volume of almost 1 billion shares.

The Dow industrials, however, managed to bounce back from a 46- point deficit, closing up slightly at 11,030. The volume on the big board, just 657 million shares. One big winner: International Paper, up 2 1/2 -- that on a favorable industry report. Still, there were many more losers. Declining issues outpaced winners by a margin of nearly three to two. There were 70 stocks that climbed to 52-week highs, but 148 tumbled to new lows.

BAY: Today's big loser is one of the most celebrated tech stocks: America Online. AOL stock lost more than six today, erasing almost $7 billion of the company's market cap: that after an article in "Barron's" over the weekend quoted a hedge fund manager worried about price pressures, subscriber growth and insider selling.

It has certainly been a dark few months for AOL investors. Since hitting a high in April, the stock has lost almost half its value and wiped out much of its gains for the year. Other Internet stocks today followed suit, with eBay, Amazon.com, CMGI, Yahoo! and Inktomi all heading south.

And as we told you, it was a losing day for other big tech names. Microsoft, Intel and Dell pulled down the Nasdaq composite. And on the big board, Gateway fell 1 1/2.

VARNEY: Yes, but the real drama today was in fact in the currency markets, with the relentless selloff of the dollar. The buck continued to dive against the Japanese yen, to levels not seen since 1996. But unlike last week, Japan didn't intervene to stop the yen's rapid rise.

Bill Dorman has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BILL DORMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): If you believe the currency markets, Japan's economy may be on the comeback trail, driving the yen to its highest level against the dollar in more than three years. It's all about capital flows: money going where investors detect the best chances for higher returns. Right now, that's Japan.

Over the last two months, the dollar has lost 13 percent of its value against the yen. So far, that has not pushed Treasury Secretary Larry Summers to intervene in the markets.

MAUREEN MCFARLAND, MAINSTAY FUNDS, MACKAY SHIELDS: If we were to break through 100 yen to the dollar, we could actually start to see Summers start at least having some verbal intervention that enough is enough and we don't want the yen to continue to strengthen so dramatically.

DORMAN: Summers has maintained the strong dollar policy of his predecessor, Robert Rubin, but some traders are eager to test that policy. While still in his professorial days at Harvard, Summers wrote that a strong dollar may not always serve the national interest. For U.S. exporters, a weaker dollar over time means higher profits from overseas. But as the dollar weakens, inflation here in the United States will rise. And a lower dollar may discourage some overseas investors from holding U.S. assets, such as bonds.

But even those who watch currencies for a living warn against reading too much into short-term moves in the dollar/yen relationship.

MARC CHANDLER, MELLON BANK: We saw the Nasdaq market make record highs on Friday as the dollar was falling to three-year lows. So I think the relationship between the U.S. stock market, U.S. asset prices in general and the dollar is still really tenuous.

DORMAN: The dollar is also holding up relatively well against the euro.

(on camera): A weaker dollar against the yen by itself should not cripple the stock market. But a dollar that stays weak will add to market worries, starting with inflation.

Bill Dorman, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: Now, the dollar's decline against the yen today was swift indeed: the greenback down more than two yen, one of the worst single-day drops in the past year. It was down slightly against the euro, up a little against the British pound.

BAY: Another milestone today for the oil market. Prices hit $24 a barrel and kept going on hopes that oil-producing countries will keep a lid on supplies. In New York trading, light sweet crude jumped 66 cents to $24.21 a barrel. The last time oil went for more than $24 a barrel was January of 1997.

Meanwhile, the dollar's slump continues to weigh on bond prices. The 30-year Treasury down 5/32 in price, the yield moving up to 6.04 percent.

VARNEY: Here now to help us put the markets into perspective is Mansoor Ijaz. He's the chairman of Crescent Investment Management, where he runs a hedge fund that's done rather well betting against the dollar.

Mansoor, many thanks for joining us here on MONEYLINE.

MANSOOR IJAZ, CHAIRMAN, CRESCENT INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT: Good to see you again, Stuart.

VARNEY: Do you believe that the dollar will continue to fall against the Japanese yen?

IJAZ: Yes, I do. I think you'll certainly see it test a 100 yen in the not-too-distant future.

VARNEY: Now, as a manager of money in America, does that continuing dollar decline worry you, trouble you about America's stock market?

IJAZ: Not yet. I think you have to keep in mind that probably some of the thinking in Washington goes like the -- as follows: And that is that Japan's import pattern has to be altered for the long term if Asia's recovery is to stay intact.

As we all know, during the past 3 1/2 to four years, Asia has had quite a bit of difficulty based on the rise and the fall of the yen. And one fact that we have to keep in mind is that every time the yen rises 1 percent -- and I'm talking about now the yen versus the dollar -- you can have an increase in the growth -- GDP growth of Taiwan and countries like Korea of almost 25 basis points. So certainly, the rise of the yen, if it were to stay where it is right now, would encourage a significant increase in the growth patterns for the Asian economies that were hit very hard in the 1996-1997 period.

VARNEY: But as far America is concerned, presumably this lower dollar is quite a significant first test for the new treasury secretary, Larry Summers. What do you think he's going to do about it?

IJAZ: Well, this is an interesting part of the equation. There's where the political economy gets matched in with the raw mathematical calculations that traders and money managers do.

Clearly, Mr. Summers is intellectually capable of understanding the implications of a strong yen. But where Mr. Rubin, his predecessor, was from the trading world and people knew his capabilities as a trader and understood that he knew our moves and knew how we would think about things as well as he did -- as well as we did, I think Mr. Summers probably doesn't have the same experience as far as markets are concerned.

So as a money manager, you definitely want to try and test the metal of a central banker or a treasury secretary that has such an important responsibility within the G-7 framework.

VARNEY: Mansoor, let me wrap it up, 10 seconds left. You do think the dollar is going to fall below 100 yen, correct?

IJAZ: I think it will definitely challenge 100 yen, and I think you'll see Mr. Summers' metal challenged in the process.

VARNEY: Well-said, indeed. Mansoor Ijaz, chairman of Crescent Investment Management, joining us here. Thanks very much, Mansoor.

IJAZ: Good to see you again.

BAY: Just ahead on MONEYLINE, rival suitors become merger partners. We'll tell you about the latest takeover talk in telecom.

Those concerns have rattled the stock. It's down 20 percent since the beginning of the month.

Thestreet.com, up nearly 6. The venture capital arm of Chase Manhattan invested $17 million in Thestreet.com's new British financial news Web site.

And Eastman Kodak added 2 7/8. CS First Boston repeated a strong buy rating on the stock, on strength in Kodak's digital product line.

VARNEY: Here's a switch. A hostile takeover battle turns friendly after a two-month standoff. French oil companies Totalfina and Elf Aquitaine have agreed to merge in a $54 billion deal. Totalfina offering 19 of its shares for 13 Elf shares. The deal will create the fourth largest oil group in the world. In U.S. trading, shares of Elf jumped more than 3 points today; Totalfina, down 5/8. By the way, today's merger marks the third biggest oil deal in history, right behind Exxon-Mobil and BP Amoco.

BAY: Bell Atlantic could get a major boost. The largest of the baby bells confirms it is in talks to combine its wireless operation with Vodaphone.

And as Fred Katayama reports, the new combination could prove to be a strong competitor to AT&T.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Bell Atlantic is trying to hook up with a company it once lost in a battle with Vodafone: Airtouch. It's discussing a joint venture that would unite Vodafone Airtouch's big U.S. wireless network with its own.

MICHAEL BALHOFF, LEGG MASON: Ultimately, the companies that have done better in wireless here in the United States have been companies that have been able to offer to consumers a national footprint.

KATAYAMA: Bell Atlantic is strong in the East, with more than 7 million wireless subscribers. A pending merger with GTE would add another 5 million. Vodafone Airtouch is powerful in the West, with 9 million subscribers. A joint venture would make it by far the largest U.S. wireless operator, with more than twice the number of users of leader, AT&T.

Giving users nationwide access is becoming increasingly important, especially for business users, so that subscribers can avoid roaming charges and companies can offer cheap flat-rate calling plans. Wall Street indicated its approval of the merger talks, lifting shares of both companies. Analysts say regulators would bless a venture, since it has given the green light to other big telecom combinations like MCI-WorldCom and SBC PacBell. ERIC STRUMINGHER, PAINEWEBBER: I don't see any deal killing regulatory impediment. This is a deal that regulators should like. There are some issues that will have to be looked at on a market-by- market basis.

KATAYAMA (on camera): Neither company would comment on reports that the boards of both sides would meet tomorrow to discuss the venture. Bell Atlantic would only say no timetable has been set for the talks.

Fred Katayama, CNN Financial News, New York.

BAY: Investors were enthusiastic about the possibility. Shares of Vodaphone-Airtouch up 10 3/4; Bell Atlantic gaining 1 3/4.

VARNEY: Motorola took a hit today on reports that it's in negotiations to acquire General Instrument, cable's leading maker of set-top boxes. But a rival set-top box maker, Scientific Atlanta, rose more than $2.50 on all that takeover talk.

BAY: Checking some of today's other corporate headlines: Hershey Foods issuing another profit warning. Swiss watchmaker Tag Heuer accepting a $745 million cash bid from the French conglomerate. In U.S. trading, shares of LVMH losing more than $1; Tag Heuer up more than 1/2. LaidLaw wants to focus just on buses. North America's largest school bus company plans to sell its U.S. health-care units and its stake in Safety-Kleen Corporation. The moves are expected to fetch over $2 billion.

VARNEY: Now when MONEYLINE returns, 3Com plans to put its trademark product in the hands of the public.

BAY: We will talk to the company's chief executive, Eric Benhamou, that's next. You're watching MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's MONEYLINE "Focus": 3Com. The company today announced it was spinning off the unit that makes its popular handheld computers, the Palm Pilots. 3Com plans to sell 20 percent of the business to the public in an IPO early next year, and may eventually sell more. Despite the Palm Pilot's success, 3Com's stock price is lagging, losing almost half its value from its 52-week high. Joining us now, the company's chief executive, Eric Benhamou. Mr. Benhamou, welcome to MONEYLINE. ERIC BENHAMOU, CEO, 3COM: Thank you.

BAY: So is this a strategy shift, or a pretty effective way to take advantage of a hot IPO market?

BENHAMOU: There's certainly no strategy shift. There has been all along a plan to create a thriving business in the field of handheld computing, and it's essential to a networking strategy as well.

BAY: So why is 3Com better off spinning off Palm Pilot?

BENHAMOU: Well there are several reasons. The largest of which is the fact that the market opportunity for handheld computing has dramatically expanded over the last year into new directions. For example, the direction of licensing the operating system to a proliferation of new devices that will be handheld. The opportunity to also create services, wireline and wireless services for handheld access.

BAY: Now who would be creating those services? Would it be the Palm Pilot spinoff or would it be 3Com?

BENHAMOU: It would be certainly the handheld computing company. So all of these new segments are appearing in the handheld space. It is to be able to best position ourselves to take advantage of the services, that we came to the conclusion that a structure of a publically traded independent company would be optimal.

BAY: But what about 3Com? What about the business that's left? In other words, if you're spinning off this high-growth unit, what's left to deliver that kind of growth potential to your investors?

BENHAMOU: 3Com the networking company benefits immediately from this move by virtue of the clarity of focus that it brings to a networking business. You wouldn't believe how many times as of late 3Com was introduced as the maker of the Palm Pilot, ignoring 90 percent of what we do. So clearly the brand 3Com will become much more synonymous with connectivity without having to refer to handheld. In addition to this, the management bandwidth assigned to networking will expand by virtue of having a dedicated team running the palm business.

BAY: You have been handicapped by some slow-growing businesses. Now that you have this ability to focus after spinning off Palm Pilot, where do you expect the growth to come from?

BENHAMOU: The slow businesses you're referring to happen to be related to two of all of those product lines, namely analog modems and network interface card connectivity. We have been hard at work for the last 69 months transforming the niche of our business, emphasizing new areas of growth, particularly in the area of land telephony, in the areas of like voice-over IP, the ability to carry voice traffic on IP infrastructure for carriers, wireless access, as well as broadband access. There are several high-growth areas on which we intend to focus. BAY: And you're confident that this is going to deliver the kind of growth that you will see reflected in your stock price?

BENHAMOU: We know that we have great opportunities. And if we execute well, the opportunity on the networking side of the business is just as attractive as on the handheld side of the business.

BAY: Eric Benhamou of 3Com, thanks for joining us tonight on MONEYLINE.

BENHAMOU: Thank you.

BAY: Stuart.

VARNEY: Ahead on MONEYLINE, all's fair in love and divorce wars. The ugly custody battle between Revlon's Ron Perelman and his ex-wife.

VARNEY: A story tonight about a corporate titan involved in a very messy and very public divorce. The custody battle involving Revlon's Ron Perelman continued today in a New York courtroom with testimony from his ex-wife. Their fight gives a rare glimpse inside the world of the super wealthy.

Allan Dodds Frank looks at the case of a little girl at the heart of a big-money battle.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ALLAN DODDS FRANK, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Patricia Duff, the former wife of the Revlon chairman Ronald Perelman, says her 4-year-old daughter needs a million and a half dollars a year to support the lifestyle her mother wants for her.

Duff was married to Perelman, often regarded as New York's richest man, for less than two years. Now they are locked in a bitter court fight over their daughter, who shuttles between the two.

PATRICIA DUFF: This is just to try to provide for Caleigh some reasonable lifestyle so that she is not -- she has a wonderful life of yachts and private jets and helicopters with her father. And obviously we're not asking for anything remotely resembling that, but something resembling a normal Upper East Side kind of upbringing for a child of privilege, which is what she is.

FRANK: Perelman's net worth is estimated at somewhere between $4 billion to $6 six billion. But Duff's not poor, either. She says she is worth $23 million.

The divorce, however, seems to have boosted Duff's assets. Perelman says he has given his former wife cash, jewelry, property and art work worth an estimated $30 million. So far, Perelman says he paid another $300,000 to look after Caleigh for her education, health care, nannies, camp and $12,000 a month in child support.

But Duff is asking the court for between $108,000 and $131,000 a month for Caleigh's support, in addition to renovations on a possible new home in East Hampton, Long Island, which came up in today's testimony.

In court, Perelman's lawyer attacked what she called Duff's "fantasy budget," that includes $120,000 a year for travel, $60,000 a year for a nanny, and more than $1.5 million in one-time redecorating costs.

State Supreme Court Justice Franklin Weissberg allowed Duff to testify about her daughter's potential future needs, but said there were clearly items that may not be covered by child support.

(on camera): This saga is far from over. There are more child support hearings, more child custody hearings, and even a suit about the prenuptial agreement, even though the divorce is final.

As the judge said today, if the lawyers would just stop bickering with one another, the case might be over in his lifetime.

Allan Dodds Frank, CNN financial news. New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: You know, as interesting as it maybe to read about figures like that and the twists and turns in a story like that, you just can't help but feel terribly for that child to have this tragically played out in the headlines.

BAY: It's grossly unfair to her.

urn:contentItem:5971-FJN1-F190-V4PJ-00000-00Nasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case Update2013-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisNasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case Update

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the FOX Business Network. Now, here's Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. We are taking a look at the markets this morning after yesterday's flash freeze at the NASDAQ, it's been a fairly flat morning today. We currently got future is in the red, Dow futures are down about 15, we've got the S&P down about one point, the NASDAQ is down about a quarter of a point.

Looking over at oil and gold, those are in the green this morning, we've got oil up about $0.16 cents, gold is up almost $4. Looking at Asia, those markets finished today mixed and for all the details on how they got there, let's go to business reporter Jacqueline Maddock in Beijing. Hi, Jacqueline.

JACQUELINE MADDOCK, BUSINESS REPORTER: Hi, Diane. Yes. It was a bit of a mixed results here for Friday afternoon, here in the mainland and also in Hong Kong. Markets lost ground throughout the afternoon largely because of some pretty disappointing corporate results particularly from Everbright Security if you remember that, the brokerage firm responsible for last Friday's fat-finger fiasco and it was the banks did the biggest falls today, that whispers that the PBO is preparing to unleash the new regulations on China's banking sector, China merchant banks down more than three percent.

But as you say, a different story in Japan, the Nikkei climbed Diane, more than two percent, and every markets that day indeed in the green which is a -- and that was as the yen moved up to the 99 point level accept the Tepco, Diane. Obviously Tepco, the Fukushima nuclear plant operator -- Tepco, fell another five percent at it looks that though as contamination leak has -- some way to play out (INAUDIBLE). Across to Australia though there where markets climbed almost four percent still running high on China's PMI numbers from yesterday, results of stocks love to see signs that China's economy is getting back on track -- Diane.

MACEDO: All right. Jacqueline Maddock from Beijing. Thanks, Jacqueline.

And now, for a look at the European markets, let's go live to London where Jan Lambregts, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank is now joining us. Jan, we saw some positive second quarter GDP reports from the UK and Germany confirmed by the follow-up reading. Any surprise there, and why aren't markets having more reaction to that?

It looks like we just lost Jan. We will try to get him back in a second but let's take a look at the European markets. You can see London up about 16, Parris is down about 12, Frankfurt up about three. Again, those positive GDP report possibly being mitigated by a little un-eased there over the NASDAQ freeze. But let's take a look at some of the important economic news we'll be looking forward to and one of them is a big meeting coming up, some of the most important economic figures in the world are gathering in Jackson Hole, Wyoming for the Kansas City Fed's annual conference but one difference is here, is that the biggest figure of the mall, Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke won't be attending due to a scheduling conflict.

The main focus of the conference will be the impact of the Fed's unconventional policies both at home and abroad and FOX Business's Peter Barnes is there. He will have reports for us throughout the morning.

And we've got Jan Lambregts back again, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank. Jan, I'm not sure if you heard my question the first-time, but we're looking at these GDP reports from the UK and Germany both coming in positive. Any big surprise here?

JAN LAMBREGTS, RABOBANK FINANCIAL MARKETS RESEARCH: Not really. And I don't think the markets really watching it too closely, second revisions, it adds to the general trend that things are a little bit better in Europe but still not great. I think a lot of people in the market can be watching more of these headlines coming out of Jackson Hole and thinking what that would mean for, for tapering than watching these GDP figures.

MACEDO: Markets still seem a little tentative today. You know, good GDP information and yet, they're fairly flat. Paris is even down. Are people tentative this morning over what happened at the NASDAQ yesterday?

LAMBREGTS: I don't think that is not necessarily overshadowing. Like I said, I think the more tentative reacting to positive GDP which is a fairly old number, second quarters after all, more worried that had lines later today as more news comes from Jackson Hole, actually shift perceptions in how likely tapering is and how much tapering is we will see in September.

MACEDO: All right. It's all about stimulus, Jan Lambregts at Rabobank. We appreciate it. Thanks.

LAMBREGTS: You're welcome.

MACEDO: And the Wall Street Journal says, federal prosecutors are turning up the pressure in an insider-trading case against the former portfolio manager at SAC Capital. A new indictment unsealed yesterday alleges that Matthew Martoma spoke to a second doctor involved in an Alzheimer's drug trial at the heart of the case. Martoma is accused of using insider information about results of that drug trial to allow SAC Capital to make $275 million in profits. He is due to go on trial in November and a hearing is set for this morning.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on FOX Business giving you the power to prosper.

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and gentlemen, IMUS IN THE MORNING.

IMUS: So, Doug Chrispin (ph), he's a -- but he's a local rancher and he's doing all kinds of stuff, he won the New Mexico, may it's a national bow and arrow contest that I told you about Mike, from Texas, bans all these -- here. So he says to me, you know, it took awhile for Delbert McClinton to catch on in Austin. All right.

I said, who's -- they found that of course. So he says who is better? Name one person who is better in Austin than Delbert McClinton? He said, there are lots of people. I said what? I didn't have my gun with me, fortunately.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Thank God. Yes.

IMUS: He said Omar and the Howlers.

(LAUGHTER)

BERNARD MCGUIRK, PROGRAM PRODUCER: Oh, those guys.

WARNER WOLF, SPORTSCASTER: Oh, yes.

MCSHANE: Omar and the Howlers?

IMUS: I said, Omar and the Howlers?

WOLF: Sure.

IMUS: So, we were at the horse barn, up at the horse barn. So, I got in the truck and went back to the house and go to iTunes.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: And listened to Omar and the Howlers.

MCSHANE: Uh-huh.

IMUS: And they suck.

MCSHANE: Hey, Omar.

IMUS: I thought he was kidding.

MCSHANE: He said, Omar --

IMUS: And then he is a big Joe Walsh fan. You know? I said, well, have you seen that Eagles? Didn't have any interest. Do you like the Eagles? He said they are all right. So when I first heard the Eagles, sounded like a cross between the Beach Boys and the four perhaps.

MCSHANE: Oh-oh!

IMUS: Well.

MCGUIRK: You got to carry that gun at all times.

MCSHANE: Yes, be ready.

IMUS: The only place I don't carry it is on the ranch for some reason.

LOU RUFINO, PROGRAM ENGINEER: Omar and the Howlers?

IMUS: Omar and the Howlers?

RUFINO: I'm probably the only person who knew that band that you just mentioned.

IMUS: Really?

RUFINO: Yes. I played that band in college.

IMUS: Oh, you did.

RUFINO: -- Back in school and they still together barely alive.

IMUS: Well, they may not, he is going back years, so.

RUFINO: Omar and the Howlers.

GUNZELMAN: This guy is crazy.

IMUS: That is insane, didn't he?

MCGUIRK: Lunacy.

IMUS: Paul Begala is coming up this morning. We no longer need him, so.

MCGUIRK: Yes.

MCSHANE: That's not right.

IMUS: One of my new best friends, one of them, is Bill Powers, the president of U.T., the University of Texas. So, I better not blow of Begala just yet. You know? And Tom Friedman. Hey, Warner?

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Who won those little league world series games?

MCGUIRK: Tijuana beat Panama. So, Tijuana, they will now play Tokyo for the international championship and the Westport Washington State game was rained out. So, they will play today at 3:00.

IMUS: Right.

MCGUIRK: And the winner will play Chula Vista for the title on Sunday.

IMUS: And the winner of that will play either Tijuana or Tokyo.

MCGUIRK: Probably.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Which is it? Tijuana or --

WOLF: Well, Tijuana beat Panama. So, Tijuana will play Tokyo.

IMUS: That is what I just said.

MCSHANE: Right.

WOLF: That's right.

MCSHANE: We got it, yes.

WOLF: Yes. We had some other stories too.

IMUS: What are they?

WOLF: Well, the umpire, they blew a call in the Yankee game which is going to fit right in with next year's videotape replay. They messed up a caught ball and called it a trap and we have got Ryan Braun, what a phony, man. Instead of --

IMUS: Really?

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: You're kidding, Warner.

WOLF: He comes out --

IMUS: Hey, Tom, should we have a breaking news thing up on the FOX NewsChannel, the business channel?

WOLF: That's right. This just in. But the way he did it, he apologize that he made a mistake, but it was issued in a statement. I mean, he didn't even have the, you know, guts to stand up and faced the press. Really weak. And the other thing, you had two exhibition football games last night. And finally we are going to hear about Jeremy Lin, cut out the whining. Remember him? Jeremy Lin.

IMUS: Yes, of course.

MCGUIRK: Today is his birthday.

WOLF: Oh, it is?

IMUS: Yes. He's 25 today.

WOLF: Well, maybe give him some slack.

IMUS: Jay Mohr, of the funnier people on the planet is 43 today. OK.

MCGUIRK: Happy Birthday.

IMUS: And Dagen McDowell is not here again.

MCSHANE: She's out again, yes.

MCGUIRK: Oh, man.

IMUS: So, I said, well, she said she can't put anything on her face. How about a paper bag?

MCSHANE: Yes, she did. You went there. It wasn't funny.

IMUS: And there is something here we don't know. I don't know what it is. But man, there is something here. Hey, what happened to the NASDAQ yesterday?

MCSHANE: Yes. It was a mess with the computers, they don't know 100 percent what happened but they had to halt the number, all the stocks that trade on it and the middle of the day, it went down for hours which is odd, Wall Street has had a number of computer problems the last few years but there is a report this morning, there may have been some connectivity issues with another exchange so they continue their investigation. No panic.

IMUS: NASDAQ stocks.

MCSHANE: Yes, no panic on the market though. You know?

IMUS: You want to get listed on the NASDAQ, you can't get on the big one. Right?

MCGUIRK: No. That's Apple and all these big tech companies if you're over on the NASDAQ, Google, Microsoft.

IMUS: Oh, they are?

MCGUIRK: Yes, so.

IMUS: I have been to see Cavuto yesterday, he looks great. You know, that?

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: Sometimes he needs to take good care of himself as he should. But man, he looks terrific. He is really good. You know who else is pretty good is that Charles Payne guy.

MCSHANE: Charles Payne, yes, absolutely, good guy. Yep.

MCGUIRK: No pain, no gain.

MCSHANE: That's right.

IMUS: What is coming up with you, Bernie?

MCGUIRK: Sydney Leathers.

IMUS: Oh God.

MCGUIRK: Yes. Well, this is true. She made a porn tape.

IMUS: Oh, please.

MCGUIRK: .called Weiner and me but that is not where this stops. She very well may have exposed herself to HIV.

MCSHANE: Oh, wow!

IMUS: Not amusing. That is your hilarious Bernie briefing this morning?

MCGUIRK: I was not presenting that as a joke.

MCSHANE: No punch-line there.

MCGUIRK: That's a story. You remember that kid that gave the rousing speech at Georgia tech?

IMUS: Oh, yes.

MCGUIRK: Well, he may have ripped it off from somebody. And he was interviewed by your friend Neil Cavuto yesterday. We have little piece of that.

IMUS: OK.

MCGUIRK: Cavuto is -- all over him, just the -- it was great. But he may not be for real.

IMUS: Rob Bartlett and Tony Powell are both here this morning. They're both appearing places. Rob is going to be at the Leavitt Theater in Ogunquit, Maine.

MCGUIRK: Ogunquit.

IMUS: Yes. September 21st. For tickets, go to Robshow.com. And Tony Powell, Powell to the People, he will be appearing at the Belmar Theater on Saturday, September 28th. That is coming up here pretty soon and you can get tickets to that by either calling that theater there. The Belmar Theater, or go to NewYorkentertainmentclub.com. I guess, he gets stuff there. It is 13 after the hour, let's do some news. And here with that is Connell McShane. Good morning, Connell.

MCSHANE: Hey, good morning, I-man. The number of refugees created by the Syrian civil war has not topped one million, a million refugees and a U.N. agency adding to that says 740,000 of them are children under age 11. So, some numbers, it all comes out as we are seeing new pictures of what the rebels claim are another chemical weapons attack.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: And this is the fourteenth time that the central regime uses chemical weapons against innocent civilians and each time we've asked and we've said that the international community does not move this, the regime will enlarge the scale that use these chemical weapons.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: And the U.N. secretary-general did say today, these claims of chemical weapons must be investigated immediately. We also have reports this morning coming in of Israeli airstrikes just south of Beirut said to be a response to four rockets that were fired yesterday into Israel. Back here at home, you mention the problems on Wall Street yesterday, computer problems at the NASDAQ, trading stocks listed there. The Apples and the Google of the world, a lot of big tech names were halted in the middle of the day because of problems with the system that disseminates quotes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: Is it going to affect the way that they look at individual companies and want to invest in companies for 10, 15 or 20 years? No. It will just going to say that this game is not really being played.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Jonathan Kurpido (ph) works at the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Now, to get more on that, this web site All Things D is reporting this morning. NASDAQ thinks the issue may be a problem with connectivity at a rival exchange.

IMUS: What does that mean?

MCSHANE: This another digital exchange, NYSCR by the way, the New York Stock Exchange digital component that there may have been problems with the two exchanges connecting with one another. Apparently, according to this report, and they are basically saying --

IMUS: Each other by the way. But go ahead.

MCSHANE: You are right. May say, more on this later on but I don't know exactly what the --

IMUS: How do we know it wasn't deliberate?

MCGUIRK: Sabotage.

MCSHANE: Well, there all these rumors going around yesterday, and it's where the NASDAQ was not really that transparent about it, didn't talk about it during the day, it's hard to get all of them, there are no comments and then the rumors, what if there was a cyber attack and all this kind of thing. That is what people were worried about.

MCGUIRK: Yes, the Russians.

MCSHANE: But no evidence of that at all and now they're saying that could have been the exchanges, digital exchanges having trouble connecting with each other but --

IMUS: Everybody is lying.

MCSHANE: Probably.

IMUS: Don't you think?

MCSHANE: Well, the thing, you know, I thought there was sort of reassuring about it is, that the markets, not like the market -- or crashed yesterday on this when people, you know, wasn't that many jitters.

IMUS: Yes.

MCSHANE: The Dow was actually up. The NASDAQ ended up. So, you know, got through it. And they've been computer problems in the past. The last big one I guess was like three years ago. Although, the NASDAQ had big time issue about Facebook IPO. You may remember.

MCGUIRK: Yes.

MCSHANE: Yes. That was a mess. But this, we will see. The investigation continues and we will get more on it later today, exactly what happened, so.

IMUS: Oh, yes, great.

MCSHANE: Well, from Washington --

IMUS: Sixteen after the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Connell continues.

MCSHANE: Well, you'll going to start hearing talk about a possible government shutdown again. I know you will be looking forward to that. More than a third of House Republicans urging the Speaker John Boehner to shut down the government rather than fund the president's health-care law. They sent him a letter on that 80 Republicans yesterday.

And then we have this U.S. soldier who killed 16 civilians in Afghanistan last year, he apologized yesterday for the first time for what he called his act of cowardice. The Staff Sergeant Robert Bales is in the middle of a sentencing hearing. Here is Marc Edwards, he's a friend of his who used to play in the NFL, this guy Marc Edwards, he spoke with reporters.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARC EDWARDS, FORMER NFL PLAYER: The person I knew a long time ago has changed quite a bit, the experience that he's had over there. I am not in a position to understand. None of us are.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: None of us are, he says. Well, the sentencing hearing will continue there. And there's no --

IMUS: Why are you repeating what the people are saying?

MCSHANE: I just thought it was a little fuzzy.

IMUS: Sounds like Conan O'Brien.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: This portion of the IMUS IN THE MORNING program sponsored by Hackensack University Medical Center, a place where medicine meets innovation. What were you saying now?

MCSHANE: Well, no verdict for the Fort Hood shooter. That continues deliberations yesterday. And the final thing in the news is Bradley Manning who we talked about a lot in the show yesterday. He says, he felt that he has been a female since childhood and he wants people to refer to him as Chelsea. So, this is the convicted Wiki leaker so to speak. Back in forth, Leavenworth begin serving 35 years in a military prison.

Now, a military spokesman said, if Bradley wants to change his name to Chelsea, a name change would have to be approved in court, then a petition submitted to the army to make it official. So, that's where we are on all that.

IMUS: The Godfather will have some thoughts on Bradley Manning and his wishes coming up here in just a little bit. This moment is also sponsored by the Hackensack University Medical Center, a place where medicine meets innovation, the home of the Deirdre Imus environmental health center. So, well, any business news? Business news incidentally Connell.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: Is presented by this clown over here at the -- well, he is not a clown, that is unfortunate, Don.

MCSHANE: Clown?

IMUS: Dr. Gill Leatherman.

MCSHANE: Oh!

IMUS: Hit the cancer.

MCSHANE: Hit the cancer, baby.

IMUS: Hit the cancer. Shut-up.

MCSHANE: Yes, it's OK.

IMUS: This radio search deal, he has got going.

MCSHANE: Right.

IMUS: You can call Dr. Gill Leatherman at 212-scam -- no, not scam.

MCSHANE: No, no, that's not the word.

IMUS: That's unfortunate.

MCSHANE: No.

IMUS: 212-choices. What is going on in business news other than the tedious NASDAQ deal?

MCSHANE: Well, that's the big I guess story up. I'll give you an update on the markets on where we are. The Dow futures are down a little bit this morning. But the Dow was up yesterday, actually the first time it was up in seven sessions. Got lost a little bit in that NASDAQ story.

IMUS: I'll be darn.

MCSHANE: .of 66 to 14,963. So, not much of an effect in terms of the markets going up and down from that NASDAQ mess, the traders able to shake it off. Commerce Department today releasing some numbers on new home sales on housing numbers, Dow futures are down this morning by 18 points ahead to all that.

IMUS: Is that it?

MCSHANE: Well, I mean, yes, there's --

IMUS: OK. Can't just stop talking. I thought you had a stroke.

MCSHANE: I thought --

IMUS: Well, no. But just stop talking. What's the matter with you?

RUFINO: He stopped.

IMUS: Well, I know he stopped but I mean, back to you, I-man, anything.

MCSHANE: That will be the way --

IMUS: No, no, no.

RUFINO: Connell do it every time.

(TALKING OVER EACH OTHER)

I am Connell McShane.

MCSHANE: Almost 20 minutes past.

IMUS: Omar and the Howlers.

MCGUIRK: Back to you, I-man.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Doug Crispin's big band is the Beatles I guess to him. I guess they are out of AustinTexas, they're coming up here, he told me they were better than Delbert McClinton. I mean, you -- that is insanity, isn't it? Never heard anything like that.

MCSHANE: Never.

RUFINO: I can't believe my ears.

IMUS: There is nobody better than Delbert McClinton. Anyway, Warner with sports is sponsored by Peerless Boilers. Go to Peerlessboilers.com and get one of them. Anyway, it's 20 minutes after the hour, here is Warner Wolf. Good morning, Warner.

WOLF: Good morning, I-man.

IMUS: Yankees beat the Jays five-three, they sweep the series make it ten of 12, they cut the race for the last wild card team, the three-and- a-half, blown call by the umpire in the bottom of the fifth gave the Yankees the lead for good. Bases loaded, one-out, Michael Kay, Yes Network.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL KAY, YES NETWORK: (INAUDIBLE) To the second and it is a double play. He's tagging everybody but it is a double play to end the inning. Did he kick the catch? Now, they're saying that he didn't make the catch.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WOLF: Well, if you watch your FOX Business, you can see that he did indeed make the catch. So instead of a double play to end the inning, Wells is given an RBI and the Yankees take the lead. Well, that is one of the things they will correct next year with video tape replay. Dodgers beat the Marlins six-nothing. Clayton Kershaw on the shut out, he's earned run average is now 1.72. And Brian Wilson pitched for the first time in a year and a half in the ninth inning, he struck out two batters and Wilson has been offered $1 million to shave his beard by 800razors.com.

MCGUIRK: He looks scary like that, man.

WOLF: Pirates and Cardinals win, Pirates by one. Ryan Braun --

IMUS: Maybe could have fought ahead with this and had a photograph of him that we could have put up. I guess not.

MCGUIRK: He makes the duck dynasty guys look like Park Avenue socialites.

MCSHANE: He really does.

WOLF: What we did have him after the game, Brian Wilson with this brief comment.

MCGUIRK: Oh, no.

WOLF: Ryan Braun has issued a statement through the Brewers. They talked about a guy, he say, he said he was sorry he took the PEDs during the --

IMUS: You and Doug are going down.

WOLF: Two-11 MVP year. You know, what? Braun ought to give back the MVP trophy and give it to Matt Kemp.

IMUS: That is enough sports. I am bored now.

WOLF: OK. How come, I don't know about a Thursday night football game?

WOLF: Thursday football. I've got it. Lions beat the Patriots 40 to nine.

IMUS: How come there wasn't any.

WOLF: There were two.

IMUS: They were?

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Why you didn't tell me about this?

WOLF: Well, because you said that was the end of this --

IMUS: Well, no, but the Lions beat the Patriots -- what?

WOLF: Forty to nine. Patriots turned the ball over three of the first four possessions.

IMUS: Tebow play?

WOLF: Tebow did not play.

MCSHANE: Oh, God!

WOLF: Not a good sign.

MCGUIRK: He got to bail out Hernandez.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Twenty three after the hour. What is coming up in the briefing, Bernie?

MCGUIRK: Well, Sydney Leathers may have HIV and we have that kid who may be a fraud and Ben Affleck, as Batman.

IMUS: OK. That is all. This would be Omar and the Howlers. Doug Crispin, told me with a straight face why you thought this loser was better than Delbert McClinton. I mean, how do you even say that with the --

(MUSIC PLAYING)

ANNOUNCER: IMUS IN THE MORNING.

IMUS: Are you kidding me? Some fat hillbilly screaming his guts out? Well, that is ridiculous. If you have not ordered your MyPillow yet, you probably are missing out. You have missed out. I'm also irritated this morning because I slept completely straight through the night. When I woke up, I had to get up. I hate that. Sleeping with the mushy pillow and wake up and don't have any energy and I obviously have energy this morning, so what are you going to do? What is you going to do?

You know MyPillow has got this new deal now, you order two of them, they will give you a go anywhere pillow for nothing, 60 day money back guarantee on the MyPillows. If you decide you don't like them, they gave your money back, and you can keep the go anywhere pillow. So, you can't pass this up. So, go to MyPillow.com and type in the word Imus, get 25 percent off. Get your two pillows, try them, if you like them, keep them, if you don't, get your money back. And still keep the go anywhere pillow for nothing. Come on. Mypillow.com. Do it.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACEDO: Good morning, everyone. I am Diane Macedo. And Moody's investor service says, it may cut the credit ratings of major U.S. banks due to the possibility of reduced government support for the institutions if they ran into financial trouble. The list of banks includes JP Morgan Chase and Goldman Sachs. Moody's also says, it may downgrade Wells Fargo and Morgan Stanley bonds and it says Bank of America and Citigroup bonds may also be downgraded for the same reasons but they could also be upgraded because the bank's operations are improving.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS: Good morning, Don and to all of your listeners and viewers, we are live at the Nasdaq MarketSite.

You know, there are many exchanges, but the two biggest, the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq, one of them went down yesterday for a full three hours.

Throwing the entire trading system for all of you who maybe have 401(k)s or trade stocks, it went down for a full three hours and of course, now, it's been attributed to a highly technical glitch.

We're joined now by the CEO of the Nasdaq, Bob Greifeld. Thank you for being here --

ROBERT GREIFELD, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, NASDAQ: I'm glad to have you here, Liz.

CLAMAN: OK, this is not a great day for you, this was a nightmare yesterday, but it was also a nightmare for companies like Yahoo!, Apple, Google who list on the Nasdaq but also the individual investor.

Right off the bat, I have to ask you because so many people were questioning this. Was there any indication of any kind of computer hacking or system hacking here?

GREIFELD: No, none whatsoever. So, this had nothing to do with hacking. Hacking is a fact of life but had nothing to do with the problem yesterday.

CLAMAN: That worries some people that it was an internal system because it indicates to some people, you guys don't have your arms wrapped around your system?

GREIFELD: Well, certainly we're deeply disappointed with what happened yesterday and what we had to do is improve what I call defensive driving.

So, our system by itself was working but you have interconnections in the world we live in today and we have to handle bad actions from some of those people connected to us.

And we have to improve on that. So, we're deeply disappointed but I would highlight that one of the reasons it took three hours was, we have a first and foremost responsibility for fair and orderly markets.

So, we spent two and a half hours really making sure the entire industry, we had opened telephone lines with them, we made sure the entire industry was ready to come live and we did come live, we came live quite successfully and finished the day in normal course of business.

CLAMAN: Nobody begrudges you that moment where you have to work and make sure that once you do press go again, it's going to be fine.

What they do get very upset about, Bob, is the lack of communication. I talked to CEOs of Nasdaq-traded companies who said I got nothing.

I'm sitting in meetings, I'm checking my Blackberry, I'm checking my phone, there's nothing from the Nasdaq.

They do know that you were putting out some 20 missives to the trading community, but that's not the CEOs of all of these companies who are worried about their stocks.

What's wrong with your communication system?

GREIFELD: Well, our communication system I think worked well yesterday. It can always be improved.

First order of businesses to focus on solving the problem and then dealing with people directly involved with the problem.

Now, in one of those open lines we had people representing our issuers on the call and they were -- they are to give regular updates out.

We gave a formal update out after the close of trading which we wanted to do. So, I think we did well, we'll certainly reflect upon how we communicate, see if we can do better.

CLAMAN: Can't you just --

GREIFELD: But certainly --

CLAMAN: Hire somebody to work the phones and call the IR offices? The --

GREIFELD: Oh, they were doing that --

CLAMAN: You know --

GREIFELD: Although we had teams --

CLAMAN: Investor relations offices --

GREIFELD: No --

CLAMAN: On the stock --

GREIFELD: We had teams of people doing that. As I'm saying, we had the people responsible for the issuers on the open lines so they could hear first-hand exactly what was going on.

They were taking inbound calls, we took hundreds of inbound calls, reaching, making outbound calls. So, there was active communication going on.

In this type of situation, you probably didn't get to every single CEO or every single IRO, but we communicated quite actively to a large number of them.

Then the official communication went out after the close of trading day to everybody.

CLAMAN: OK --

GREIFELD: Right, so, it happened you know, quite rapidly.

CLAMAN: I get the explanations but we had former Securities and Exchange Commission head, Harvey Pitt on yesterday, he was very harsh.

You were probably busy working the situation, but he said the Nasdaq handled this "terribly". What he didn't like too was when you started the systems up.

He said you only allowed trading in certain stocks, and he said how can you be fair when you're only allowing certain stocks to get up --

GREIFELD: Well, I think it's hard for people outside direct involvement with the problem to comment and comment intelligently on it.

So we have --

CLAMAN: Well, you're taking the smack at Harvey Pitt?

GREIFELD: Well --

CLAMAN: I mean, he's not --

GREIFELD: I'm just saying for anybody who is not there, right? So, they -- you know the people who are not on the open lines, who are not in the head trader alert communication, it's hard for them to know, right?

And hard for them to comment intelligently in terms of what happened. So, everybody was directly involved, the exchanges were on what's called the UTP line.

SIP arranged a line with our members, in addition to that, we had the head trader alert. So, that happened all the way and each plan, right?

And we solved the problem within half an hour, right? And certain members made a request in terms of having a longer period of time to quote --

CLAMAN: OK --

GREIFELD: Instead of five-15 minutes, that cost a half hour of time to get ready for that. So, that communication was there and I think to the extent that anybody who wasn't involved became involved, we said OK, that was as active as you can get.

CLAMAN: You guys are considered the sexier exchange.

GREIFELD: Yes.

CLAMAN: You know, you've got the lots of the dotcoms of the world but there are some that aren't public yet. Twitter, for example, everybody is waiting for that to go public.

Do you think you've lost Twitter? Can you make a 30-second pitch to Twitter to say here is why you should still consider listing on Nasdaq?

GREIFELD: Well, I think it's important to recognize that we aspire towards perfection with respect to the operations of our systems.

And technology people, Twitter and all the companies recognize that. We will always fall short of that but we have to keep trying, right?

And we get better all the time, and the number of problems have actually declined. But probably as importantly, we have to make sure we handle problems in the proper way, right?

So, what we did yesterday, right, nobody wanted to be down for three hours and if we had been quite reckless we could have been up a lot sooner than that.

But I think the procedures we had in place, the industry had in place worked well. So, we would say to any technology-based company, we're not perfect, right?

We're 99.99 percent perfect, we're not perfect, we'll have problems but if we do, we're going to make sure we maintain a fair and orderly market.

And that's what we did yesterday. And it's important to recognize the fact we didn't trade for several hours. If you're a traditional long investor, a mom-and-pop, institutional investor, that three hours doesn't matter.

You're buying the stock for the longer period of time, right? And the fact is, every single person was in the same situation. Nobody was relatively advantaged or disadvantaged because the market was down for that --

CLAMAN: I --

GREIFELD: Period of time.

CLAMAN: Some moms and pops are a little more sophisticated these days and like to trade a lot. But either way, we appreciate you coming on Fox --

GREIFELD: Right --
