FRANCESA: No, I don't know. I disagree completely. Disagree completely and I think it's ridiculous. He has 4,000 hits? Why? We now, the Major League and the Japanese leagues are now co-leagues? He has 2,700 major league hits. He doesn't have anything more than that. I think it's utterly ridiculous that we are now going to act like Ichiro got 4,000 hits. He didn't get 4,000 hits, he has 2,700 hits. I give you that, but only 2700 hits as far as we're concerned.

He doesn't have 3,000 hits and how the heck does he have 4,000 hits? I mean, when did that start? When did we start mingling the Japan statistics with the American statistics? He's got 2,700 Major League hits. He doesn't have 4,000 Major League hits. It doesn't make sense to me. When did we decide that? Who decided the Japanese hits are equal to the major league hits. We've got the statistics.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

IMUS: Stop, stop, if I wanted to listen to him, I'd listen. I know he does that, repeats himself ad nauseam. I love Mike, but --

RUFINO: I think it's a great accomplishment.

IMUS: But it's unlistenable.

MCGUIRK: And sportscreed.com, they write, of course, Francesa's argument is fatuous, the only surprise there being that he stayed awake long enough to make it.

IMUS: What are you doing, be like if you're trying to rope, Wyatt.

MCSHANE: Good morning, Wyatt.

MCGUIRK: Wait a second, what's going on there.

IMUS: Are you roping today?

WYATT: Yes.

IMUS: OK, I'm going to fool with you, talk to you when you're backing your horse in the box on the rope.

WYATT: You're not doing anything, you're talking.

MCSHANE: Physical.

WYATT: And having breakfast while you're talking.

IMUS: You're purposely going out of your way to annoy me.

WYATT: I'm bringing you breakfast.

IMUS: If I could, I'd whip your little ass no, no, leave my yogurt away.

MCGUIRK: And have your own kid spitting in your coffee soon.

RUFINO: Soon?

IMUS: He makes me laugh as much as anybody on the planet. God, he's funny. What are you saying?

MCGUIRK: I was saying that I'm done and we're late for Tom Friedman, cutting into Tom Friedman's time. It's an outrage.

IMUS: So, get the whining comy on, 25 until the hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the Fox Business Network, and now, here is Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS: Good morning, everyone. Some of the most important economic figures in the world are gathering in Jackson Hole, Wyoming for the fed annual conference. A big difference this year is that Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke won't be attending due to a scheduling conflict. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi will also miss this meeting. The main focus of the conference, though, will be the impact of the fed's unconventional policies at home and abroad.

Now let's get the latest on weather from meteorologist Maria Molina in our Fox Business Weather Center. Hi, Maria.

MARIA MOLINA, FOX BUSINESS WEATHER CENTER: Hi. Good morning, Diane. Good morning, everyone. Today we're looking at a beautiful day across sections of the northeast. Yesterday, we had storms roll through, leaving behind lower humidity and also pleasant temperatures, like in New York City, 83 degrees for a high temperature and parts of the Midwest and the plains heating in the upper 80's and widespread 90's and feeling like August across the center of the country.

And out west, a danger of fires, and red flags, that leaves the hours and eventually into the west. Much-need rain across parts of Nevada, Utah and across parts of Southern California, several inches could fall out here so flooding could be a concern. Diane, back to you.

MACEDO: All right, that's Maria Molina from the weather center. Let's take a quick look at futures. Those have been searching for direction today. Dow futures are now up by 2 points. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now.

IMUS: It's 20 minutes until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Please welcome now from the New York sometimes, Tom Friedman. Good morning, Mr. Friedman.

TOM FRIEDMAN, "THE NEW YORK TIMES" (via telephone): Good morning, Don.

IMUS: Wonder how long the "New York Times" is going to stay in business?

FRIEDMAN: Gosh, you know, I really think, you know, we've got a strong enough global brand, I don't worry about the times per se, but what I worry, if you look at the numbers, our -- the newspaper ads, you know, have been, I don't know how long it is, six, nine, 12 quarters, you know, they continue to decline and you know, you just hope that we'll find a bottom.

We're still making a profit, thank God, but if that doesn't find a bottom, you know, at some point, you know, it will affect obviously what we can do, but you hope it will find a bottom. I don't know if you realize, I think last quarter, the quarter before, we made more money selling the paper than we did from advertising and like that's a huge line to cross.

IMUS: Well, and are you working on another book?

FRIEDMAN: I'm thinking about something, Don. You know, sort of pushing ahead from the last book I did that used to be about just kind of the new phase of globalization where it's going, technology, how it's all merging, how it's affecting business, education, et cetera. It's germinating in my head, but I'm not quite there yet, but thinking about something on the Middle East, too.

IMUS: You're not kidding. That sounds hideous. You've got to come up with a better idea than that. Geez, are you kidding me? Nobody's going to read that.

FRIEDMAN: You want to write a book called "The World Is Flat" nobody's going to read that.

IMUS: Well, no.

FRIEDMAN: I'm thinking about something.

IMUS: That was a great book, though, the olive tree and that stuff, but this latest one. Have you just given up? Said the hell with it?

FRIEDMAN: No.

IMUS: Anyway, let me ask you a couple of serious questions. Syria, what the hell is going on there?

FRIEDMAN: Well, we don't have the conclusive proof, but you look at those pictures of those bodies, don, how they died, unmarked by any kind of wounds, you know, it's pretty clear the regime used some kind of chemical weapon and obviously Obama said that would be a red line. They already crossed it once. What he will do this time once it's conclusively proved, I don't know.

There's a big discussion at the White House yesterday, as you reported, that three hours where they debated what to do. One of the problems, the problem is this so let's say we launched a cruise missile attack in response to this to deter chemical weapons.

What targets to hit. Do you cause more refugee outflow from Syria and destabilize Jordan, for instance? So there's a lot of real-- so many moving parts with this, it's going to be a difficult one to sort out, but, you know, I'm glad they're considering something because once you start introducing those kind of weapons, you know, it's Katie bar the door.

IMUS: What would you recommend that we do?

FRIEDMAN: You know, I would be in favor of -- as I sit here right now, I'd be in favor of some kind of military response at that simply says we're not going to tolerate that. The world is not going to tolerate that.

IMUS: Would you want troops on the ground?

FRIEDMAN: No, no, I'm talking about some kind of aerial response. It's sort of something I'd be ready to consider. I want to see all the facts, they haven't all come out, some kind of response not just by us, but by the world, the allies, NATO that draws a red line there. I think it's something that it's really worth considering.

IMUS: Talking with Tom Friedman from the "New York Times" who probably has an e-mail address at the times in which you can contact him and here is what I'd like you to do, send him some ideas for a book. He hasn't got any. And every day I say to Connell, well, why should I care about Egypt? So, let me ask you, why should I?

FRIEDMAN: You know, there are a lot of reasons, Don. It's a country of 85 million people. It sits astride the Suez Canal. It's the partner with Israel in the Camp David peace treaty and has been traditionally the bedrock of the geopolitics there and the leader of the Arab world, as Egypt goes, so goes the Arab world.

You want the country to have a decent outcome of this revolutionary process. The problem in Egypt right now, Don, you've had two choices historically, that is either the army or the Muslim Brotherhood. In Egypt if you look at its history oscillated between those two for the last 60-odd years.

And the question, really, is can they-- can they find a third way, a way that's actually forward-looking, inclusive, progressive that doesn't just involve one of these narrow-minded options or the other? You know, one of the things that's been rattling around in my head, Don. Princess Di once said with Prince Charles there are three people in this marriage.

IMUS: Yes.

FRIEDMAN: Historically we've looked at Egypt and saying there's two people in the marriage, the Muslim Brotherhood and the army. If that's the choice we'll go with the army, with Mubarak, but we talked about this in earlier conversation, I think there are three people in this story now, there's the military, the Muslim Brotherhood and Mother Nature.

And by that, I mean there is all of these incredible water, environmental population stresses that have built up over the last 60 years, precisely because of the incompetence of the military government and the Muslim Brotherhood in managing the problems and stresses, if they don't get the act together, find a third way that can sort of tilt Egypt forward to deal with some of these problems, Don, half the women in Egypt can't read.

After $30 billion in U.S. aid, over the last 30-odd years, half the women still can't read and these other social stresses I think are just going to blow the place apart.

IMUS: What in your view would be a decent outcome in Egypt?

FRIEDMAN: I think a decent outcome would be a government that would -- where the military says to this government that they've appointed and they actually-- when they ousted the Muslim Brotherhood government they appointed a new president and he appointed a new cabinet. And you know some of these people and they're pretty decent people, if they would assign that government the task of writing a new constitution, one that would guarantee minority rights, that would be -- that would guarantee women's rights, that would be basically progressive leaning and take out some of the bad stuff the Muslim Brotherhood had in the constitution, and begin to organize an elective process gradually.

Giving time for not just the Muslim Brotherhood or Islamists as it were, but the liberal and progressive parties to get organize and contest that election, to put Egypt on that gradual transition path, not to just stop with the military government.

IMUS: Why did you decide to employ the Princess Di analogy?

FRIEDMAN: I have no idea. It popped into my head there. There are three different parties in this story now.

IMUS: You're a weird dude, sometimes, so -- but you do sometimes in your columns it works well.

FRIEDMAN: Yes.

IMUS: Have you gotten away this summer at all?

FRIEDMAN: A little bit. Just kind of on and off. I just turned 60, Don. So I'm going out to California next week.

IMUS: When was your birthday?

FRIEDMAN: July 20th.

IMUS: Well, happy birthday.

FRIEDMAN: Thank you very much.

IMUS: You look pretty good for 60. I guess 60 is -- 60 is getting up there.

FRIEDMAN: I'm trying to take care of myself. In this day and age, there are a few miles on these treads so I'm trying to take care of myself, and looking forward to getting away.

IMUS: In spite of what you think, the times is not long for this world so get a good idea for a book. Tom Friedman.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACEDO: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. It's time to check the markets now, the day after the Nasdaq flash free that halted trading for three hours. The U.S. futures are fairly flat this morning, but now point to go a higher open. Dow futures are up 3. The S&P is up about 1. The Nasdaq is up 3.5.

Over in Europe, we got the second quarter reading on second quarter GDP in the U.K. and Germany, both rose 7/10 of a percent. London is now up about 37. Paris is down barely and Frankfurt is up 16.

The "Wall Street Journal" says that federal prosecutors are turning up the pressure in an insider trading case against a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital. The new indictment unsealed yesterday alleges that Matthew Martoma spoke to a second doctor involved in an Alzheimer's drug trial at the heart of the case.

Martoma is accused of using insider information about results of that drug trial, which then allowed SAC Capital to make $275 million in profits. He's due to go on trial in November. A hearing is set for this morning, SAC Capital has been charged with encouraging insider trader, but Steven Cohen, the hedge fund's founder has not been charged. Cohen and his firm deny any wrongdoing.

Here's a look at commodities now. We're watching oil and gold for you this morning. Those have been also fairly flat. Oil is now down up 13 cents. Gold is up 20. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now.

IMUS: He looks like he is he doesn't have any energy, doesn't he? Here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, coming up on the radio, a fascinating, funny conversation with the great Terry Bradshaw.

MCSHANE: All right.

IMUS: And before that, it's 9:20 Eastern Time on the Fox Business Network. The lying limey, Stuart Varney, so --

MCSHANE: We love Varney.

IMUS: I do like Varney a lot. So I don't know.

MCSHANE: What's wrong?

IMUS: Well, and the Godfather is going to be on to talk about -- I forget what he's going to talk about. What, Godfather.

MCSHANE: Good question.

IMUS: Down, Godfather.

BARTLETT: The gentleman --

IMUS: Can barely hear the Godfather, so the Godfather decided well, mail it in this morning. Did he have his mic off, Connell?

MCSHANE: I think his headphones were down and he couldn't hear.

BARTLETT: Turn it up.

MCSHANE: Now he's better. And solving yet another problem and working through a lot this morning.

IMUS: Got to project, Rob.

BARTLETT: Yes, sir.

MCSHANE: He couldn't hear.

IMUS: Also, you did a -- a lousy job on the last script. Why was that?

BARTLETT: I'm a little under the weather today. It affected my performance, I apologize.

IMUS: What's the matter with you?

BARTLETT: Got a little bit of a -- a touch of a bug, I think.

IMUS: Well, why didn't you tell me that instead of turning in a performance that sucks? Because we don't have to do it, you know?

BARTLETT: Just, I'm going to suck it up, I didn't --

IMUS: No, you didn't suck it up because you gave in like a finocchio.

MCSHANE: Finocchio.

IMUS: To your little sniffles.

BARTLETT: I have 135 fever.

IMUS: OK.

MCSHANE: That's right.

IMUS: You gave in to your 135 degree fever and provided all of us with a weenie performance.

MCSHANE: Struggling, Rob, the last couple.

IMUS: It would be better if you said to me, Don, I don't feel great and I would say, fine. So every time you want off, I mean, you ever -- a problem getting off when you need it? Of course not, neither one of you.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5966-F0P1-DXH2-61MP-00000-00Nasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case Update2013-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:20ZLexisNexisIMUS IN THE MORNING6:00 AM ESTJacqueline Maddock, Jan Lambregts, Jan Randolph, Tom Friedman, Robert GreifeldNEWSBusiness082301cb.220Nasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case UpdateDon Imus, Diane Macedo, Connell McShane, Warner Wolf, Dagen McDowell, Bernard McGuirk, Maria Molina, Lou Rufino, Rob Bartlett, Tony Powell, Carley Shimkus, Michael Gunzelman, Tom Bigfoot Bowman, Nicole Petallides, Peter Barnes, Liz Claman

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the FOX Business Network. Now, here's Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. We are taking a look at the markets this morning after yesterday's flash freeze at the NASDAQ, it's been a fairly flat morning today. We currently got future is in the red, Dow futures are down about 15, we've got the S&P down about one point, the NASDAQ is down about a quarter of a point.

Looking over at oil and gold, those are in the green this morning, we've got oil up about $0.16 cents, gold is up almost $4. Looking at Asia, those markets finished today mixed and for all the details on how they got there, let's go to business reporter Jacqueline Maddock in Beijing. Hi, Jacqueline.

JACQUELINE MADDOCK, BUSINESS REPORTER: Hi, Diane. Yes. It was a bit of a mixed results here for Friday afternoon, here in the mainland and also in Hong Kong. Markets lost ground throughout the afternoon largely because of some pretty disappointing corporate results particularly from Everbright Security if you remember that, the brokerage firm responsible for last Friday's fat-finger fiasco and it was the banks did the biggest falls today, that whispers that the PBO is preparing to unleash the new regulations on China's banking sector, China merchant banks down more than three percent.

But as you say, a different story in Japan, the Nikkei climbed Diane, more than two percent, and every markets that day indeed in the green which is a -- and that was as the yen moved up to the 99 point level accept the Tepco, Diane. Obviously Tepco, the Fukushima nuclear plant operator -- Tepco, fell another five percent at it looks that though as contamination leak has -- some way to play out (INAUDIBLE). Across to Australia though there where markets climbed almost four percent still running high on China's PMI numbers from yesterday, results of stocks love to see signs that China's economy is getting back on track -- Diane.

MACEDO: All right. Jacqueline Maddock from Beijing. Thanks, Jacqueline.

And now, for a look at the European markets, let's go live to London where Jan Lambregts, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank is now joining us. Jan, we saw some positive second quarter GDP reports from the UK and Germany confirmed by the follow-up reading. Any surprise there, and why aren't markets having more reaction to that?

It looks like we just lost Jan. We will try to get him back in a second but let's take a look at the European markets. You can see London up about 16, Parris is down about 12, Frankfurt up about three. Again, those positive GDP report possibly being mitigated by a little un-eased there over the NASDAQ freeze. But let's take a look at some of the important economic news we'll be looking forward to and one of them is a big meeting coming up, some of the most important economic figures in the world are gathering in Jackson Hole, Wyoming for the Kansas City Fed's annual conference but one difference is here, is that the biggest figure of the mall, Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke won't be attending due to a scheduling conflict.

The main focus of the conference will be the impact of the Fed's unconventional policies both at home and abroad and FOX Business's Peter Barnes is there. He will have reports for us throughout the morning.

And we've got Jan Lambregts back again, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank. Jan, I'm not sure if you heard my question the first-time, but we're looking at these GDP reports from the UK and Germany both coming in positive. Any big surprise here?

JAN LAMBREGTS, RABOBANK FINANCIAL MARKETS RESEARCH: Not really. And I don't think the markets really watching it too closely, second revisions, it adds to the general trend that things are a little bit better in Europe but still not great. I think a lot of people in the market can be watching more of these headlines coming out of Jackson Hole and thinking what that would mean for, for tapering than watching these GDP figures.

MACEDO: Markets still seem a little tentative today. You know, good GDP information and yet, they're fairly flat. Paris is even down. Are people tentative this morning over what happened at the NASDAQ yesterday?

LAMBREGTS: I don't think that is not necessarily overshadowing. GREIFELD: Well --

CLAMAN: I mean, he's not --

GREIFELD: I'm just saying for anybody who is not there, right? So, they -- you know the people who are not on the open lines, who are not in the head trader alert communication, it's hard for them to know, right?

SIP arranged a line with our members, in addition to that, we had the head trader alert. So, that happened all the way and each plan, right?

And we solved the problem within half an hour, right? And certain members made a request in terms of having a longer period of time to quote --

CLAMAN: OK --

GREIFELD: Instead of five-15 minutes, that cost a half hour of time to get ready for that. So, that communication was there and I think to the extent that anybody who wasn't involved became involved, we said OK, that was as active as you can get.

CLAMAN: You know, you've got the lots of the dotcoms of the world but there are some that aren't public yet. Twitter, for example, everybody is waiting for that to go public.

GREIFELD: Well, I think it's important to recognize that we aspire towards perfection with respect to the operations of our systems.

And technology people, Twitter and all the companies recognize that. We will always fall short of that but we have to keep trying, right?

And we get better all the time, and the number of problems have actually declined. But probably as importantly, we have to make sure we handle problems in the proper way, right?

So, what we did yesterday, right, nobody wanted to be down for three hours and if we had been quite reckless we could have been up a lot sooner than that.

But I think the procedures we had in place, the industry had in place worked well. So, we would say to any technology-based company, we're not perfect, right?

We're 99.99 percent perfect, we're not perfect, we'll have problems but if we do, we're going to make sure we maintain a fair and orderly market.

And that's what we did yesterday. And it's important to recognize the fact we didn't trade for several hours. If you're a traditional long investor, a mom-and-pop, institutional investor, that three hours doesn't matter.

You're buying the stock for the longer period of time, right? And the fact is, every single person was in the same situation. Nobody was relatively advantaged or disadvantaged because the market was down for that --

IMUS: Talking with Tom Friedman from the "New York Times" who probably has an e-mail address at the times in which you can contact him and here is what I'd like you to do, send him some ideas for a book. He hasn't got any. And every day I say to Connell, well, why should I care about Egypt? So, let me ask you, why should I?

FRIEDMAN: You know, there are a lot of reasons, Don. It's a country of 85 million people. It sits astride the Suez Canal. It's the partner with Israel in the Camp David peace treaty and has been traditionally the bedrock of the geopolitics there and the leader of the Arab world, as Egypt goes, so goes the Arab world.

You want the country to have a decent outcome of this revolutionary process. The problem in Egypt right now, Don, you've had two choices historically, that is either the army or the Muslim Brotherhood. In Egypt if you look at its history oscillated between those two for the last 60-odd years.

And the question, really, is can they-- can they find a third way, a way that's actually forward-looking, inclusive, progressive that doesn't just involve one of these narrow-minded options or the other? You know, one of the things that's been rattling around in my head, Don. Princess Di once said with Prince Charles there are three people in this marriage.

IMUS: Yes.

FRIEDMAN: Historically we've looked at Egypt and saying there's two people in the marriage, the Muslim Brotherhood and the army. If that's the choice we'll go with the army, with Mubarak, but we talked about this in earlier conversation, I think there are three people in this story now, there's the military, the Muslim Brotherhood and Mother Nature.

And by that, I mean there is all of these incredible water, environmental population stresses that have built up over the last 60 years, precisely because of the incompetence of the military government and the Muslim Brotherhood in managing the problems and stresses, if they don't get the act together, find a third way that can sort of tilt Egypt forward to deal with some of these problems, Don, half the women in Egypt can't read.

After $30 billion in U.S. aid, over the last 30-odd years, half the women still can't read and these other social stresses I think are just going to blow the place apart.

IMUS: What in your view would be a decent outcome in Egypt?

FRIEDMAN: I think a decent outcome would be a government that would -- where the military says to this government that they've appointed and they actually-- when they ousted the Muslim Brotherhood government they appointed a new president and he appointed a new cabinet. And you know some of these people and they're pretty decent people, if they would assign that government the task of writing a new constitution, one that would guarantee minority rights, that would be -- that would guarantee women's rights, that would be basically progressive leaning and take out some of the bad stuff the Muslim Brotherhood had in the constitution, and begin to organize an elective process gradually.

Giving time for not just the Muslim Brotherhood or Islamists as it were, but the liberal and progressive parties to get organize and contest that election, to put Egypt on that gradual transition path, not to just stop with the military government.

IMUS: Why did you decide to employ the Princess Di analogy?

FRIEDMAN: I have no idea. It popped into my head there. There are three different parties in this story now.

IMUS: You're a weird dude, sometimes, so -- but you do sometimes in your columns it works well.

FRIEDMAN: Yes.

IMUS: Have you gotten away this summer at all?

FRIEDMAN: A little bit. Just kind of on and off. I just turned 60, Don. So I'm going out to California next week.

IMUS: When was your birthday?

FRIEDMAN: July 20th.

IMUS: Well, happy birthday.

FRIEDMAN: Thank you very much.

IMUS: You look pretty good for 60. I guess 60 is -- 60 is getting up there.

FRIEDMAN: I'm trying to take care of myself. In this day and age, there are a few miles on these treads so I'm trying to take care of myself, and looking forward to getting away.

IMUS: In spite of what you think, the times is not long for this world so get a good idea for a book. Tom Friedman.

MACEDO: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. It's time to check the markets now, the day after the Nasdaq flash free that halted trading for three hours. The U.S. futures are fairly flat this morning, but now point to go a higher open. Dow futures are up 3. The S&P is up about 1. The Nasdaq is up 3.5.

Over in Europe, we got the second quarter reading on second quarter GDP in the U.K. and Germany, both rose 7/10 of a percent. London is now up about 37. Paris is down barely and Frankfurt is up 16.

The "Wall Street Journal" says that federal prosecutors are turning up the pressure in an insider trading case against a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital. The new indictment unsealed yesterday alleges that Matthew Martoma spoke to a second doctor involved in an Alzheimer's drug trial at the heart of the case.

Martoma is accused of using insider information about results of that drug trial, which then allowed SAC Capital to make $275 million in profits. He's due to go on trial in November. A hearing is set for this morning, SAC Capital has been charged with encouraging insider trader, but Steven Cohen, the hedge fund's founder has not been charged. Cohen and his firm deny any wrongdoing.

Here's a look at commodities now. We're watching oil and gold for you this morning. Those have been also fairly flat. Oil is now down up 13 cents. Gold is up 20. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now.

IMUS: He looks like he is he doesn't have any energy, doesn't he? Here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, coming up on the radio, a fascinating, funny conversation with the great Terry Bradshaw.

MCSHANE: All right.

IMUS: And before that, it's 9:20 Eastern Time on the Fox Business Network. The lying limey, Stuart Varney, so --

MCSHANE: We love Varney.

IMUS: I do like Varney a lot. So I don't know.

MCSHANE: What's wrong?

IMUS: Well, and the Godfather is going to be on to talk about -- I forget what he's going to talk about. What, Godfather.

MCSHANE: Good question.

IMUS: Down, Godfather.

BARTLETT: The gentleman --

IMUS: Can barely hear the Godfather, so the Godfather decided well, mail it in this morning. Did he have his mic off, Connell?

MCSHANE: I think his headphones were down and he couldn't hear.

BARTLETT: Turn it up.

MCSHANE: Now he's better. And solving yet another problem and working through a lot this morning.

IMUS: Got to project, Rob.

BARTLETT: Yes, sir.

MCSHANE: He couldn't hear.

IMUS: Also, you did a -- a lousy job on the last script. Why was that?

BARTLETT: I'm a little under the weather today. It affected my performance, I apologize.

IMUS: What's the matter with you?

BARTLETT: Got a little bit of a -- a touch of a bug, I think.

IMUS: Well, why didn't you tell me that instead of turning in a performance that sucks? Because we don't have to do it, you know?

BARTLETT: Just, I'm going to suck it up, I didn't --

IMUS: No, you didn't suck it up because you gave in like a finocchio.

MCSHANE: Finocchio.

IMUS: To your little sniffles.

BARTLETT: I have 135 fever.

IMUS: OK.

MCSHANE: That's right.

IMUS: You gave in to your 135 degree fever and provided all of us with a weenie performance.

MCSHANE: Struggling, Rob, the last couple.

IMUS: It would be better if you said to me, Don, I don't feel great and I would say, fine. So every time you want off, I mean, you ever -- a problem getting off when you need it? Of course not, neither one of you.

urn:contentItem:5JD9-VJP1-JBHT-D0TY-00000-00Nasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case Update2013-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:20ZLexisNexisNasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case UpdateLanhamFULL TEXT

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the FOX Business Network. Now, here's Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. We are taking a look at the markets this morning after yesterday's flash freeze at the NASDAQ, it's been a fairly flat morning today. We currently got future is in the red, Dow futures are down about 15, we've got the S&P down about one point, the NASDAQ is down about a quarter of a point.

Looking over at oil and gold, those are in the green this morning, we've got oil up about $0.16 cents, gold is up almost $4. Looking at Asia, those markets finished today mixed and for all the details on how they got there, let's go to business reporter Jacqueline Maddock in Beijing. Hi, Jacqueline.

JACQUELINE MADDOCK, BUSINESS REPORTER: Hi, Diane. Yes. It was a bit of a mixed results here for Friday afternoon, here in the mainland and also in Hong Kong. Markets lost ground throughout the afternoon largely because of some pretty disappointing corporate results particularly from Everbright Security if you remember that, the brokerage firm responsible for last Friday's fat-finger fiasco and it was the banks did the biggest falls today, that whispers that the PBO is preparing to unleash the new regulations on China's banking sector, China merchant banks down more than three percent.

But as you say, a different story in Japan, the Nikkei climbed Diane, more than two percent, and every markets that day indeed in the green which is a -- and that was as the yen moved up to the 99 point level accept the Tepco, Diane. Obviously Tepco, the Fukushima nuclear plant operator -- Tepco, fell another five percent at it looks that though as contamination leak has -- some way to play out (INAUDIBLE). Across to Australia though there where markets climbed almost four percent still running high on China's PMI numbers from yesterday, results of stocks love to see signs that China's economy is getting back on track -- Diane.

MACEDO: All right. Jacqueline Maddock from Beijing. Thanks, Jacqueline.

And now, for a look at the European markets, let's go live to London where Jan Lambregts, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank is now joining us. Jan, we saw some positive second quarter GDP reports from the UK and Germany confirmed by the follow-up reading. Any surprise there, and why aren't markets having more reaction to that?

It looks like we just lost Jan. We will try to get him back in a second but let's take a look at the European markets. You can see London up about 16, Parris is down about 12, Frankfurt up about three. Again, those positive GDP report possibly being mitigated by a little un-eased there over the NASDAQ freeze. But let's take a look at some of the important economic news we'll be looking forward to and one of them is a big meeting coming up, some of the most important economic figures in the world are gathering in Jackson Hole, Wyoming for the Kansas City Fed's annual conference but one difference is here, is that the biggest figure of the mall, Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke won't be attending due to a scheduling conflict.

The main focus of the conference will be the impact of the Fed's unconventional policies both at home and abroad and FOX Business's Peter Barnes is there. He will have reports for us throughout the morning.

And we've got Jan Lambregts back again, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank. Jan, I'm not sure if you heard my question the first-time, but we're looking at these GDP reports from the UK and Germany both coming in positive. Any big surprise here?

JAN LAMBREGTS, RABOBANK FINANCIAL MARKETS RESEARCH: Not really. And I don't think the markets really watching it too closely, second revisions, it adds to the general trend that things are a little bit better in Europe but still not great. I think a lot of people in the market can be watching more of these headlines coming out of Jackson Hole and thinking what that would mean for, for tapering than watching these GDP figures.

MACEDO: Markets still seem a little tentative today. You know, good GDP information and yet, they're fairly flat. Paris is even down. Are people tentative this morning over what happened at the NASDAQ yesterday?

LAMBREGTS: I don't think that is not necessarily overshadowing. Like I said, I think the more tentative reacting to positive GDP which is a fairly old number, second quarters after all, more worried that had lines later today as more news comes from Jackson Hole, actually shift perceptions in how likely tapering is and how much tapering is we will see in September.

MACEDO: All right. It's all about stimulus, Jan Lambregts at Rabobank. We appreciate it. Thanks.

LAMBREGTS: You're welcome.

MACEDO: And the Wall Street Journal says, federal prosecutors are turning up the pressure in an insider-trading case against the former portfolio manager at SAC Capital. A new indictment unsealed yesterday alleges that Matthew Martoma spoke to a second doctor involved in an Alzheimer's drug trial at the heart of the case. Martoma is accused of using insider information about results of that drug trial to allow SAC Capital to make $275 million in profits. He is due to go on trial in November and a hearing is set for this morning.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on FOX Business giving you the power to prosper.

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and gentlemen, IMUS IN THE MORNING.

IMUS: So, Doug Chrispin (ph), he's a -- but he's a local rancher and he's doing all kinds of stuff, he won the New Mexico, may it's a national bow and arrow contest that I told you about Mike, from Texas, bans all these -- here. So he says to me, you know, it took awhile for Delbert McClinton to catch on in Austin. All right.

I said, who's -- they found that of course. So he says who is better? Name one person who is better in Austin than Delbert McClinton? He said, there are lots of people. I said what? I didn't have my gun with me, fortunately.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Thank God. Yes.

IMUS: He said Omar and the Howlers.

(LAUGHTER)

BERNARD MCGUIRK, PROGRAM PRODUCER: Oh, those guys.

WARNER WOLF, SPORTSCASTER: Oh, yes.

MCSHANE: Omar and the Howlers?

IMUS: I said, Omar and the Howlers?

WOLF: Sure.

IMUS: So, we were at the horse barn, up at the horse barn. So, I got in the truck and went back to the house and go to iTunes.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: And listened to Omar and the Howlers.

MCSHANE: Uh-huh.

IMUS: And they suck.

MCSHANE: Hey, Omar.

IMUS: I thought he was kidding.

MCSHANE: He said, Omar --

IMUS: And then he is a big Joe Walsh fan. You know? I said, well, have you seen that Eagles? Didn't have any interest. Do you like the Eagles? He said they are all right. So when I first heard the Eagles, sounded like a cross between the Beach Boys and the four perhaps.

MCSHANE: Oh-oh!

IMUS: Well.

MCGUIRK: You got to carry that gun at all times.

MCSHANE: Yes, be ready.

IMUS: The only place I don't carry it is on the ranch for some reason.

LOU RUFINO, PROGRAM ENGINEER: Omar and the Howlers?

IMUS: Omar and the Howlers?

RUFINO: I'm probably the only person who knew that band that you just mentioned.

IMUS: Really?

RUFINO: Yes. I played that band in college.

IMUS: Oh, you did.

RUFINO: -- Back in school and they still together barely alive.

IMUS: Well, they may not, he is going back years, so.

RUFINO: Omar and the Howlers.

GUNZELMAN: This guy is crazy.

IMUS: That is insane, didn't he?

MCGUIRK: Lunacy.

IMUS: Paul Begala is coming up this morning. We no longer need him, so.

MCGUIRK: Yes.

MCSHANE: That's not right.

IMUS: One of my new best friends, one of them, is Bill Powers, the president of U.T., the University of Texas. So, I better not blow of Begala just yet. You know? And Tom Friedman. Hey, Warner?

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Who won those little league world series games?

MCGUIRK: Tijuana beat Panama. So, Tijuana, they will now play Tokyo for the international championship and the Westport Washington State game was rained out. So, they will play today at 3:00.

IMUS: Right.

MCGUIRK: And the winner will play Chula Vista for the title on Sunday.

IMUS: And the winner of that will play either Tijuana or Tokyo.

MCGUIRK: Probably.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Which is it? Tijuana or --

WOLF: Well, Tijuana beat Panama. So, Tijuana will play Tokyo.

IMUS: That is what I just said.

MCSHANE: Right.

WOLF: That's right.

MCSHANE: We got it, yes.

WOLF: Yes. We had some other stories too.

IMUS: What are they?

WOLF: Well, the umpire, they blew a call in the Yankee game which is going to fit right in with next year's videotape replay. They messed up a caught ball and called it a trap and we have got Ryan Braun, what a phony, man. Instead of --

IMUS: Really?

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: You're kidding, Warner.

WOLF: He comes out --

IMUS: Hey, Tom, should we have a breaking news thing up on the FOX News Channel, the business channel?

WOLF: That's right. This just in. But the way he did it, he apologize that he made a mistake, but it was issued in a statement. I mean, he didn't even have the, you know, guts to stand up and faced the press. Really weak. And the other thing, you had two exhibition football games last night. And finally we are going to hear about Jeremy Lin, cut out the whining. Remember him? Jeremy Lin.

IMUS: Yes, of course.

MCGUIRK: Today is his birthday.

WOLF: Oh, it is?

IMUS: Yes. He's 25 today.

WOLF: Well, maybe give him some slack.

IMUS: Jay Mohr, of the funnier people on the planet is 43 today. OK.

MCGUIRK: Happy Birthday.

IMUS: And Dagen McDowell is not here again.

MCSHANE: She's out again, yes.

MCGUIRK: Oh, man.

IMUS: So, I said, well, she said she can't put anything on her face. How about a paper bag?

MCSHANE: Yes, she did. You went there. It wasn't funny.

IMUS: And there is something here we don't know. I don't know what it is. But man, there is something here. Hey, what happened to the NASDAQ yesterday?

MCSHANE: Yes. It was a mess with the computers, they don't know 100 percent what happened but they had to halt the number, all the stocks that trade on it and the middle of the day, it went down for hours which is odd, Wall Street has had a number of computer problems the last few years but there is a report this morning, there may have been some connectivity issues with another exchange so they continue their investigation. No panic.

IMUS: NASDAQ stocks.

MCSHANE: Yes, no panic on the market though. You know?

IMUS: You want to get listed on the NASDAQ, you can't get on the big one. Right?

MCGUIRK: No. That's Apple and all these big tech companies if you're over on the NASDAQ, Google, Microsoft.

IMUS: Oh, they are?

MCGUIRK: Yes, so.

IMUS: I have been to see Cavuto yesterday, he looks great. You know, that?

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: Sometimes he needs to take good care of himself as he should. But man, he looks terrific. He is really good. You know who else is pretty good is that Charles Payne guy.

MCSHANE: Charles Payne, yes, absolutely, good guy. Yep.

MCGUIRK: No pain, no gain.

MCSHANE: That's right.

IMUS: What is coming up with you, Bernie?

MCGUIRK: Sydney Leathers.

IMUS: Oh God.

MCGUIRK: Yes. Well, this is true. She made a porn tape.

IMUS: Oh, please.

MCGUIRK: .called Weiner and me but that is not where this stops. She very well may have exposed herself to HIV.

MCSHANE: Oh, wow!

IMUS: Not amusing. That is your hilarious Bernie briefing this morning?

MCGUIRK: I was not presenting that as a joke.

MCSHANE: No punch-line there.

MCGUIRK: That's a story. You remember that kid that gave the rousing speech at Georgia tech?

IMUS: Oh, yes.

MCGUIRK: Well, he may have ripped it off from somebody. And he was interviewed by your friend Neil Cavuto yesterday. We have little piece of that.

IMUS: OK.

MCGUIRK: Cavuto is -- all over him, just the -- it was great. But he may not be for real.

Of course, the big question here is when the Fed could start to wind down, to dial back its $85 billion a month in quantitative easing bond purchases designed to help keep interest rates low on mortgages and other types of loans coming in to the conference. The handicapping is that the Fed could start small at its next policy meeting in September.

The big elephant not in the room this time around at Jackson Hole is Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke. He is skipping the conference for the first time since he became Fed chairman back in 2005. urn:contentItem:5971-1XK1-JD2T-F2K2-00000-00Nasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case Update2013-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:20ZLexisNexisNasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case Update

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the FOX Business Network. Now, here's Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. We are taking a look at the markets this morning after yesterday's flash freeze at the NASDAQ, it's been a fairly flat morning today. We currently got future is in the red, Dow futures are down about 15, we've got the S&P down about one point, the NASDAQ is down about a quarter of a point.

Looking over at oil and gold, those are in the green this morning, we've got oil up about $0.16 cents, gold is up almost $4. Looking at Asia, those markets finished today mixed and for all the details on how they got there, let's go to business reporter Jacqueline Maddock in Beijing. Hi, Jacqueline.

JACQUELINE MADDOCK, BUSINESS REPORTER: Hi, Diane. Yes. It was a bit of a mixed results here for Friday afternoon, here in the mainland and also in Hong Kong. Markets lost ground throughout the afternoon largely because of some pretty disappointing corporate results particularly from Everbright Security if you remember that, the brokerage firm responsible for last Friday's fat-finger fiasco and it was the banks did the biggest falls today, that whispers that the PBO is preparing to unleash the new regulations on China's banking sector, China merchant banks down more than three percent.

But as you say, a different story in Japan, the Nikkei climbed Diane, more than two percent, and every markets that day indeed in the green which is a -- and that was as the yen moved up to the 99 point level accept the Tepco, Diane. Obviously Tepco, the Fukushima nuclear plant operator -- Tepco, fell another five percent at it looks that though as contamination leak has -- some way to play out (INAUDIBLE). Across to Australia though there where markets climbed almost four percent still running high on China's PMI numbers from yesterday, results of stocks love to see signs that China's economy is getting back on track -- Diane.

MACEDO: All right. Jacqueline Maddock from Beijing. Thanks, Jacqueline.

And now, for a look at the European markets, let's go live to London where Jan Lambregts, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank is now joining us. Jan, we saw some positive second quarter GDP reports from the UK and Germany confirmed by the follow-up reading. Any surprise there, and why aren't markets having more reaction to that?

It looks like we just lost Jan. We will try to get him back in a second but let's take a look at the European markets. You can see London up about 16, Parris is down about 12, Frankfurt up about three. Again, those positive GDP report possibly being mitigated by a little un-eased there over the NASDAQ freeze. But let's take a look at some of the important economic news we'll be looking forward to and one of them is a big meeting coming up, some of the most important economic figures in the world are gathering in Jackson Hole, Wyoming for the Kansas City Fed's annual conference but one difference is here, is that the biggest figure of the mall, Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke won't be attending due to a scheduling conflict.

The main focus of the conference will be the impact of the Fed's unconventional policies both at home and abroad and FOX Business's Peter Barnes is there. He will have reports for us throughout the morning.

And we've got Jan Lambregts back again, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank. Jan, I'm not sure if you heard my question the first-time, but we're looking at these GDP reports from the UK and Germany both coming in positive. Any big surprise here?

JAN LAMBREGTS, RABOBANK FINANCIAL MARKETS RESEARCH: Not really. And I don't think the markets really watching it too closely, second revisions, it adds to the general trend that things are a little bit better in Europe but still not great. I think a lot of people in the market can be watching more of these headlines coming out of Jackson Hole and thinking what that would mean for, for tapering than watching these GDP figures.

MACEDO: Markets still seem a little tentative today. You know, good GDP information and yet, they're fairly flat. Paris is even down. Are people tentative this morning over what happened at the NASDAQ yesterday?

LAMBREGTS: I don't think that is not necessarily overshadowing. Like I said, I think the more tentative reacting to positive GDP which is a fairly old number, second quarters after all, more worried that had lines later today as more news comes from Jackson Hole, actually shift perceptions in how likely tapering is and how much tapering is we will see in September.

MACEDO: All right. It's all about stimulus, Jan Lambregts at Rabobank. We appreciate it. Thanks.

LAMBREGTS: You're welcome.

MACEDO: And the Wall Street Journal says, federal prosecutors are turning up the pressure in an insider-trading case against the former portfolio manager at SAC Capital. A new indictment unsealed yesterday alleges that Matthew Martoma spoke to a second doctor involved in an Alzheimer's drug trial at the heart of the case. Martoma is accused of using insider information about results of that drug trial to allow SAC Capital to make $275 million in profits. He is due to go on trial in November and a hearing is set for this morning.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on FOX Business giving you the power to prosper.

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and gentlemen, IMUS IN THE MORNING.

IMUS: So, Doug Chrispin (ph), he's a -- but he's a local rancher and he's doing all kinds of stuff, he won the New Mexico, may it's a national bow and arrow contest that I told you about Mike, from Texas, bans all these -- here. So he says to me, you know, it took awhile for Delbert McClinton to catch on in Austin. All right.

I said, who's -- they found that of course. So he says who is better? Name one person who is better in Austin than Delbert McClinton? He said, there are lots of people. I said what? I didn't have my gun with me, fortunately.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Thank God. Yes.

IMUS: He said Omar and the Howlers.

(LAUGHTER)

BERNARD MCGUIRK, PROGRAM PRODUCER: Oh, those guys.

WARNER WOLF, SPORTSCASTER: Oh, yes.

MCSHANE: Omar and the Howlers?

IMUS: I said, Omar and the Howlers?

WOLF: Sure.

IMUS: So, we were at the horse barn, up at the horse barn. So, I got in the truck and went back to the house and go to iTunes.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: And listened to Omar and the Howlers.

MCSHANE: Uh-huh.

IMUS: And they suck.

MCSHANE: Hey, Omar.

IMUS: I thought he was kidding.

MCSHANE: He said, Omar --

IMUS: And then he is a big Joe Walsh fan. You know? I said, well, have you seen that Eagles? Didn't have any interest. Do you like the Eagles? He said they are all right. So when I first heard the Eagles, sounded like a cross between the Beach Boys and the four perhaps.

MCSHANE: Oh-oh!

IMUS: Well.

MCGUIRK: You got to carry that gun at all times.

MCSHANE: Yes, be ready.

IMUS: The only place I don't carry it is on the ranch for some reason.

LOU RUFINO, PROGRAM ENGINEER: Omar and the Howlers?

IMUS: Omar and the Howlers?

RUFINO: I'm probably the only person who knew that band that you just mentioned.

IMUS: Really?

RUFINO: Yes. I played that band in college.

IMUS: Oh, you did.

RUFINO: -- Back in school and they still together barely alive.

IMUS: Well, they may not, he is going back years, so.

RUFINO: Omar and the Howlers.

GUNZELMAN: This guy is crazy.

IMUS: That is insane, didn't he?

MCGUIRK: Lunacy.

IMUS: Paul Begala is coming up this morning. We no longer need him, so.

MCGUIRK: Yes.

MCSHANE: That's not right.

IMUS: One of my new best friends, one of them, is Bill Powers, the president of U.T., the University of Texas. So, I better not blow of Begala just yet. You know? And Tom Friedman. Hey, Warner?

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Who won those little league world series games?

MCGUIRK: Tijuana beat Panama. So, Tijuana, they will now play Tokyo for the international championship and the Westport Washington State game was rained out. So, they will play today at 3:00.

IMUS: Right.

MCGUIRK: And the winner will play Chula Vista for the title on Sunday.

IMUS: And the winner of that will play either Tijuana or Tokyo.

MCGUIRK: Probably.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Which is it? Tijuana or --

WOLF: Well, Tijuana beat Panama. So, Tijuana will play Tokyo.

IMUS: That is what I just said.

MCSHANE: Right.

WOLF: That's right.

MCSHANE: We got it, yes.

WOLF: Yes. We had some other stories too.

IMUS: What are they?

WOLF: Well, the umpire, they blew a call in the Yankee game which is going to fit right in with next year's videotape replay. They messed up a caught ball and called it a trap and we have got Ryan Braun, what a phony, man. Instead of --

IMUS: Really?

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: You're kidding, Warner.

WOLF: He comes out --

IMUS: Hey, Tom, should we have a breaking news thing up on the FOX News Channel, the business channel?

WOLF: That's right. This just in. But the way he did it, he apologize that he made a mistake, but it was issued in a statement. I mean, he didn't even have the, you know, guts to stand up and faced the press. Really weak. And the other thing, you had two exhibition football games last night. And finally we are going to hear about Jeremy Lin, cut out the whining. Remember him? Jeremy Lin.

IMUS: Yes, of course.

MCGUIRK: Today is his birthday.

WOLF: Oh, it is?

IMUS: Yes. He's 25 today.

WOLF: Well, maybe give him some slack.

IMUS: Jay Mohr, of the funnier people on the planet is 43 today. OK.

MCGUIRK: Happy Birthday.

IMUS: And Dagen McDowell is not here again.

MCSHANE: She's out again, yes.

MCGUIRK: Oh, man.

IMUS: So, I said, well, she said she can't put anything on her face. How about a paper bag?

MCSHANE: Yes, she did. You went there. It wasn't funny.

IMUS: And there is something here we don't know. I don't know what it is. But man, there is something here. Hey, what happened to the NASDAQ yesterday?

MCSHANE: Yes. It was a mess with the computers, they don't know 100 percent what happened but they had to halt the number, all the stocks that trade on it and the middle of the day, it went down for hours which is odd, Wall Street has had a number of computer problems the last few years but there is a report this morning, there may have been some connectivity issues with another exchange so they continue their investigation. No panic.

IMUS: NASDAQ stocks.

MCSHANE: Yes, no panic on the market though. You know?

IMUS: You want to get listed on the NASDAQ, you can't get on the big one. Right?

MCGUIRK: No. That's Apple and all these big tech companies if you're over on the NASDAQ, Google, Microsoft.

IMUS: Oh, they are?

MCGUIRK: Yes, so.

IMUS: I have been to see Cavuto yesterday, he looks great. You know, that?

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: Sometimes he needs to take good care of himself as he should. But man, he looks terrific. He is really good. You know who else is pretty good is that Charles Payne guy.

MCSHANE: Charles Payne, yes, absolutely, good guy. Yep.

MCGUIRK: No pain, no gain.

MCSHANE: That's right.

IMUS: What is coming up with you, Bernie?

MCGUIRK: Sydney Leathers.

IMUS: Oh God.

MCGUIRK: Yes. Well, this is true. She made a porn tape.

IMUS: Oh, please.

MCGUIRK: .called Weiner and me but that is not where this stops. She very well may have exposed herself to HIV.

MCSHANE: Oh, wow!

IMUS: Not amusing. That is your hilarious Bernie briefing this morning?

MCGUIRK: I was not presenting that as a joke.

MCSHANE: No punch-line there.

MCGUIRK: That's a story. You remember that kid that gave the rousing speech at Georgia tech?

IMUS: Oh, yes.

MCGUIRK: Well, he may have ripped it off from somebody. And he was interviewed by your friend Neil Cavuto yesterday. We have little piece of that.

IMUS: OK.

MCGUIRK: Cavuto is -- all over him, just the -- it was great. But he may not be for real.

IMUS: Rob Bartlett and Tony Powell are both here this morning. They're both appearing places. Rob is going to be at the Leavitt Theater in Ogunquit, Maine.

MCGUIRK: Ogunquit.

IMUS: Yes. September 21st. For tickets, go to Robshow.com. And Tony Powell, Powell to the People, he will be appearing at the Belmar Theater on Saturday, September 28th. That is coming up here pretty soon and you can get tickets to that by either calling that theater there. The Belmar Theater, or go to NewYorkentertainmentclub.com. I guess, he gets stuff there. It is 13 after the hour, let's do some news. And here with that is Connell McShane. Good morning, Connell.

MCSHANE: Hey, good morning, I-man. The number of refugees created by the Syrian civil war has not topped one million, a million refugees and a U.N. agency adding to that says 740,000 of them are children under age 11. So, some numbers, it all comes out as we are seeing new pictures of what the rebels claim are another chemical weapons attack.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: And this is the fourteenth time that the central regime uses chemical weapons against innocent civilians and each time we've asked and we've said that the international community does not move this, the regime will enlarge the scale that use these chemical weapons.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: And the U.N. secretary-general did say today, these claims of chemical weapons must be investigated immediately. We also have reports this morning coming in of Israeli airstrikes just south of Beirut said to be a response to four rockets that were fired yesterday into Israel. Back here at home, you mention the problems on Wall Street yesterday, computer problems at the NASDAQ, trading stocks listed there. The Apples and the Google of the world, a lot of big tech names were halted in the middle of the day because of problems with the system that disseminates quotes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: Is it going to affect the way that they look at individual companies and want to invest in companies for 10, 15 or 20 years? No. It will just going to say that this game is not really being played.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Jonathan Kurpido (ph) works at the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Now, to get more on that, this web site All Things D is reporting this morning. NASDAQ thinks the issue may be a problem with connectivity at a rival exchange.

IMUS: What does that mean?

MCSHANE: This another digital exchange, NYSCR by the way, the New York Stock Exchange digital component that there may have been problems with the two exchanges connecting with one another. Apparently, according to this report, and they are basically saying --

IMUS: Each other by the way. But go ahead.

MCSHANE: You are right. May say, more on this later on but I don't know exactly what the --

IMUS: How do we know it wasn't deliberate?

MCGUIRK: Sabotage.

MCSHANE: Well, there all these rumors going around yesterday, and it's where the NASDAQ was not really that transparent about it, didn't talk about it during the day, it's hard to get all of them, there are no comments and then the rumors, what if there was a cyber attack and all this kind of thing. That is what people were worried about.

MCGUIRK: Yes, the Russians.

MCSHANE: But no evidence of that at all and now they're saying that could have been the exchanges, digital exchanges having trouble connecting with each other but --

IMUS: Everybody is lying.

MCSHANE: Probably.

IMUS: Don't you think?

MCSHANE: Well, the thing, you know, I thought there was sort of reassuring about it is, that the markets, not like the market -- or crashed yesterday on this when people, you know, wasn't that many jitters.

IMUS: Yes.

MCSHANE: The Dow was actually up. The NASDAQ ended up. So, you know, got through it. And they've been computer problems in the past. The last big one I guess was like three years ago. Although, the NASDAQ had big time issue about Facebook IPO. You may remember.

MCGUIRK: Yes.

MCSHANE: Yes. That was a mess. But this, we will see. The investigation continues and we will get more on it later today, exactly what happened, so.

IMUS: Oh, yes, great.

MCSHANE: Well, from Washington --

IMUS: Sixteen after the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Connell continues.

MCSHANE: Well, you'll going to start hearing talk about a possible government shutdown again. I know you will be looking forward to that. More than a third of House Republicans urging the Speaker John Boehner to shut down the government rather than fund the president's health-care law. They sent him a letter on that 80 Republicans yesterday.

And then we have this U.S. soldier who killed 16 civilians in Afghanistan last year, he apologized yesterday for the first time for what he called his act of cowardice. The Staff Sergeant Robert Bales is in the middle of a sentencing hearing. Here is Marc Edwards, he's a friend of his who used to play in the NFL, this guy Marc Edwards, he spoke with reporters.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARC EDWARDS, FORMER NFL PLAYER: The person I knew a long time ago has changed quite a bit, the experience that he's had over there. I am not in a position to understand. None of us are.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: None of us are, he says. Well, the sentencing hearing will continue there. And there's no --

IMUS: Why are you repeating what the people are saying?

MCSHANE: I just thought it was a little fuzzy.

IMUS: Sounds like Conan O'Brien.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: This portion of the IMUS IN THE MORNING program sponsored by Hackensack University Medical Center, a place where medicine meets innovation. What were you saying now?

MCSHANE: Well, no verdict for the Fort Hood shooter. That continues deliberations yesterday. And the final thing in the news is Bradley Manning who we talked about a lot in the show yesterday. He says, he felt that he has been a female since childhood and he wants people to refer to him as Chelsea. So, this is the convicted Wiki leaker so to speak. Back in forth, Leavenworth begin serving 35 years in a military prison.

Now, a military spokesman said, if Bradley wants to change his name to Chelsea, a name change would have to be approved in court, then a petition submitted to the army to make it official. So, that's where we are on all that.

IMUS: The Godfather will have some thoughts on Bradley Manning and his wishes coming up here in just a little bit. This moment is also sponsored by the Hackensack University Medical Center, a place where medicine meets innovation, the home of the Deirdre Imus environmental health center. So, well, any business news? Business news incidentally Connell.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: Is presented by this clown over here at the -- well, he is not a clown, that is unfortunate, Don.

MCSHANE: Clown?

IMUS: Dr. Gill Leatherman.

MCSHANE: Oh!

IMUS: Hit the cancer.

MCSHANE: Hit the cancer, baby.

IMUS: Hit the cancer. Shut-up.

MCSHANE: Yes, it's OK.

IMUS: This radio search deal, he has got going.

MCSHANE: Right.

IMUS: You can call Dr. Gill Leatherman at 212-scam -- no, not scam.

MCSHANE: No, no, that's not the word.

IMUS: That's unfortunate.

MCSHANE: No.

IMUS: 212-choices. What is going on in business news other than the tedious NASDAQ deal?

MCSHANE: Well, that's the big I guess story up. I'll give you an update on the markets on where we are. The Dow futures are down a little bit this morning. But the Dow was up yesterday, actually the first time it was up in seven sessions. Got lost a little bit in that NASDAQ story.

IMUS: I'll be darn.

MCSHANE: .of 66 to 14,963. So, not much of an effect in terms of the markets going up and down from that NASDAQ mess, the traders able to shake it off. Commerce Department today releasing some numbers on new home sales on housing numbers, Dow futures are down this morning by 18 points ahead to all that.

IMUS: Is that it?

MCSHANE: Well, I mean, yes, there's --

IMUS: OK. Can't just stop talking. I thought you had a stroke.

MCSHANE: I thought --

IMUS: Well, no. But just stop talking. What's the matter with you?

RUFINO: He stopped.

IMUS: Well, I know he stopped but I mean, back to you, I-man, anything.

MCSHANE: That will be the way --

IMUS: No, no, no.

RUFINO: Connell do it every time.

(TALKING OVER EACH OTHER)

I am Connell McShane.

MCSHANE: Almost 20 minutes past.

IMUS: Omar and the Howlers.

MCGUIRK: Back to you, I-man.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Doug Crispin's big band is the Beatles I guess to him. I guess they are out of AustinTexas, they're coming up here, he told me they were better than Delbert McClinton. I mean, you -- that is insanity, isn't it? Never heard anything like that.

MCSHANE: Never.

RUFINO: I can't believe my ears.

IMUS: There is nobody better than Delbert McClinton. Anyway, Warner with sports is sponsored by Peerless Boilers. Go to Peerlessboilers.com and get one of them. Anyway, it's 20 minutes after the hour, here is Warner Wolf. Good morning, Warner.

WOLF: Good morning, I-man.

IMUS: Yankees beat the Jays five-three, they sweep the series make it ten of 12, they cut the race for the last wild card team, the three-and- a-half, blown call by the umpire in the bottom of the fifth gave the Yankees the lead for good. Bases loaded, one-out, Michael Kay, Yes Network.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL KAY, YES NETWORK: (INAUDIBLE) To the second and it is a double play. He's tagging everybody but it is a double play to end the inning. Did he kick the catch? Now, they're saying that he didn't make the catch.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WOLF: Well, if you watch your FOX Business, you can see that he did indeed make the catch. So instead of a double play to end the inning, Wells is given an RBI and the Yankees take the lead. Well, that is one of the things they will correct next year with video tape replay. Dodgers beat the Marlins six-nothing. Clayton Kershaw on the shut out, he's earned run average is now 1.72. And Brian Wilson pitched for the first time in a year and a half in the ninth inning, he struck out two batters and Wilson has been offered $1 million to shave his beard by 800razors.com.

MCGUIRK: He looks scary like that, man.

WOLF: Pirates and Cardinals win, Pirates by one. Ryan Braun --

IMUS: Maybe could have fought ahead with this and had a photograph of him that we could have put up. I guess not.

MCGUIRK: He makes the duck dynasty guys look like Park Avenue socialites.

MCSHANE: He really does.

WOLF: What we did have him after the game, Brian Wilson with this brief comment.

MCGUIRK: Oh, no.

WOLF: Ryan Braun has issued a statement through the Brewers. They talked about a guy, he say, he said he was sorry he took the PEDs during the --

IMUS: You and Doug are going down.

We're joined now by the CEO of the Nasdaq, Bob Greifeld. Thank you for being here --

ROBERT GREIFELD, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, NASDAQ: I'm glad to have you here, Liz.

Right off the bat, I have to ask you because so many people were questioning this. Was there any indication of any kind of computer hacking or system hacking here?

GREIFELD: No, none whatsoever. So, this had nothing to do with hacking. Hacking is a fact of life but had nothing to do with the problem yesterday.

CLAMAN: That worries some people that it was an internal system because it indicates to some people, you guys don't have your arms wrapped around your system?

GREIFELD: Well, certainly we're deeply disappointed with what happened yesterday and what we had to do is improve what I call defensive driving.

So, our system by itself was working but you have interconnections in the world we live in today and we have to handle bad actions from some of those people connected to us.

And we have to improve on that. So, we're deeply disappointed but I would highlight that one of the reasons it took three hours was, we have a first and foremost responsibility for fair and orderly markets.

So, we spent two and a half hours really making sure the entire industry, we had opened telephone lines with them, we made sure the entire industry was ready to come live and we did come live, we came live quite successfully and finished the day in normal course of business.

CLAMAN: Nobody begrudges you that moment where you have to work and make sure that once you do press go again, it's going to be fine.

What they do get very upset about, Bob, is the lack of communication. I talked to CEOs of Nasdaq-traded companies who said I got nothing.

I'm sitting in meetings, I'm checking my Blackberry, I'm checking my phone, there's nothing from the Nasdaq.

What's wrong with your communication system?

GREIFELD: Well, our communication system I think worked well yesterday. It can always be improved.

First order of businesses to focus on solving the problem and then dealing with people directly involved with the problem.

Now, in one of those open lines we had people representing our issuers on the call and they were -- they are to give regular updates out.

We gave a formal update out after the close of trading which we wanted to do. So, I think we did well, we'll certainly reflect upon how we communicate, see if we can do better.

CLAMAN: Can't you just --

GREIFELD: But certainly --

GREIFELD: Although we had teams --

CLAMAN: Investor relations offices --

GREIFELD: No --

CLAMAN: On the stock --

GREIFELD: We had teams of people doing that. As I'm saying, we had the people responsible for the issuers on the open lines so they could hear first-hand exactly what was going on.

They were taking inbound calls, we took hundreds of inbound calls, reaching, making outbound calls. So, there was active communication going on.

In this type of situation, you probably didn't get to every single CEO or every single IRO, but we communicated quite actively to a large number of them.

Then the official communication went out after the close of trading day to everybody.

CLAMAN: OK --

GREIFELD: Right, so, it happened you know, quite rapidly.

CLAMAN: I get the explanations but we had former Securities and Exchange Commission head, Harvey Pitt on yesterday, he was very harsh.

You were probably busy working the situation, but he said the Nasdaq handled this "terribly". What he didn't like too was when you started the systems up.

He said you only allowed trading in certain stocks, and he said how can you be fair when you're only allowing certain stocks to get up --

GREIFELD: Well, I think it's hard for people outside direct involvement with the problem to comment and comment intelligently on it.

So we have --

CLAMAN: Well, you're taking the smack at Harvey Pitt?

GREIFELD: Well --

CLAMAN: I mean, he's not --

GREIFELD: I'm just saying for anybody who is not there, right? So, they -- you know the people who are not on the open lines, who are not in the head trader alert communication, it's hard for them to know, right?

And hard for them to comment intelligently in terms of what happened. So, everybody was directly involved, the exchanges were on what's called the UTP line.

SIP arranged a line with our members, in addition to that, we had the head trader alert. So, that happened all the way and each plan, right?

And we solved the problem within half an hour, right? And certain members made a request in terms of having a longer period of time to quote --

CLAMAN: OK --

GREIFELD: Instead of five-15 minutes, that cost a half hour of time to get ready for that. So, that communication was there and I think to the extent that anybody who wasn't involved became involved, we said OK, that was as active as you can get.

CLAMAN: You guys are considered the sexier exchange.

GREIFELD: Yes.

CLAMAN: You know, you've got the lots of the dotcoms of the world but there are some that aren't public yet. Twitter, for example, everybody is waiting for that to go public.

GREIFELD: Well, I think it's important to recognize that we aspire towards perfection with respect to the operations of our systems.

And technology people, Twitter and all the companies recognize that. We will always fall short of that but we have to keep trying, right?

And we get better all the time, and the number of problems have actually declined. But probably as importantly, we have to make sure we handle problems in the proper way, right?

So, what we did yesterday, right, nobody wanted to be down for three hours and if we had been quite reckless we could have been up a lot sooner than that.

But I think the procedures we had in place, the industry had in place worked well. So, we would say to any technology-based company, we're not perfect, right?

We're 99.99 percent perfect, we're not perfect, we'll have problems but if we do, we're going to make sure we maintain a fair and orderly market.

And that's what we did yesterday. And it's important to recognize the fact we didn't trade for several hours. If you're a traditional long investor, a mom-and-pop, institutional investor, that three hours doesn't matter.

You're buying the stock for the longer period of time, right? And the fact is, every single person was in the same situation. Nobody was relatively advantaged or disadvantaged because the market was down for that --

GREIFELD: Period of time.

GREIFELD: Right --
