That would be a disappointing reading after existing home sales for last month jumped 6.5 percent to their highest level in four years.

But the mood of the housing market does appear to be improving. Home builders confidence jumped last week to its highest level in eight years despite rising interest rates.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on Fox Business.

WOLF: Meanwhile, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman says the Yanks will win --

IMUS: Hello?

MCSHANE: Hello? --

(LAUGHTER)

WOLF: Well, wait --

IMUS: Hello, Warner.

(LAUGHTER)

WOLF: Hey, Brian. Now major league baseball --

IMUS: Hello --

RUFINO: No Warner, don't say it back --

MCSHANE: Don't respond --

(LAUGHTER)

WOLF: Now, this is Jerry Jones --

(LAUGHTER)

This is Jerry Jones.

RUFINO: Do Cashman again.

IMUS: Warner.

MCGUIRK: I want to take a shower right now.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: This is Jerry Jones.

RUFINO: Man, I've never get on with you, man --

WOLF: Hey, Jerry --

MCSHANE: You guys should do your medical talk in these, in these voices --

(LAUGHTER)

RUFINO: We'll see for steroids --

(IMUS EXTRA SEGMENTS)

IMUS: All right, we're going to talk with Tom Friedman, the "New York Times" coming up here on the "IMUS IN THE MORNING" program. Our last day from the ranch for this summer, so -- and Glenn and everybody out here, Glenn is great and been doing it forever. He and his crew, and Glenn and Ken, Ken's great. Glenn's great and kid over here with the camera and the woman whatever her name is.

In fact, I know these people and only worked with them 15 years, but it's a great crew here at the ranch. They really, they're here on -- they're never late and everything works.

MCSHANE: Very good.

IMUS: And they're real pros. And out of Albuquerque and do a lot of film work and they're real professionals and I greatly appreciate it, like all of them. It's 31 past the hour. Time for a Bernie Briefing and that's sponsored by My Pillow. Here with it is Bernard McGuirk. Good morning, Mr. McGuirk.

MCGUIRK: Good morning, Mr. Imus. Yesterday, as Warner Wolf pointed out, the day before yesterday, Ichiro Suzuki, 4,000 hits combined with his Japanese career and his Major League Baseball career. And this dude, JJ from Staten Island called in, as sportsgreat.com writes and so it began on Mike Francesa's dozy time sleep train as our host lambasted a startled caller on Yankees celebration of Ichiro's 4,000 hits and repeated himself. JJ stayed Suzuki had an accomplishment. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MIKE FRANCESA, SPORTS RADIO TALK SHOW HOST: JJ in Staten Island, what's up.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think it's very, very unbelievable accomplishment, you know?

FRANCESA: No, I don't know. I disagree completely. Disagree completely and I think it's ridiculous. He has 4,000 hits? Why? We now, the Major League and the Japanese leagues are now co-leagues? He has 2,700 major league hits. He doesn't have anything more than that. I think it's utterly ridiculous that we are now going to act like Ichiro got 4,000 hits. He didn't get 4,000 hits, he has 2,700 hits. I give you that, but only 2700 hits as far as we're concerned.

He doesn't have 3,000 hits and how the heck does he have 4,000 hits? I mean, when did that start? When did we start mingling the Japan statistics with the American statistics? He's got 2,700 Major League hits. He doesn't have 4,000 Major League hits. It doesn't make sense to me. When did we decide that? Who decided the Japanese hits are equal to the major league hits. We've got the statistics.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

IMUS: Stop, stop, if I wanted to listen to him, I'd listen. I know he does that, repeats himself ad nauseam. I love Mike, but --

RUFINO: I think it's a great accomplishment.

IMUS: But it's unlistenable.

MCGUIRK: And sportscreed.com, they write, of course, Francesa's argument is fatuous, the only surprise there being that he stayed awake long enough to make it.

IMUS: What are you doing, be like if you're trying to rope, Wyatt.

MCSHANE: Good morning, Wyatt.

MCGUIRK: Wait a second, what's going on there.

IMUS: Are you roping today?

WYATT: Yes.

IMUS: OK, I'm going to fool with you, talk to you when you're backing your horse in the box on the rope.

WYATT: You're not doing anything, you're talking.

MCSHANE: Physical.

WYATT: And having breakfast while you're talking.

IMUS: You're purposely going out of your way to annoy me.

WYATT: I'm bringing you breakfast.

IMUS: If I could, I'd whip your little ass no, no, leave my yogurt away.

MCGUIRK: And have your own kid spitting in your coffee soon.

RUFINO: Soon?

IMUS: He makes me laugh as much as anybody on the planet. God, he's funny. What are you saying?

MCGUIRK: I was saying that I'm done and we're late for Tom Friedman, cutting into Tom Friedman's time. It's an outrage.

IMUS: So, get the whining comy on, 25 until the hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the Fox Business Network, and now, here is Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS: Good morning, everyone. Some of the most important economic figures in the world are gathering in Jackson Hole, Wyoming for the fed annual conference. A big difference this year is that Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke won't be attending due to a scheduling conflict. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi will also miss this meeting. The main focus of the conference, though, will be the impact of the fed's unconventional policies at home and abroad.

Now let's get the latest on weather from meteorologist Maria Molina in our Fox Business Weather Center. Hi, Maria.

MARIA MOLINA, FOX BUSINESS WEATHER CENTER: Hi. Good morning, Diane. Good morning, everyone. Today we're looking at a beautiful day across sections of the northeast. Yesterday, we had storms roll through, leaving behind lower humidity and also pleasant temperatures, like in New York City, 83 degrees for a high temperature and parts of the Midwest and the plains heating in the upper 80's and widespread 90's and feeling like August across the center of the country.

And out west, a danger of fires, and red flags, that leaves the hours and eventually into the west. Much-need rain across parts of Nevada, Utah and across parts of Southern California, several inches could fall out here so flooding could be a concern. Diane, back to you.

MACEDO: All right, that's Maria Molina from the weather center. Let's take a quick look at futures. Those have been searching for direction today. Dow futures are now up by 2 points. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now.

IMUS: It's 20 minutes until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Please welcome now from the New York sometimes, Tom Friedman. Good morning, Mr. Friedman.

TOM FRIEDMAN, "THE NEW YORK TIMES" (via telephone): Good morning, Don.

IMUS: Wonder how long the "New York Times" is going to stay in business?

FRIEDMAN: Gosh, you know, I really think, you know, we've got a strong enough global brand, I don't worry about the times per se, but what I worry, if you look at the numbers, our -- the newspaper ads, you know, have been, I don't know how long it is, six, nine, 12 quarters, you know, they continue to decline and you know, you just hope that we'll find a bottom.

We're still making a profit, thank God, but if that doesn't find a bottom, you know, at some point, you know, it will affect obviously what we can do, but you hope it will find a bottom. I don't know if you realize, I think last quarter, the quarter before, we made more money selling the paper than we did from advertising and like that's a huge line to cross.

IMUS: Well, and are you working on another book?

FRIEDMAN: I'm thinking about something, Don. You know, sort of pushing ahead from the last book I did that used to be about just kind of the new phase of globalization where it's going, technology, how it's all merging, how it's affecting business, education, et cetera. It's germinating in my head, but I'm not quite there yet, but thinking about something on the Middle East, too.

IMUS: You're not kidding. That sounds hideous. You've got to come up with a better idea than that. Geez, are you kidding me? Nobody's going to read that.

FRIEDMAN: You want to write a book called "The World Is Flat" nobody's going to read that.

IMUS: Well, no.

FRIEDMAN: I'm thinking about something.

IMUS: That was a great book, though, the olive tree and that stuff, but this latest one. Have you just given up? Said the hell with it?

FRIEDMAN: No.

IMUS: Anyway, let me ask you a couple of serious questions. Syria, what the hell is going on there?

FRIEDMAN: Well, we don't have the conclusive proof, but you look at those pictures of those bodies, don, how they died, unmarked by any kind of wounds, you know, it's pretty clear the regime used some kind of chemical weapon and obviously Obama said that would be a red line. They already crossed it once. What he will do this time once it's conclusively proved, I don't know.

There's a big discussion at the White House yesterday, as you reported, that three hours where they debated what to do. One of the problems, the problem is this so let's say we launched a cruise missile attack in response to this to deter chemical weapons.

What targets to hit. Do you cause more refugee outflow from Syria and destabilize Jordan, for instance? So there's a lot of real-- so many moving parts with this, it's going to be a difficult one to sort out, but, you know, I'm glad they're considering something because once you start introducing those kind of weapons, you know, it's Katie bar the door.

IMUS: What would you recommend that we do?

FRIEDMAN: You know, I would be in favor of -- as I sit here right now, I'd be in favor of some kind of military response at that simply says we're not going to tolerate that. The world is not going to tolerate that.

IMUS: Would you want troops on the ground?

FRIEDMAN: No, no, I'm talking about some kind of aerial response. It's sort of something I'd be ready to consider. I want to see all the facts, they haven't all come out, some kind of response not just by us, but by the world, the allies, NATO that draws a red line there. I think it's something that it's really worth considering.

IMUS: Talking with Tom Friedman from the "New York Times" who probably has an e-mail address at the times in which you can contact him and here is what I'd like you to do, send him some ideas for a book. He hasn't got any. And every day I say to Connell, well, why should I care about Egypt? So, let me ask you, why should I?

FRIEDMAN: You know, there are a lot of reasons, Don. It's a country of 85 million people. It sits astride the Suez Canal. It's the partner with Israel in the Camp David peace treaty and has been traditionally the bedrock of the geopolitics there and the leader of the Arab world, as Egypt goes, so goes the Arab world.

You want the country to have a decent outcome of this revolutionary process. The problem in Egypt right now, Don, you've had two choices historically, that is either the army or the Muslim Brotherhood. In Egypt if you look at its history oscillated between those two for the last 60-odd years.

And the question, really, is can they-- can they find a third way, a way that's actually forward-looking, inclusive, progressive that doesn't just involve one of these narrow-minded options or the other? You know, one of the things that's been rattling around in my head, Don. Princess Di once said with Prince Charles there are three people in this marriage.

IMUS: Yes.

FRIEDMAN: Historically we've looked at Egypt and saying there's two people in the marriage, the Muslim Brotherhood and the army. If that's the choice we'll go with the army, with Mubarak, but we talked about this in earlier conversation, I think there are three people in this story now, there's the military, the Muslim Brotherhood and Mother Nature.

And by that, I mean there is all of these incredible water, environmental population stresses that have built up over the last 60 years, precisely because of the incompetence of the military government and the Muslim Brotherhood in managing the problems and stresses, if they don't get the act together, find a third way that can sort of tilt Egypt forward to deal with some of these problems, Don, half the women in Egypt can't read.

After $30 billion in U.S. aid, over the last 30-odd years, half the women still can't read and these other social stresses I think are just going to blow the place apart.

IMUS: What in your view would be a decent outcome in Egypt?

FRIEDMAN: I think a decent outcome would be a government that would -- where the military says to this government that they've appointed and they actually-- when they ousted the Muslim Brotherhood government they appointed a new president and he appointed a new cabinet. And you know some of these people and they're pretty decent people, if they would assign that government the task of writing a new constitution, one that would guarantee minority rights, that would be -- that would guarantee women's rights, that would be basically progressive leaning and take out some of the bad stuff the Muslim Brotherhood had in the constitution, and begin to organize an elective process gradually.

Giving time for not just the Muslim Brotherhood or Islamists as it were, but the liberal and progressive parties to get organize and contest that election, to put Egypt on that gradual transition path, not to just stop with the military government.

IMUS: Why did you decide to employ the Princess Di analogy?

FRIEDMAN: I have no idea. It popped into my head there. There are three different parties in this story now.

IMUS: You're a weird dude, sometimes, so -- but you do sometimes in your columns it works well.

FRIEDMAN: Yes.

IMUS: Have you gotten away this summer at all?

FRIEDMAN: A little bit. Just kind of on and off. I just turned 60, Don. So I'm going out to California next week.

IMUS: When was your birthday?

FRIEDMAN: July 20th.

IMUS: Well, happy birthday.

FRIEDMAN: Thank you very much.

IMUS: You look pretty good for 60. I guess 60 is -- 60 is getting up there.

FRIEDMAN: I'm trying to take care of myself. In this day and age, there are a few miles on these treads so I'm trying to take care of myself, and looking forward to getting away.

IMUS: In spite of what you think, the times is not long for this world so get a good idea for a book. Tom Friedman.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACEDO: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. It's time to check the markets now, the day after the Nasdaq flash free that halted trading for three hours. The U.S. futures are fairly flat this morning, but now point to go a higher open. Dow futures are up 3. The S&P is up about 1. The Nasdaq is up 3.5.

Over in Europe, we got the second quarter reading on second quarter GDP in the U.K. and Germany, both rose 7/10 of a percent. London is now up about 37. Paris is down barely and Frankfurt is up 16.

The "Wall Street Journal" says that federal prosecutors are turning up the pressure in an insider trading case against a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital. The new indictment unsealed yesterday alleges that Matthew Martoma spoke to a second doctor involved in an Alzheimer's drug trial at the heart of the case.

Martoma is accused of using insider information about results of that drug trial, which then allowed SAC Capital to make $275 million in profits. He's due to go on trial in November. A hearing is set for this morning, SAC Capital has been charged with encouraging insider trader, but Steven Cohen, the hedge fund's founder has not been charged. Cohen and his firm deny any wrongdoing.

Here's a look at commodities now. We're watching oil and gold for you this morning. Those have been also fairly flat. Oil is now down up 13 cents. Gold is up 20. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now.

IMUS: He looks like he is he doesn't have any energy, doesn't he? Here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, coming up on the radio, a fascinating, funny conversation with the great Terry Bradshaw.

MCSHANE: All right.

IMUS: And before that, it's 9:20 Eastern Time on the Fox Business Network. The lying limey, Stuart Varney, so --

MCSHANE: We love Varney.

IMUS: I do like Varney a lot. So I don't know.

MCSHANE: What's wrong?

IMUS: Well, and the Godfather is going to be on to talk about -- I forget what he's going to talk about. What, Godfather.

MCSHANE: Good question.

IMUS: Down, Godfather.

BARTLETT: The gentleman --

IMUS: Can barely hear the Godfather, so the Godfather decided well, mail it in this morning. Did he have his mic off, Connell?

MCSHANE: I think his headphones were down and he couldn't hear.

BARTLETT: Turn it up.

MCSHANE: Now he's better. And solving yet another problem and working through a lot this morning.

IMUS: Got to project, Rob.

BARTLETT: Yes, sir.

MCSHANE: He couldn't hear.

IMUS: Also, you did a -- a lousy job on the last script. Why was that?

BARTLETT: I'm a little under the weather today. It affected my performance, I apologize.

IMUS: What's the matter with you?

BARTLETT: Got a little bit of a -- a touch of a bug, I think.

IMUS: Well, why didn't you tell me that instead of turning in a performance that sucks? Because we don't have to do it, you know?

BARTLETT: Just, I'm going to suck it up, I didn't --

IMUS: No, you didn't suck it up because you gave in like a finocchio.

MCSHANE: Finocchio.

IMUS: To your little sniffles.

BARTLETT: I have 135 fever.

IMUS: OK.

MCSHANE: That's right.

IMUS: You gave in to your 135 degree fever and provided all of us with a weenie performance.

MCSHANE: Struggling, Rob, the last couple.

IMUS: It would be better if you said to me, Don, I don't feel great and I would say, fine. So every time you want off, I mean, you ever -- a problem getting off when you need it? Of course not, neither one of you.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5JB0-C081-JBHT-D54C-00000-00Nasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case Update2013-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisNasdaq Glitch Examined; Bernanke Not Attending Jackson Hole Conference; Markets Mostly Flat; SAC Capital Case UpdateLanhamFULL TEXT

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the FOX Business Network. Now, here's Diane Macedo.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. We are taking a look at the markets this morning after yesterday's flash freeze at the NASDAQ, it's been a fairly flat morning today. We currently got future is in the red, Dow futures are down about 15, we've got the S&P down about one point, the NASDAQ is down about a quarter of a point.

Looking over at oil and gold, those are in the green this morning, we've got oil up about $0.16 cents, gold is up almost $4. Looking at Asia, those markets finished today mixed and for all the details on how they got there, let's go to business reporter Jacqueline Maddock in Beijing. Hi, Jacqueline.

JACQUELINE MADDOCK, BUSINESS REPORTER: Hi, Diane. Yes. It was a bit of a mixed results here for Friday afternoon, here in the mainland and also in Hong Kong. Markets lost ground throughout the afternoon largely because of some pretty disappointing corporate results particularly from Everbright Security if you remember that, the brokerage firm responsible for last Friday's fat-finger fiasco and it was the banks did the biggest falls today, that whispers that the PBO is preparing to unleash the new regulations on China's banking sector, China merchant banks down more than three percent.

But as you say, a different story in Japan, the Nikkei climbed Diane, more than two percent, and every markets that day indeed in the green which is a -- and that was as the yen moved up to the 99 point level accept the Tepco, Diane. Obviously Tepco, the Fukushima nuclear plant operator -- Tepco, fell another five percent at it looks that though as contamination leak has -- some way to play out (INAUDIBLE). Across to Australia though there where markets climbed almost four percent still running high on China's PMI numbers from yesterday, results of stocks love to see signs that China's economy is getting back on track -- Diane.

MACEDO: All right. Jacqueline Maddock from Beijing. Thanks, Jacqueline.

And now, for a look at the European markets, let's go live to London where Jan Lambregts, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank is now joining us. Jan, we saw some positive second quarter GDP reports from the UK and Germany confirmed by the follow-up reading. Any surprise there, and why aren't markets having more reaction to that?

It looks like we just lost Jan. We will try to get him back in a second but let's take a look at the European markets. You can see London up about 16, Parris is down about 12, Frankfurt up about three. Again, those positive GDP report possibly being mitigated by a little un-eased there over the NASDAQ freeze. But let's take a look at some of the important economic news we'll be looking forward to and one of them is a big meeting coming up, some of the most important economic figures in the world are gathering in Jackson Hole, Wyoming for the Kansas City Fed's annual conference but one difference is here, is that the biggest figure of the mall, Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke won't be attending due to a scheduling conflict.

The main focus of the conference will be the impact of the Fed's unconventional policies both at home and abroad and FOX Business's Peter Barnes is there. He will have reports for us throughout the morning.

And we've got Jan Lambregts back again, global head of financial markets research at Rabobank. Jan, I'm not sure if you heard my question the first-time, but we're looking at these GDP reports from the UK and Germany both coming in positive. Any big surprise here?

JAN LAMBREGTS, RABOBANK FINANCIAL MARKETS RESEARCH: Not really. And I don't think the markets really watching it too closely, second revisions, it adds to the general trend that things are a little bit better in Europe but still not great. I think a lot of people in the market can be watching more of these headlines coming out of Jackson Hole and thinking what that would mean for, for tapering than watching these GDP figures.

MACEDO: Markets still seem a little tentative today. You know, good GDP information and yet, they're fairly flat. Paris is even down. Are people tentative this morning over what happened at the NASDAQ yesterday?

LAMBREGTS: I don't think that is not necessarily overshadowing. Like I said, I think the more tentative reacting to positive GDP which is a fairly old number, second quarters after all, more worried that had lines later today as more news comes from Jackson Hole, actually shift perceptions in how likely tapering is and how much tapering is we will see in September.

MACEDO: All right. It's all about stimulus, Jan Lambregts at Rabobank. We appreciate it. Thanks.

LAMBREGTS: You're welcome.

MACEDO: And the Wall Street Journal says, federal prosecutors are turning up the pressure in an insider-trading case against the former portfolio manager at SAC Capital. A new indictment unsealed yesterday alleges that Matthew Martoma spoke to a second doctor involved in an Alzheimer's drug trial at the heart of the case. Martoma is accused of using insider information about results of that drug trial to allow SAC Capital to make $275 million in profits. He is due to go on trial in November and a hearing is set for this morning.

IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on FOX Business giving you the power to prosper.

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and gentlemen, IMUS IN THE MORNING.

IMUS: So, Doug Chrispin (ph), he's a -- but he's a local rancher and he's doing all kinds of stuff, he won the New Mexico, may it's a national bow and arrow contest that I told you about Mike, from Texas, bans all these -- here. So he says to me, you know, it took awhile for Delbert McClinton to catch on in Austin. All right.

I said, who's -- they found that of course. So he says who is better? Name one person who is better in Austin than Delbert McClinton? He said, there are lots of people. I said what? I didn't have my gun with me, fortunately.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Thank God. Yes.

IMUS: He said Omar and the Howlers.

(LAUGHTER)

BERNARD MCGUIRK, PROGRAM PRODUCER: Oh, those guys.

WARNER WOLF, SPORTSCASTER: Oh, yes.

MCSHANE: Omar and the Howlers?

IMUS: I said, Omar and the Howlers?

WOLF: Sure.

IMUS: So, we were at the horse barn, up at the horse barn. So, I got in the truck and went back to the house and go to iTunes.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: And listened to Omar and the Howlers.

MCSHANE: Uh-huh.

IMUS: And they suck.

MCSHANE: Hey, Omar.

But I think the procedures we had in place, the industry had in place worked well. So, we would say to any technology-based company, we're not perfect, right?

And that's what we did yesterday. And it's important to recognize the fact we didn't trade for several hours. If you're a traditional long investor, a mom-and-pop, institutional investor, that three hours doesn't matter.

And you know some of these people and they're pretty decent people, if they would assign that government the task of writing a new constitution, one that would guarantee minority rights, that would be -- that would guarantee women's rights, that would be basically progressive leaning and take out some of the bad stuff the Muslim Brotherhood had in the constitution, and begin to organize an elective process gradually.

Giving time for not just the Muslim Brotherhood or Islamists as it were, but the liberal and progressive parties to get organize and contest that election, to put Egypt on that gradual transition path, not to just stop with the military government.

IMUS: Why did you decide to employ the Princess Di analogy?

FRIEDMAN: I have no idea. It popped into my head there. There are three different parties in this story now.

IMUS: You're a weird dude, sometimes, so -- but you do sometimes in your columns it works well.

FRIEDMAN: Yes.

IMUS: Have you gotten away this summer at all?

FRIEDMAN: A little bit. Just kind of on and off. I just turned 60, Don. So I'm going out to California next week.

IMUS: When was your birthday?

FRIEDMAN: July 20th.

IMUS: Well, happy birthday.

FRIEDMAN: Thank you very much.

IMUS: You look pretty good for 60. I guess 60 is -- 60 is getting up there.

FRIEDMAN: I'm trying to take care of myself. In this day and age, there are a few miles on these treads so I'm trying to take care of myself, and looking forward to getting away.

IMUS: In spite of what you think, the times is not long for this world so get a good idea for a book. Tom Friedman.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACEDO: Good morning, everyone. I'm Diane Macedo. It's time to check the markets now, the day after the Nasdaq flash free that halted trading for three hours. The U.S. futures are fairly flat this morning, but now point to go a higher open. Dow futures are up 3. The S&P is up about 1. The Nasdaq is up 3.5.

Over in Europe, we got the second quarter reading on second quarter GDP in the U.K. and Germany, both rose 7/10 of a percent. London is now up about 37. Paris is down barely and Frankfurt is up 16.

The "Wall Street Journal" says that federal prosecutors are turning up the pressure in an insider trading case against a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital. The new indictment unsealed yesterday alleges that Matthew Martoma spoke to a second doctor involved in an Alzheimer's drug trial at the heart of the case.

Martoma is accused of using insider information about results of that drug trial, which then allowed SAC Capital to make $275 million in profits. He's due to go on trial in November. A hearing is set for this morning, SAC Capital has been charged with encouraging insider trader, but Steven Cohen, the hedge fund's founder has not been charged. Cohen and his firm deny any wrongdoing.

Here's a look at commodities now. We're watching oil and gold for you this morning. Those have been also fairly flat. Oil is now down up 13 cents. Gold is up 20. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now.

IMUS: He looks like he is he doesn't have any energy, doesn't he? Here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, coming up on the radio, a fascinating, funny conversation with the great Terry Bradshaw.

MCSHANE: All right.

IMUS: And before that, it's 9:20 Eastern Time on the Fox Business Network. The lying limey, Stuart Varney, so --

MCSHANE: We love Varney.

IMUS: I do like Varney a lot. So I don't know.

MCSHANE: What's wrong?

IMUS: Well, and the Godfather is going to be on to talk about -- I forget what he's going to talk about. What, Godfather.

MCSHANE: Good question.

IMUS: Down, Godfather.

BARTLETT: The gentleman --

IMUS: Can barely hear the Godfather, so the Godfather decided well, mail it in this morning. Did he have his mic off, Connell?

MCSHANE: I think his headphones were down and he couldn't hear.

BARTLETT: Turn it up.

MCSHANE: Now he's better. And solving yet another problem and working through a lot this morning.

IMUS: Got to project, Rob.

BARTLETT: Yes, sir.

MCSHANE: He couldn't hear.

IMUS: Also, you did a -- a lousy job on the last script. Why was that?

BARTLETT: I'm a little under the weather today. It affected my performance, I apologize.

IMUS: What's the matter with you?

BARTLETT: Got a little bit of a -- a touch of a bug, I think.

IMUS: Well, why didn't you tell me that instead of turning in a performance that sucks? Because we don't have to do it, you know?

BARTLETT: Just, I'm going to suck it up, I didn't --

IMUS: No, you didn't suck it up because you gave in like a finocchio.

MCSHANE: Finocchio.

IMUS: To your little sniffles.

BARTLETT: I have 135 fever.

IMUS: OK.

MCSHANE: That's right.

IMUS: You gave in to your 135 degree fever and provided all of us with a weenie performance.

MCSHANE: Struggling, Rob, the last couple.

IMUS: It would be better if you said to me, Don, I don't feel great and I would say, fine. So every time you want off, I mean, you ever -- a problem getting off when you need it? Of course not, neither one of you.

END

urn:contentItem:3Y2B-RS60-00MP-T413-00000-00Nasdaq Hangs Tough as Market's Rocket Ride Pauses1999-12-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisMARKETS; Midday MusingsNasdaq Hangs Tough as Market's Rocket Ride PausesBy Thomas Lepri, Staff ReporterDecember 7, 1999 1:09 PM ET

A truly exceptional market like this one rarely surprises. Astonishing advances become the norm, while pullbacks are always "to be expected," enablers of the next move higher. Wall Street was getting a taste of the latter at midday, but that's not stopping observers from marveling at the big tech machine. 

** Major IndicesINDEXCHANGE%VALUEDow-85.02-0.76%11,139.99S&P 500-8.69-0.61%1414.65Nasdaq1.500.04%3547.51Russell 2000-2.02-0.43%463.73TSC Internet-4.13-0.39%1040.51BONDCHANGEPRICEYIELD30-Year Treasury12/3298 27/326.210% ** Market data as of: 1:00 PM EST, Tue Dec 7 1999

 

At midday, the major benchmarks were mixed to lower. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 85 to 11,140 and the S&P 500 was off 9 to 1415, while the Nasdaq Composite Index was up a point and a half to just under 3548. 

Net stocks and small-caps were in the red. The Russell 2000 was down 2 to 464, while TheStreet.com Internet Sector was 4 lower to 1041. 

"Based on all the normal measures -- and even the extreme measures -- of valuation and momentum and all these things, it's just off the charts in every way," said Robert Dickey, managing director of technical analysis at Dain Rauscher Wessels in Minneapolis. "So we should be looking for a return to average soon." 

The traditional contrarian measures have been foretelling a pullback for some time now. One place technicians often look for signs of market tops is the options market. In particular, the Chicago Board Options Exchange Market Volatility Index effectively tracks the level of fear in the market. In general, throughout 1999, the closer the VIX has gotten to 20, the better a selling point it's proven. But except for a brief stretch two weeks ago, the VIX has been tucked smugly in the low 20s since early November. 

Today's selling was making investors a bit more nervous, with the VIX lately sitting at up 0.97 to 22.03. But that's still far from fearful, and it would be very shortsighted to mistake today's action for a "return to average." The losses on Wall Street toward midday are hardly denting the huge gains the market's seen recently, especially in the technology sector. Before today, the Nasdaq had gained 29.8% since mid-October. And the broader S&P 500 had risen 14.1%, and the Dow 12% 

"Measures are averages of extremes," Dickey said. "Right now, we're at the extreme of extremes, and it's just bigger than what we've all seen in the past. I remember smaller, isolated incidents in the past, but not as broad as this. It's narrowly based, but narrowly based in a lot of stocks." 

Dickey's talking about tech, of course: "If you look at something that doesn't have any tech in it, it stinks. The utilities, transports and many, many other groups and sectors just aren't participating. It's tech alone." 

Today, tech was taking a bit of a breather, especially chip stocks. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange Semiconductor Index was down 2.7%, while the Morgan Stanley High-Tech 35 had fallen a more modest 0.3%. But that contraction wasn't too much rotation into nontech sectors. 

U.S. Bancorp's (USB:NYSE) earnings warning yesterday is making the banking sector an unpopular place to be long, with the Philadelphia Stock Exchange/KBW Bank Index off 1.5% in an extension of its pullback from its mid-November highs. 

Transports were looking better, especially the airlines. The American Stock Exchange Airline Index was up 1.8%, while the Dow Jones Transportation Average was 0.2% higher. But drug stocks were continuing their recent downtrend, with the American Stock Exchange Pharmaceutical Index 1.9% lower. 

"Tech is the one area where the fundamentals seem intact," said Peter Boockvar, equity strategist at Miller Tabak. "So it continues to be the place to hide." And even with the mixed performance in the broader tech sector today, investors were piling into stocks like Cisco (CSCO:Nasdaq) and Yahoo! (YHOO:Nasdaq). Yahoo! will be joining the S&P 500 after today's close. Cisco was lately up 2.9%, while Yahoo! had picked up a further 6.9% to crack 300 for the first time. 

Ultimately, in heady times like these, retail investors might do better to just mind their own business. Timing market tops is a delicate and difficult task. "You get a watched-clock syndrome," Dickey said. "And it doesn't matter anyway, because people don't buy 'the market.' The whole point is that people should be careful, and notice if their individual stocks start to turn. And individually, they're all over the place. That's what you've got to focus on." 

The bond market was moving higher after a Fed coupon pass and a benign speech by Fed boss Alan Greenspan. The 30-year Treasury was up 12/32 to 98 27/32, putting the yield at 6.21%. (For more on the fixed-income market, see today's early Bond Focus.)
 
Market Internals 

Breadth was solidly negative on strong volume. 

New York Stock Exchange: 1,003 advancers, 1,936 decliners, 570 million shares. 72 new 52-week highs, 240 new lows. 

Nasdaq Stock Market: 1,682 advancers, 2,193 decliners, 893 million shares. 207 new highs, 92 new lows.
 
Tuesday's Midday Watchlist 

By Tara Murphy
Staff Reporter(Earnings estimates from First Call/Thomson Financial; earnings reported on a diluted basis unless otherwise specified.)
 
Mergers, acquisitions and joint ventures 

BP Amoco (BPA:NYSE ADR) lost 12 to 59 1/2 and Exxon Mobil (XOM:NYSE) inched up 11/16 to 84 9/16 after the companies said they will dissolve their European fuel and lubricants joint venture and divide up the assets in line with their equity stakes. Mobil had to sell its 30% interest in the fuel business as a condition of European regulatory approval of its merger with Exxon. BP Amoco will pay about $1.5 billion for Mobil's stake, which includes its pipeline at London's Gatwick Airport. Goldman Sachs raised Exxon Mobil to its recommended list from market outperformer. For more on BP Amoco's buy, check out a separate story from the TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom. 

The European Commission said it granted regulatory approval to the full buyout of Dutch company Eurotronics by Avnet (AVT:NYSE). Shares of lost 1 1/16 to 57 1/8. 

Hexcel (HXL:NYSE) rose 1 1/16 to 5 5/8 after saying it has retained Credit Suisse First Boston to explore alternatives for its Engineered Products business, including a possible sale. 

News Corp. (NWS:NYSE ADR) slipped 3/16 to 38 5/8 and Healtheon (HLTH:Nasdaq) rose 5/16 to 45 13/16 after the companies said they formed a $1 billion partnership in which News Corp. will take a 10.8% stake in the online health network to move into the health programming arena. The financial terms include $700 million in branding services provided by News Corp. over 10 years and a $100 million purchase of Healtheon/WebMD stock at $50 a share. The alliance also includes a $100 million cash investment by News Corp. in an international joint venture and a $62.5 million five-year licensing agreement for syndication of WebMD daily broadcast content. Banc of America Securities upped its rating on Healtheon to buy from market performer. For more on News Corp.'s new friend, check out a separate story from the TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom. 

Provident American (PAMC:Nasdaq) rose 3 9/16, or 11.1%, to 35 5/8 after it said its Healthaxis.com unit will merge with a unit of UICI (UCI:NYSE). Shares of UICI slipped 15/16 to 23 11/16. Provident said each company's shareholders will own 50% of the new Healthaxis.com, which will receive a $57 million equity investment. 

Tricon Global Restaurants (YUM:NYSE) climbed 1/16 to 40 1/8 after saying it will combine its Canadian restaurant operations with Scott's Restaurants, with the combined group operating most Pizza Hut, KFC and Taco Bell outlets in Canada for a total of about 639 stores. 

Vodafone AirTouch (VOD:NYSE ADR) lost 1/16 to 52 15/16 after it said it has chosen Ericsson (ERICY:Nasdaq ADR) to supply its infrastructure for its next-generation network technology in Britain, the Netherlands and Greece. Ericsson fell 1 5/8 to 57 5/8 despite the news. The General Packet Radio Service technology will let mobile customers access services such as train timetables, directions and online shopping. 

Separately, U.S. regulators approved the planned combination of the U.S. wireless operations of Bell Atlantic (BEL:NYSE) and Vodafone, as long as the companies eliminate some overlapping properties, Bell Atlantic said. Shares of Bell Atlantic gained 5/16 to 64 11/16.
 
Earnings/revenue reports and previews 

H.J. Heinz (HNZ:NYSE) rose 5/16 to 43 7/16 after it reported second-quarter earnings of 65 cents a share, a penny better than the 17-analyst estimate and up from 60 cents a year ago. Heinz said it was comfortable with third-quarter estimates of 62 cents and fourth-quarter estimates of 63 cents. The current 15-analyst estimate calls for 63 cents a share in each of those quarters. Heinz also said it was on track to deliver a year-end target of 6% to 7% earnings-per-share growth. 

The European Commission said it cleared plans by Heinz's European unit to buy U.K.-based United Biscuits' frozen and chilled foods unit. The cost of the purchase, made in October, was $317 million. For more on Heinz, check out a separate story from the TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom. 

Interstate Bakeries (IBC:NYSE) fell 7/8 to 17 1/16 after it reported second-quarter earnings of 40 cents a share, missing the nine-analyst estimate of 49 cents and the year-ago 44 cents a share. The company said the latest second-quarter decline in earnings was due to business disruptions from Hurricane Floyd, ongoing operational start-up problems in the northeast bakery consolidation project and higher selling and delivery costs.
 
Offerings and stock actions 

Celestica (CLS:NYSE) popped 5 5/8, or 7.4%, to 81 5/8 after it said it will split its shares 2-for-1. 

CompanyOffering PriceCurrent Price% ChangeAirNet Communications$1441+193.3%E-Cruiter.com$68 1/4+35.4%Harris Interactive$14N/AN/AHealthCentral.com$1111--


Analyst actions 

Goldman Sachs started BroadVision (BVSN:Nasdaq) as a market outperformer. Shares of BroadVision were slipping 4 to 101 1/2. 

DeutscheBanc Alex. Brown started coverage of Casella Waste (CWST:Nasdaq) as a strong buy. Deutsche resumed coverage of Republic Services (RSG:NYSE) as a strong buy, and Waste Management (WMI:NYSE) as a market performer. Shares of Casella Waste were adding 5/16 to 19, while Republic Services was losing to 12 7/16. Waster Management shares were sliding 3/16 to 15 1/4. 

Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette cut Coca-Cola (KO:NYSE) to a market perform from a buy. Shares of Coca-Cola were sinking 5, or 8.6%, to 59. 

Merrill Lynch started shares of Corning (GLW:NYSE) with an intermediate-term accumulate, long-term buy rating. Merrill said it sees shares of Corning doubling within the next three years. Corning shares were hopping 2 15/16 to 107 15/16. 

Goldman Sachs upped its rating on CNF Transportation(CNF:NYSE) to a market outperformer from market performer. CNF Transportation was climbing 11/16 to 30 15/16. 

PaineWebber raised its price target on Cygnus(CYGN:Nasdaq) to 20 from 10 and upped its rating to buy from a neutral. Shares of Cygnus were bouncing 6, or 73%, to 15 7/8. 

CIBC World Markets analyst Jim Berlino upgraded Dell (DELL:Nasdaq) to buy from hold and set a price target of 55. Shares of Dell were edging up 1/8 to 45. 

J.P. Morgan started coverage with buy ratings on Exodus (EXDS:Nasdaq), Akamai (AKAM:Nasdaq) and Covad (COVD:Nasdaq). 

Shares of Exodus were jumping 7 5/16, or 5.6%, to 131 5/16 and Akamai was leaping 8 3/8 to 224. Covad shares were advancing 2 15/16, or 5.4%, to 56 15/16. 

SoundView Technology rolled out coverage of Finistar(FNSR:Nasdaq) with a buy rating. J.P. Morgan also stamped the stock as a buy. Shares of Finistar were plunging 8 3/16, or 7.5%, to 100 1/2. 

DeutscheBanc Alex. Brown started coverage of Flextronics (FLEX:Nasdaq) with a buy rating and set a price target of 45. Shares of Flextronics were losing 3/4 to 88 7/8. 

Lehman Brothers cut its rating on Guidant (GDT:NYSE) to neutral from outperform. Shares of Guidant were skidding 3/4 to 47. 

SoundView Technology raised its price target on IBM (IBM:NYSE) to 140 from 110 and maintained its buy rating. IBM shares were slipping 1/16 to 116. 

Robertson Stephens initiated coverage of Lucent (LU:NYSE) with a buy rating. Shares of Lucent were up .92% to 80 15/16. 

Robertson Stephens initiated coverage of Net2Phone(NTOP:Nasdaq) with a buy rating. Shares of Net2Phone was climbing 1 3/16 to 54 1/16. 

Bear Stearns initiated coverage of Starwood Financial (SFI:NYSE) with a buy rating. Shares of Starwood Financial were gaining 1/16 to 17 3/4. 

Banc of America Securities raised its rating on Symantec (SYMC:Nasdaq) to strong buy from buy rating and upped its price target to 72 from 60. Shares of Symantec were bouncing 3 3/8, or 6.45, to 55 3/8. 

Goldman cut Texaco (TX:NYSE) to market performer from market outperformer. Shares of Texaco were skidding 1 to 57 15/16. 

Lehman started coverage on Veritas Software (VRTS:Nasdaq) as a buy and set a 12-month price target of 140. Shares of Veritas Software were sinking 2 1/16 to 102 1/16. 

Schroeder said its boosted its price target on Yahoo! (YHOO:Nasdaq) to 350 from 225. Yahoo! was soaring 19 1/4, or 6.9%, to 300.
 
Miscellany 

El Al Airlines signed a $400 million deal with Boeing (BA:NYSE) for three 777 planes. Shares of Boeing were sliding 5/16 to 38 5/16. 

Cendant (CD:NYSE) was climbing 1 5/16, or 7.6%, to 18 9/16 after it said it agreed to pay $2.83 billion to settle a shareholder class action lawsuit over accounting irregularities. Cendant said the settlement would result in a noncash, after-tax charge of $1.8 billion in the fourth quarter and would reduce 2000 earnings-per-share by 12 cents to 16 cents. TheStreet.com took an in-depth look back at the Cendant debacle in an April series. 

Hasbro (HAS:NYSE) was declining 1 5/16, or 6.1%, to 20 1/16 after it said it would cut 2,200 jobs, or 19% of its workforce, and consolidate manufacturing, product lines and sourcing activities in a sweeping restructuring. Hasbro said it will close manufacturing plants in Tijuana, Mexico, and Ashford, England. The company said it expects to post a fourth-quarter charge of $141 million from the consolidation, and also set a new $500 million share-buyback plan. See additional reporting from TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom for more on the tinkering at Hasbro. 

IMC Global (IGL:NYSE) was edging up 5/16 to 16 1/4 after it said it would record special charges of $825 million in the fourth quarter as part of a restructuring that will include cutting 850 jobs. The program will provide estimated annual pretax savings of about $70 million affecting 2000, according to the company. 

Shares of VISX (VISX:Nasdaq) were plummeting 38, or 43.3%, to 49 7/8 after the International Trade Commission made an initial finding in favor of a rival in a patent infringement case. For more on VISX vexation, check out a separate story from the TheStreet.com/NYTimes.com joint newsroom. 

A front-page story in The Wall Street Journal examines an unusual breed of day traders, who continuously trade a single stock, irrespective of the company's revenue, profits, news developments or strategies. For instance, the story cites one trader, who, in a single day, traded more than 130,000 shares of CMGI (CMGI:Nasdaq). The trader accounted, by himself, for nearly 2% of the company's total daily volume. The aim for such traders is to determine when big, institutional players are buying or selling stock in volume, and jump in ahead of them. Shares of CMGI were adding 7 to 174. 

The Heard on the Street column in the Journal takes a look at a spat between FTD.com (EFTD:Nasdaq) parent IOS Brands and Bankers Trust, a unit of Deutsche Bank. In a suit which will be heard in New York federal court, FTD has accused Bankers Trust of improperly forcing its way into FTD's newly public Internet subsidiary, FTD.com, by demanding and receiving, warrants in the parent during negotiations over a previous FTD financing. Shares of FTD.com were slipping 1/4 to 6.

urn:contentItem:5MTV-WVS1-DY9P-N058-00000-00Nasdaq hits historic high;NEW YORK REPORT2017-02-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 18Nasdaq hits historic highNEW YORK REPORT

THE S&P 500 ended barely higher yesterday while the Nasdaq managed to scratch out a new record as gains in big tech names countered energy declines.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average also hit an intraday all-time high just after the market opened, and the benchmark S&P 500 came close to yet another record high.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 37.87 points, or 0.19 per cent, to 20,090.29, the S&P 500 gained 0.52 points, or 0.02 per cent, to 2,293.08 and the Nasdaq Composite added 10.67 points, or 0.19 per cent, to 5,674.22.

US equities have rallied sharply after President Donald Trump's election, spurred by hopes his government will cut regulations and taxes.

Energy was the worst-performing S&P sector, falling 1.4 per cent. Chevron's 1.4 per cent fall and Exxon's 0.6 per cent drop were among the biggest drags on the S&P. Tech stocks helped prop up the S&P though. Apple rose about one per cent and Alphabet gained 0.9 per cent.

urn:contentItem:60T3-26N1-JCMN-Y2BR-00000-00Nasdaq in Correction: One Solid Reason to Buy the Dip in ETFs2020-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisNasdaq in Correction: One Solid Reason to Buy the Dip in ETFsSanghamitra Saha

Sep 09, 2020( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The rout in technology shares that started on Sep 3 worsened to start this week's trading as investors continued dumping this winning segment of the coronavirus crisis. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite underperformed once again compared with its other key U.S. peers after suffering its worst week since March[1]. Along with big tech names, chip stocks were crushed too as tensions between the United States and China flared up.SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY) lost 2.7%, SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average ETF Trust (DIA) retreated 2.3%, small-cap iShares Russell 2000 ETF (IWM) lost about 1.9% while the Nasdaq-100 fund Invesco QQQ Trust (QQQ) was off about 4.8% on Sep 8. Nasdaq is 10.03% below its closing record of 12,056.44 from Sep 2. The Nasdaq has now entered into the correction territory (see all technology ETFs[2] here).Apart from the overvaluation concerns, reports that U.S. sanctions could spread to businesses[3] like Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp., China's largest chip fabricator, hurt the semis space on Sep 8. Over the weekend, talks were doing rounds that SMIC could join the U.S. 'entity list' like telecom equipment maker Huawei back in May.Stock-wise, Tesla lost 21.1% on Sep 8, in a sign to record its worst-day[4] ever.

The sharp crash came on the heels of the electric car maker's failure to make it to the S&P Dow Jones Indices. Shares of Apple recorded its worst three-day stretch since October 2008, according to Bespoke Investment Group, as quoted on CNBC. Is This a Chance to Dip the Toe in Tech Stocks? While President Donald Trump and some others see a vaccine as early as this year[5], nine biopharma CEOs are seeking a joint safety and efficacy pledge. On Sep 8, the CEOs of AstraZeneca, BioNTech, GlaxoSmithKline, Johnson & Johnson, Merck, Moderna, Novavax, Pfizer and Sanofi pledged to not seek approvals or emergency use authorizations for their vaccine candidates without conclusive positive data, per a source[6].The drugmakers will "onlysubmit for approval or emergency use authorization after demonstrating safety and efficacy through a phase 3 clinical study that is designed and conducted to meet requirements of expert regulatory authorities such as FDA," they said, per the abovesaid source. AstraZeneca plc said it has stopped a late-stage trial[7] of one of the leading COVID-19 vaccine candidates after an unexplained illness in a volunteer.This means further uncertainty in the health emergency and the related economic recovery. This also ensures a prolonged period of social distancing norms and continued surge of digitization. No doubt, the Nasdaq had been a high-flying index this year, but the latest correction will help investors to dip their toe in the index and its tech components.Against this backdrop, below we highlight a few ETFs that could be bought right now. Nasdaq & Tech ETFs Nasdaq ETFs likeInvesco QQQQQQ[8], First Trust NASDAQ-100 Equal Weighted Index Fund QQEW[9] and Fidelity Nasdaq Composite Index Tracking StockONEQ[10] can be bought on the correction.As long as tech ETFs are concerned, investors can buy low P/E or undervalued tech ETFs like Invesco S&P 500 Equal Weight Technology ETF (RYT[11]) (P/E 19.92X),iShares Cybersecurity and Tech ETF (IHAK[12]) (P/E 20.19X), First Trust NASDAQ Technology Dividend Index Fund TDIV[13] (P/E 20.56X) and First Trust ISE Cloud Computing Index Fund SKYY[14] (P/E 21.98X). These funds have the lowest P/Es in the tech space. Want key ETF info delivered straight to your inbox? Zacks' free Fund Newsletter will brief you on top news and analysis, as well as top-performing ETFs, each week.Get it free > >[15]Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? urn:contentItem:5NT4-Y6N1-F03R-N28P-00000-00Nasdaq (NDAQ) Getting Somewhat Favorable Press Coverage, AlphaOne Reports2017-06-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisNasdaq (NDAQ) Getting Somewhat Favorable Press Coverage, AlphaOne ReportsJohn Perry

Jun 15, 2017( Zolmax.com: http://www.zolmax.com/ Delivered by Newstex) News coverage about Nasdaq (NASDAQ:NDAQ) has been trending somewhat positive this week, according to AlphaOne Sentiment. AlphaOne, a unit of Accern, identifies negative and positive media coverage by analyzing more than 20 million news and blog sources. AlphaOne ranks coverage of public companies on a scale of negative one to positive one, with scores nearest to one being the most favorable. Nasdaq earned a daily sentiment score of 0.12 on AlphaOne's scale.

AlphaOne also gave news articles about the financial services provider an impact score of 90 out of 100, indicating that recent media coverage is very likely to have an effect on the company's share price in the immediate future. Here are some of the news articles that may have impacted AlphaOne Sentiment Analysis's analysis: Nasdaq Struggles as Big Tech Selling Continues[1] (investorplace.com) Nasdaq, Inc. (NDAQ) Rating Increased to Hold at BidaskClub[2] (americanbankingnews.com) Nasdaq : Appoints Mattias Hammarqvist as New CEO of Nasdaq Broker Services AB[3] (4-traders.com) Nasdaq Welcomes Athenex, Inc. (Nasdaq: ATNX) to The Nasdaq Stock Market[4] (finance.yahoo.com) The Emma Bowen Foundation to Ring The Nasdaq Stock Market Closing Bell[5] (finance.yahoo.com)NDAQ has been the topic of several recent analyst reports. Deutsche Bank AG restated a 'buy' rating and set a $77.00 price objective (down from $79.00) on shares of Nasdaq in a research note on Monday, May 15th. Royal Bank Of Canada lifted their target price on Nasdaq from $70.00 to $74.00 and gave the stock a 'sector perform' rating in a research note on Thursday, April 27th. Zacks Investment Research[6] cut Nasdaq from a 'hold' rating to a 'sell' rating in a research note on Tuesday, April 4th. BidaskClub upgraded Nasdaq from a 'sell' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research note on Thursday. Finally, Evercore ISI reiterated an 'in-line' rating and set a $74.00 target price on shares of Nasdaq in a research note on Friday, April 28th. Seven investment analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating and three have given a buy rating to the company. The stock currently has a consensus rating of 'Hold' and a consensus price target of $73.11. Shares of Nasdaq (NDAQ[7]) traded down 0.14% during midday trading on Thursday, reaching $70.95. The company had a trading volume of 1,296,324 shares. The company has a 50 day moving average of $68.23 and a 200 day moving average of $68.76. The firm has a market capitalization of $11.72 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 82.69 and a beta of 0.76. Nasdaq has a 12-month low of $61.19 and a 12-month high of $72.52. Nasdaq (NASDAQ:NDAQ) last released its quarterly earnings data on Wednesday, April 26th. The financial services provider reported $1.10 EPS for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate of $1.05 by $0.05. Nasdaq had a return on equity of 11.77% and a net margin of 3.87%. The company had revenue of $583 million for the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $593.46 million. During the same period last year, the firm posted $0.91 earnings per share. Nasdaq's revenue was up 9.2% compared to the same quarter last year. Analysts anticipate that Nasdaq will post $4.12 EPS for the current year. The firm also recently disclosed a quarterly dividend, which will be paid on Friday, June 30th. Investors of record on Friday, June 16th will be given a dividend of $0.38 per share. The ex-dividend date of this dividend is Wednesday, June 14th. This is a boost from Nasdaq's previous quarterly dividend of $0.32. This represents a $1.52 annualized dividend and a dividend yield of 2.14%. Nasdaq's dividend payout ratio (DPR) is 154.22%. In other Nasdaq news, Director Lars Wedenborn sold 10,000 shares of the stock in a transaction dated Thursday, April 27th. The stock was sold at an average price of $68.38, for a total value of $683,800.00. The transaction was disclosed in a filing with the SEC, which is accessible through this link[8]. Company insiders own 1.60% of the company's stock. About Nasdaq Nasdaq, Inc (Nasdaq) is a holding company. The Company is a provider of trading, clearing, exchange technology, regulatory, securities listing, information and public company services. urn:contentItem:6082-BVG1-JCMN-Y2M3-00000-00Nasdaq Outperforms Major Indices in 1H20: ETFs to Gain2020-06-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisNasdaq Outperforms Major Indices in 1H20: ETFs to GainSweta Jaiswal, FRM

Jun 30, 2020( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The first half of 2020 has been majorly dominated by the coronavirus pandemic. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite index, however, showed some resilience to the virus attack and has managed to gain around 10% so far. However, other major stock market indices like Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 index have lost around 10.3% and 6.6%, respectively, in the same period.Even since Mar 23, when the coronavirus worries had peaked, ravaging the stock market, the Nasdaq has recouped losses and gained more than 43% against Dow Jones Industrial Average index's recovery of around 37% and the broader S&P 500 index's 36% rise. Going by Dow Jones Market Data, for the second time since its foundation in 1971, Nasdaq has been able to outperform peers in the middle of the year (per a MarketWatch article[1]). The same phenomenon was last observed in 1977.It is being widely believed that the major technology companies' resilience to the coronavirus crisis must have supported the tech-heavy index.

Major technology stocks like FacebookFB[2], MicrosoftMSFT[3], AppleAAPL[4], NetflixNFLX[5] and AlphabetGOOGL[6] are all positive in 2020 so far. Moreover, Amazon AMZN[7] has supported the Nasdaq by gaining more than 45% in the year.In this regard, Ed Yardeni,president and chief investment strategist at Yardeni Research, had once said that 'while we have all become even more dependent on the products and services provided by the FAANGMs during the Great Virus Crisis, they might have become more immune to government regulation. They have great balance sheets and generate lots of cash flow,' according toa CNBC article[8].Looking ForwardThe second half of 2020 is expected to keep facing the brunt of the coronavirus pandemic as the second wave of the outbreak is gathering steam. In the current scenario, the rising work-from-home and online shopping trend, increasing digital payments, growing video streaming and soaring video game sales are slowly becoming the 'new normal.' With the new trends making way, these major technology stocks are expected to continue to gain on rising demand for their products and services.Going on, even as the U.S. economy is reopening in phases and social-distancing restrictions are being eased, people are trying to minimize human-to-human contact. It's largely because the pandemic has resulted in some changes in the lifestyle and preferences of Americans. Most of the surveys have found that people are more interested in online shopping rather than visiting a brick-and-mortar store for their purchases of essential food items and supplies now. However, considering the surging number of coronavirus cases, some states have started to pause the reopening process in the United States. Notably, Texas Governor Greg Abbott has announced holding back of reopening plans.ETFs to GainInvestors seeking to ride the Nasdaq bulls could consider the following ETFs. These funds might see massive trading volumes in the days ahead if the afore-mentioned trends stay.Invesco QQQQQQ[9] — up 14.2% year-to-dateThis ETF provides exposure to 104 largest domestic and international non-financial companies listed on the Nasdaq by tracking the Nasdaq-100 Index. QQQ is one of the largest and most popular ETFs in the large-cap space, with AUM of $111.52 billion and average daily volume of around 52.3 million shares. It charges investors 20 bps in annual fees. The fund sports a Zacks ETF Rank #1 (Strong Buy), with a Medium-risk outlook (read:Top-Ranked ETFs That Crushed the Market in 1H[10]).Fidelity Nasdaq Composite Index Tracking StockONEQ[11] — up 9.6%This ETF tracks the Nasdaq Composite Index, holding a broad basket of 992 stocks. It has AUM of $2.64 billion. The expense ratio comes is 0.21%. The product carries a Zacks ETF Rank #2 (Buy), with a Medium-risk outlook (read: Make the Most of the Big Tech Rally With These ETFs[12]).First Trust NASDAQ-100 Equal Weighted Index FundQQEW[13] — up6.2%Holding 105 stocks, this fund replicates as closely as possible, before fees and expenses, the price and yield of the NASDAQ-100 Equal Weighted Index. It has amassed $822.8 million in its asset base, while it trades in lower volumes of nearly 115,000 shares a day on average. QQEW carries a Zacks ETF Rank #3 (Hold), with a Medium-risk outlook (read: Nasdaq is Burning Hot: How to Make the Most of it With ETFs[14]).ProShares Ultra QQQQLD[15] — up 16.7%Investors seeking to make big gains in a short span can bet on QLD. It provides twice the return of the NASDAQ-100 Index's daily performance. The fund has AUM of $2.46 billion and charges 95 bps in fees and expenses.ProShares UltraPro QQQTQQQ[16] — up 6.7%For a more bullish approach, TQQQ could be an excellent choice. It also tracks the NASDAQ-100 Index but offers thrice the returns of the daily performance, with the same expense ratio of QLD. The fund has managed AUM of $5.80 billion (read:Best Leveraged/Inverse ETFs of June[17]).Want key ETF info delivered straight to your inbox?Zacks' free Fund Newsletter will brief you on top news and analysis, as well as top-performing ETFs, each week.Get it free > >[18]Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? urn:contentItem:56NB-YGC1-F03R-N2DK-00000-00Nasdaq Partners with Amazon and 3 Morning Hot Stocks Trading Today2012-09-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisNasdaq Partners with Amazon and 3 Morning Hot Stocks Trading Today

Apple's (NASDAQ:AAPL) new iPhone 5 has a sleek look in no small measure due to the use of in-cell screen technology which combines the display and the touch sensor into one component. But the company paid a cost in terms of supply disruptions that led to demand for the phone outstripping supply on its launch debut. In-cell screens are tougher to produce, resulting in Sharp Corp., one of the suppliers, falling behind on delivery schedules and quality concerns.


Don't Miss: Another Troll Attacks These Big Tech Companies.
In an effort to create a cheaper route to regulatory compliance, Nasdaq (NASDAQ:NDAQ) launched a platform of the cloud created by Amazon Web Services (NASDAQ:AMZN) and dubbedFinQloud that allows the exchanges trading clients to store financial and regulatory data securely. According to NASDAQ, the data can now be stored and retrieved inexpensively and with ease.
According to a regulatory filing with the SEC by Oracle (NASDAQ:ORCL), Larry Ellison, who holds a 23.5% stake in the company, increased the number of shares of the company pledged as collateral from 40 million shares in 2011 to 139 million shares in 2012. The stock was pledged as "collateral to secure certain personal indebtedness, including various lines of credit."
A joint statement by UK-based liquor giant Diageo (NYSE:DEO) and Indian spirits group United Spirits Ltd confirms the two companies are in talks regarding the sale of a stake in the latter. No information was offered on the size of the stake, and there is no certainty that the discussions could lead to a conclusive deal. A transaction could lead to Diageo plcenhancing its presence in a major emerging market, and help the Indian group sort out the financial difficulties at its Kingfisher airline.
Catalysts are critical to discovering winning stocks. Check out our newest CHEAT SHEET stock picks now.

urn:contentItem:5J2F-7RB1-JCMN-Y4TS-00000-00Nasdaq Perilously Close to Bear Market: 5 Growth Stocks on Sale2016-02-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisNasdaq Perilously Close to Bear Market: 5 Growth Stocks on SaleZacks Equity Research

Feb 10, 2016( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Volatility continues to plague the broader markets, with the Nasdaq flirting with a bear market on Tuesday. The Nasdaq tanked almost 18% from its all-time intraday high set in July, to settle at 4,268.76. It needs to fall to 4,185.55 to be in the bear zone, which will indicate a persistent drop of 20% or more from previous highs. Plunge in high flying tech stocks along with sell-off in biotech stocks continued to drag the tech-laden index into negative territory.A series of headwinds including the relentless slump in oil prices, slide in bank stocks, global growth worries and uncertainty about the timing of a Fed rate hike also weighed on investors' sentiment. They found solace in taking money out of equity markets and parking them in safe-haven assets like treasuries and gold.However, these fears that have resulted in selling and down-sizing stocks listed on the Nasdaq should work well for bargain-hunting investors.

They can now buy high-quality stocks at a discounted price. Investors should keep an eye on stocks that are positioned to grow in the near term, despite the initial hiccup. Analysts are also expected to be bullish on such stocks, with earnings estimates being revised on the upside.Tech Stocks Crash The Nasdaq is now dangerously close to the bear market level mostly due to the decline in FANG stocks. These stocks that helped the index to end in the green last year, failed to repeat their feat. Instead, shares of Facebook, Inc. FB[1], Amazon.com, Inc.AMZN[2], Netflix, Inc.NFLX[3] and Alphabet Inc. GOOGL[4] dropped 4.9%, 28.7%, 24.7% and 9.9%, respectively, on a year-to-date basis.Their sky-high valuations were also a reason for putting off investors. In fact, carnage in these momentum names was led by LinkedIn Corp. LNKD[5]. Shares of this Internet stock were down 8.8% on Tuesday, a day after the company missed on earnings and issued a downwardly revised guidance.Amazon and Netflixare already in bear territory, while the other big tech bellwethers including Apple Inc.AAPL[6], Tesla Motors, Inc. TSLA[7] and Cisco Systems, Inc.CSCO[8] are succumbing to a bear market. Moreover, behind Nasdaq's atrocious performance this year was GoPro, Inc. GPRO[9]. Shares of this company engaged in producing wearable HD camcorders have plummeted 36.8% year to date. Overall, the Technology Select Sector SPDR (XLK) is down 9.5% on a year-to-date basis.Biotech's Sell-offSell-offs among biotech stocks is also taking a toll on the Nasdaq. Some biotech stocks such as Gilead Sciences Inc. GILD[10] and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Inc. REGN[11] nosedived 13.8% and 32.6%, respectively, year to date. The broader iShares NASDAQ Biotechnology Index (IBB) has decreased 26.6%.Analysts are continuing to speculate about the reasons behind this biotech crash. Fundamental issues such as drug price regulation, lackluster earnings results and a few merger deals may be having an adverse effect on biotech companies. Some also fear that presidential candidates might be presenting ways to curtail drug price increases while others believe that demand for medications in China might get hampered due to its slow economic growth.Macroeconomic HeadwindsChina plunged into a bear market territory last month, while it had surprised investors last year by devaluing its currency, which eventually led to a rout of $5 trillion in the nation's equity markets. Moreover, on Tuesday, the yield on 10-year government bonds in Japan slipped into negative territory for the first time ever. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 declined 5.4% yesterday.Global economic growth seems to be highly uncertain against the backdrop of falling oil prices. Global oil prices continue to move south as investors remain concerned about the persistent supply glut. The oil industry's woes escalate as storage levels turn into 'critical levels.' Moreover, the International Energy Agency (IEA) warned on Tuesday that the global supply glut will grow further this year. Meanwhile, Iran had ramped up production levels after its ban got lifted.Additionally, bank stocks declined due to uncertainty over the rate hike and widening credit spreads. Investors worry that a Fed rate hike now will perpetuate more turbulence, slowing down the domestic economy further.5 Growth Stocks to Cash In on Downward TrendA plethora of risks including slowdown in the global economy, rate hike hysteria and broad-based sell-off in tech and biotech stocks has not only kept the Nasdaq firmly in correction territory but is also threatening to drag the index into a bear market.However, whether the Nasdaq will continue to plunge further depends on the pace of domestic economic growth. If the U.S. economy sinks into recession, then the tech-heavy index might fall deeper into the negative zone.But Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen said that the probability of a recession this year is a meager 10%. Moreover, when it comes to tech and biotech stocks, they mostly have solid fundamentals and a strong profit trajectory. Since the long-term trends bode well for stocks listed on the Nasdaq, it would be wise to invest in such stocks that are poised to grow in the near term but are currently trading at a cheaper price. By purchasing stocks following a dip, investors are essentially buying shares at a discounted price.With the help of our new style score system[12], we have short listed Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) stocks with a Growth Style Score of 'A' that hold immense growth potential despite declining in recent weeks. Our research shows that stocks with a Growth Style Score of 'A' when combined with a Zacks Rank #1 offer the best investment opportunities in the growth investing space.LogMeIn, Inc.LOGM[13] provides cloud-based services for individuals and businesses. LOGM is poised to grow despite declining 23.6% in the past four weeks. LOGM has a long-term expected EPS growth rate of 8%.Extreme Networks Inc. EXTR[14] provides wired and wireless network infrastructure equipment, software and services for enterprises, data centers and service providers. EXTR is poised to grow despite declining 27.2% in the past four weeks. EXTR has a long-term expected EPS growth rate of 100%.INC Research Holdings, Inc. INCR[15] is a contract research organization that provides various clinical development services for the biopharmaceutical and medical device industries. INCR is poised to grow despite declining 18.6% in the past four weeks. INCR has a long-term expected EPS growth rate of 18.1%.Netgear Inc.NTGR[16] provides networking products to consumers, businesses and service providers. NTGR is poised to grow despite declining 3.3% in the past four weeks. NTGR has a long-term expected EPS growth rate of 10.6%.LeMaitre Vascular, Inc. LMAT[17] develops, manufactures and markets medical devices and implants for the treatment of peripheral vascular disease worldwide. LMAT is poised to grow despite declining 13.1% in the past four weeks. LMAT has a long-term expected EPS growth rate of 16.6%.Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research?
