Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:3YVF-MS50-009B-G00F-00000-00Nasdaq Plunges Nearly 200 Points; MicroStrategy Collapses, Losing $13 Billion; What Is Genomics and Should You Be Investing in It?2000-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30News; DomesticSHOW00032000V19Nasdaq Plunges Nearly 200 Points; MicroStrategy Collapses, Losing $13 Billion; What Is Genomics and Should You Be Investing in It?Willow Bay, Stuart Varney, Rhonda Schaffler, Susan Lisovicz, Bob Beard, Jim Moret, Susan Lisovicz, Bruce Francis, Greg Clarkin, Peter Viles, Steve Young

The Nasdaq today posted its third-worst point drop ever today, as weakness from new economy leaders like biotech and Internet stocks pushed the composite down more than 180 points to 4610. Meanwhile, the Dow rose 85 points to end at 10,680. It's a rare session when a stock plummets 140 points in a single day, but that's what happened to MicroStrategy, losing nearly two-thirds of its value after the company announced it had to restate '98 and '99 revenues to conform to SEC requirements. That means a loss instead of a profit in '99, and investors sold off big time. The debate about the promise of genomics is growing louder. Just what is it? And why are investors rushing to cash in on this new frontier in science?

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight on MONEYLINE: the Nasdaq, swamped by a sea of red. The index plunges nearly 200 points, re- testing recent lows.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: The biggest Nasdaq disaster: MicroStrategy. In just 6 1/2 hours, the stock collapses, losing more than half its value: $13 billion wiped out.

BAY: Real pain also in the biotech sector. Investor confusion drives the sector down sharply. We begin our special series on a new frontier in medical science: genomics. What is it and how does it work?

ANNOUNCER: This is the MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR. Reporting tonight from New York, Stuart Varney and Willow Bay.

BAY: Good evening. Tech turbulence.

VARNEY: Good word. The composite index posting its third-worst point drop ever today. Weakness from new economy leaders like biotech and Internet stocks pushed the Nasdaq down more than 180 points. That's a loss of very close to 4 percent. And that comes on top of last week's 5 percent sell-off as the index trims this year's tremendous gains nearly in half.

The composite index now up just 13 percent year to date. That's sharply below its March high, when the index closed above 5,000 and was up more than 24 percent on the year.

But that's just half the story for tech stocks. Over on the big board today, tech companies were among the biggest leaders: the winners, that is.

Rhonda Schaffler has more from the New York Stock Exchange.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Wall Street's story of divergence took another twist today. Now there's even a split within the technology sector.

In the midst of a Nasdaq route, which saw dozens of biotech and Internet stocks take double- and even triple-digit dive, investors bought brand-name techs, helping the Dow industrials extend last week's 6 3/4 percent gain.

The Dow rose 85 points to end at 10,680. AT&T, IBM, Hewlett- Packard, Intel and Nasdaq big-cap Dell all reached significant gains.

LARRY RICE, JOSEPHTHAL & COMPANY: It's rotation. It's almost typical end-of-the-quarter window dressing. You know, people forget that we're at the end of the first quarter, and we're seeing a lot of the stronger stocks in Nasdaq, the quality stocks, if that's -- if that's possible, are being bought here, where a lot of the more speculative stocks in Nasdaq are being sold.

SCHAFFLER: The Nasdaq closed sharply lower, down 188 points. One major reason for the selling: a mind-boggling 140-point loss in shares of MicroStrategy after the business software maker said it would have to restate operating results for the past two years, turning previously announced profits into losses.

Biotech stocks such as Amgen, Biogen, Genome Therapies and Human Genome Sciences also suffered sever losses.

JOSEPH BATTIPAGLIA, GRUNTAL & COMPANY: Investors are demanding from the real economy performance in terms of earnings and executing of business strategy. And whenever there is a challenge to what your thinking is, these stocks pull back.

So we had a big challenge about Internet companies and cash flow. The stocks pulled back. Last week, we had concerns about who really owns the human genome. The stocks pull back.

SCHAFFLER: Some traders also blame today's pull-back and lighter than normal volume on interest rate jitters.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

(on camera): Federal Reserve policy makers meet tomorrow, and a quarter point rate hike is widely expected.

What Wall Street has to wrestle with now is whether earnings will be strong enough to weather a rise in rates -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Rhonda Schaffler, reporting from the big board.

BAY: Taking a closer look at the market action. It wasn't just the Nasdaq that fell deep in the red today. The Dow transports, the Dow utilities and the AMEX all moved lower. The S&P 500 also in negative territory, down more than seven points to 1,456.

The sour mood carried over to the big board where decliners led advancers by a slight margin: 50 stocks hit new 52-week highs today; 37 fell to new lows.

The biggest loser of all on a percentage basis: the Russell 2000. The index of small-cap stocks fell more than 4 percent to close at 549. The trigger for today's Russell 2000 sell-off, the same one behind the Nasdaq slide: a meltdown in shares of MicroStrategy.

Susan Lisovicz has more from the Nasdaq marketsite -- Susan.

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Hello, Willow.

Even on the Nasdaq, it's a rare session when a stock plummets 140 points in a single day. But that's exactly what happened to MicroStrategy, losing nearly two-thirds of its value in a single day. Before the bell, the company announced that it had to restate '98 and '99 revenues to conform to SEC requirements. That means a loss instead of a profit in '99. Investors sold off big time.

But that's only one reason why the Nasdaq took such a big dive today. Some analysts say the momentum is continuing from last week, a week in which the Nasdaq shed 5 percent while the Dow came back with a vengeance. And that momentum hit its best-performing sector hardest: biotechs losing nearly 11 percent today. And here's a good example.

Abgenix plunging 36 percent, 112-point decline today alone. An article in "Barron's" questioned the long-term survival of some well- known Internet companies. "Barron's" said they were burning cash: VerticalNet plunging today, down 17 percent, 37 points today alone. "Barron's" say it will face a major cash crunch if it doesn't raise additional capital by May. Merrill Lynch disagrees with the assessment, saying it's on a clear path to profitability.

Bucking the trend today, Intel, which introduced its new Pentium III processor designed to power the delivery of audio, video, 3-D over the Internet. It was up 5 1/8, but that was one of the aberrations today.

Decliners swamped advancers by about a 2-to-1 margin in a session that started out with positive breadth by the same margin -- Willow.

BAY: Susan Lisovicz at the Nasdaq marketsite, thank you.

VARNEY: Well, those Nasdaq losses have simply created another buying opportunity, so says our next guest. Joining us now is Thomas Galvin. He's the chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

Tom, welcome back to MONEYLINE.

THOMAS GALVIN, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, DONALDSON, LUFKIN & JENRETTE: Thanks.

VARNEY: Let's get this clear, shall we. You are the chief investment officer of a major brokerage house and you are telling people go out there and buy tech stocks, correct?

GALVIN: I think that's right. It's difficult to find the growth any place else in any other industry that you can find within technology right now, and people want to pay up for growth.

I think as far as the sell-off that we've seen, you have to keep in mind what time of the month and quarter it is. I mean, we've got about one week left of trading. You had the index, if you had annualized the recent gains, it would have almost been a double for the market this year. So We covered a lot of ground in too short a period. I think people want to take profits and savor the quarter gains while they can.

BAY: Tom, is it more than that? I mean, are we seeing signs now that all is not well with techs? For example, what we're calling the disaster du jour, MicroStrategy: Is that the tip of the iceberg? Do other companies, new high-flyers, use those kinds of accounting methods?

GALVIN: Well, I think there's going to be continuing a lot of scrutiny. We've seen a lot of transformation within the Nasdaq. I mean, Dell and Microsoft are hot stocks two years ago. They've gone cool. The electronic broker stocks were hot. Now, I think people are moving and filtering out and looking for the right business models and credibility, and they're going to get rid of the ones, obviously, that they have question marks on. There's enough out there right now that they can stick with hopefully the good quality ones.

VARNEY: Negative No. 2: the burn rate at some of these newer, especially Internet companies. They're burning through the money they've got available. "Barron's" says a lot of them will be out of money relatively quickly, and we're talking a couple of hundred companies.

Surely, that's another negative for the tech sector?

GALVIN: Well, I would tell you this: I do think the "Barron's" article certainly played into some of the uncertainly in the marketplace and the worries. Keep in mind that a lot of the burn rate is a result of capital spending going up to build out their infrastructures. But of course, the capacity utilization of those build-outs right now are very low.

So if they really had to cut their capital spending, they still could grow into some of the infrastructure they're building.

I'm not disregarding that fact. I do think overall ultimately probably a third of the Internet stocks will perish. Probably a third will get consolidated and sell out, and I think a third will dominate their space.

I think right now on the NYSE year to date, a lot of the old economy stocks are also being filtered out in a similar proportion right now. Some will not actively, I think, invest in technology, probably fall behind and die. Some will consolidate, as we've seen in the paper industry, and I think the rest will dominate their space in the old economy.

BAY: There's more. Still, you're putting your money in techs with all these negatives floating around right now?

GALVIN: I don't think it's that negative. I, frankly, just came from a technology meeting. Right now, components are in short supply. Demand from the software companies and the equipment companies is strong. On the big board today, some of the hardware stocks were strong risers: Intel was up $4 today.

So again I think there's a sorting-out of technology, but certainly I think again you've got to filter out. I think you're still getting strong growth, and I think people will pay up for that throughout this year.

VARNEY: We hear you, and Willow and I are not particularly skeptical.

(LAUGHTER)

But Thomas Galvin, thank you very much for being with us.

GALVIN: Thank you very much.

VARNEY: Good luck. Our thanks.

BAY: Coming up on MONEYLINE, when you spend in cyberspace, should anyone collect a sales tax?

VARNEY: Plus Taiwan challenges Beijing with a vote for change. We'll look at the implications for business and for trade too.

BAY: And the new face of 3Com. We will outline the makeover investors can't wait to see.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: There is word tonight that one of America's most famous businessman may also be somewhat cash-strapped. According to the latest issue of "Fortune" magazine, sources say Donald Trump is trying to mortgage his Palm Beach palace, Mar-a-lago, I believe it's called, in order to repay a $26 million loan he took out from his casino company, Trump Hotels and Resorts.

The article also says that the company is saddled with so much debt and its stock is performing so poorly that insiders are talking about taking the company private. The stock closed unchanged today at 3 1/4.

BAY: Donald Trump is not the only entrepreneur with possible cash-flow problems. As we've been telling you, several Internet stocks took a huge hit today after a "Barron's" article questioned their long-term viability. The report suggested that many Net companies are running out of cash and could soon go out of business or be forced to merge.

Among the companies "Barron's" points to: Kana Communications, PurchasePro.com, Pilot Network Services, MarketWatch.com and Secure Computing, all of which ended sharply lower today.

Merrill Lynch Internet analyst Henry Blodget said he has argued for nearly a year that up to 75 percent of Internet firms will never make money and will eventually disappear. But Blodget still says there were flaws in the "Barron's" study. He also disagrees with its choice of Net losers, including VeritcalNet, Amazon.com, Mypoint.com and EarthWeb. Blodget said these companies have already found additional financing and now have enough cash to reach profitability. Despite his comments, the stocks still ended lower today.

VARNEY: Well, all right, here's another Web debate with billions at stake, and this one's about taxes. A federal advisory panel meeting in Dallas appears to be deadlocked over recommendations for the future of Internet taxes. But the e-commerce committee does agree on one item, which could score a big win for Internet service providers.

Bob Beard has more from Washington in tonight's "Tech Watch."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BOB BEARD, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The 19-member commission set up to advise Congress on Internet taxation is stuck on whether to tax online sales. The chairman wants to extend the current tax breaks to 2006.

GOV. JIM GILMORE (R), VIRGINIA: I think there's a strong push to extend the moratorium. Let's just make sure that it's not a fake moratorium, that it's a real one.

BEARD: But there's plenty of dissension. Several committee members favor taxing online sales.

GOV. MIKE LEAVITT (R), UTAH: There needs to be a level playing field where those who shop in a retail store are treated in exactly the same way as those who shop over the Internet.

BEARD: The commission does appear to agree on simplifying state and local sales taxes and banning taxes on Internet access, a boon to the major Internet service providers, or ISPs.

BILL WHYMAN, LEGG MASON PRECURSOR GROUP: The big winners on this commission are AOL and Time Warner, as well as the other ISPs.

BEARD: Online sales are usually taxed only if the seller has a store or warehouse in the buyer's state. Supporters of e-commerce taxes point to a study showing states will lose $2.7 billion in sales taxes this year from online sales, $10.8 billion in 2003.

BILL FOX, UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE: It's about 4 percent of the sales tax revenues in that year. And so it's real money in terms of the funding of government.

BEARD (on camera): The commission wraps up tomorrow, when its expected to vote on recommendations to Congress for a final report due out April 21st.

Bob Beard, CNN Financial News, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: Coming up, oil prices tumble in the trading pits…

VARNEY: … as investors bet that OPEC will ease the global supply crunch.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: With a crucial OPEC meeting just a week away, oil prices took a nose dive today. Light sweet crude sank $1.53 to $27.55 a barrel on hopes of a supply boost at next Monday's meeting in Vienna. U.S. Energy Secretary Bill Richardson, now on a second tour of OPEC states, says he's confident of an increase.

But will it be large enough or arrive fast enough?

For more on that, we are joined from Houston by former Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher. He now heads the Mosbacher EnergyCompany, an oil and gas production company.

Secretary Mosbacher, welcome.

ROBERT MOSBACHER, FORMER COMMERCE SECRETARY: Good to be here with you, Willow.

BAY: It seems as if there is consensus that there will be increase in production as a result of next week's meeting.

MOSBACHER: Yes.

BAY: Do you have any sense as to how much of an increase and to the timing of the increase?

MOSBACHER: Well, I think since the meeting starts March 27th, which is just a week away, that if the increase goes through, as we all anticipate -- and obviously that's what brought the price down -- that it will start right away. So call it April 1st. And it will start working its way into the system certainly in the next six weeks, perhaps two months.

BAY: Will even a small increase in supply help here?

MOSBACHER: Well, I think a small one doesn't help as much as a large one, but it will help some. And, you know, they have to balance -- what they want to do is not lose all their additional income from this horrendous low price they had a year ago, but they also don't want to drive the economies of the consuming countries down.

So my guess is that the increase will be somewhere between what the consuming countries would like and what the producing countries would like to produce. And so we're going to see somewhere around a million and a half, close to two million a day, I'd guess.

BAY: There's been a great deal of talk, as you know, about using the strategic petroleum reserves. Do you think that's a good idea? And if you were in office, is that something you would be recommending?

MOSBACHER: No, it isn't. I'll tell you why. That was put there for an emergency, and it was put there for an interruption of supply. We haven't got anything close to that now. What we've got is unusually high prices -- not as high relatively as they were tremendously low a year and a month ago, but we don't have any emergency now. No, I wouldn't.

BAY: If you were facing, as they are now in Washington, a lot of heat from consumers who are paying a whole lot more at the pumps, what would you recommend?

MOSBACHER: I'd say that I'd empathize with those who are paying a lot more, but for them to look at it on a longer-term basis, I would guess that every indication is within the next two to four months, that prices will be down right about in the middle between the aberration of horrendously low prices and these high prices.

My guess is we'll see $20 to $25 oil over the next six months to a year, and gasoline prices halfway between their low of 90 some odd cents and the high of about $1.60. So I would guess we'd be talking about probably something in the $1.30, which is really close to the norm.

BAY: Secretary Mosbacher, thank you for joining us tonight.

MOSBACHER: Nice to be with you.

VARNEY: And here's what we have for you still to come on MONEYLINE: Taiwan breaks with the past, and it's a dramatic vote.

BAY: We'll look at what that means for trade and for relations with China after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Washington is working overtime to ease tensions following Saturday's landmark election in Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian, whose democratic progressive party supports independence from mainland China, won the presidency after five decades of nationalist party rule.

Protesters stormed the nationalist headquarters for a second day today, demanding the resignation of retiring president Lee Teng-hui. And Taiwan's fell: 2.6 percent, on fears of a confrontation with Beijing. That, as Congress considers a proposed free-trade deal with China.

Tonight, top U.S. officials are in Beijing, which last week threatened a tough response. And a White House emissary heads for Taipei this week. For more now, we turn to Winston Lord, he's the former U.S. Ambassador to China and he joins us tonight on MONEYLINE.

Mr. Ambassador, welcome.

WINSTON LORD, FORMER U.S. AMBASSADOR TO CHINA: Nice to be here.

VARNEY: Sir, if China were to respond to the Taiwan elections with any kind of military maneuvers, then the U.S. financial markets would probably take a hit. In your opinion, Mr. Ambassador, will China make any kind of military response at all? LORD: Quick answer is no, not in the near future. They don't have the capability to invade Taiwan. Harassment of shipping or other military maneuvers is more likely, but even that's unlikely. They don't want to jeopardize the vote in WTO and the U.S. Congress.

They don't want to hurt their own economy. They would face a confrontation with the U.S. They would unnerve their Asian neighbors. So, they're going to wait and see and so far, they've been moderate in response to the outcome of the election as has Mr. Chen himself.

VARNEY: But why did they fire those rockets across the Taiwan Strait -- those missiles -- as they did some time ago, when the current president of Taiwan first even talked about independence or the sovereignty of Taiwan?

LORD: Because they don't understand democracy. They don't understand that the way to influence Taiwan or try to draw the people closer to China, is to have a smiling, to reform their own repressive political system, and not threaten Taiwan. It backfired in '96. I participated in the decision to send aircraft carriers there. It backfired this time. It probably helped Mr. Chen get elected.

VARNEY: So China's first priority here is getting into the World Trade Organization.

LORD: Well, Taiwan is it's overwhelming priority, but it's going to have to live with Mr. Chen for either four or eight years. Chen has muted his rhetoric; called for a summit meeting; called for direct economic links with the mainland, which even its predecessor, who the Chinese didn't like, wasn't in favor of; and is willing to forego rhetorical formulations on independence that would upset Beijing. So, so far, he's been moderate and Beijing has adopted a wait-and-see attitude after its very poor rhetoric during the election campaign.

VARNEY: What do you think America's long-term interest is? Should we be helping Taiwan as a democracy or helping the Communist government in Beijing to remain in control?

LORD: Well, obviously, we helped Taiwan as a democracy, even as we engaged holding our nose sometimes, the Chinese in Beijing, it's in our national interest. So it's a delicate balancing act. Six administrations of both political parties have followed it fairly successfully. And we should continue to do that; make sure this thing is resolved peacefully; but not get in the middle; encourage the two sides to talk together.

VARNEY: Former ambassador, Mr. Winston Lord, we thank you very much for joining us tonight.

LORD: My pleasure.

VARNEY: Thank you, sir.

LORD: Thank you.

BAY: Time now for a look at the day's top stories outside the world of business. Jim Moret has that in our "MONEYLINE News Digest" -- Jim.

JIM MORET, CNN ANCHOR: Thank you, Willow.

President Clinton today announced a crucial meeting on Middle- East peace scheduled to take place at the end of his visit to South Asia this week.

The president is back in India tonight after a one-day trip to Bangladesh. On his way home Sunday, Mr. Clinton says he'll meet with Syrian president Hafez Assad in Switzerland to discuss the stalled Israel-Syria peace talks.

In Jordan, Pope John Paul II is on another landmark trip: the first papal visit to the Holy Land in 36 years. He also heads for Israel and the Palestinian territories.

Also today, Hillary Rodham Clinton outlined a national review of behavior-altering drugs, like Ritalin, and their effects on children. The first lady says she is not attacking the drugs but warns that their booming popularity calls for a closer look.

In Baltimore, police reported gunshots in an apartment where a man has allegedly held three hostages since Friday. Police say Joseph Palczynski shot at an armored personnel carrier outside and fired once inside the building.

Finally, in Los Angeles, a man looking for junk to salvage has unearthed Hollywood's lost treasure: 55 stolen Academy Awards. Police say they have charged two shipping company workers with taking the Oscars.

We'll have more on those stories coming up on "THE WORLD TODAY," 8:00 p.m. Eastern, and 5:00 p.m. Pacific -- Stuart, Willow.

VARNEY: Thanks, Jim, see you then.

VARNEY: All right, we'll have more MONEYLINE for you in just one minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: In tonight's headlines, a mighty sell-off for MicroStrategy, a stock that increased 45 fold in the past year crumbles on just one company announcement.

Life after Palm for 3Com. The company unveils a makeover, but will Wall Street like what it sees?

And the business of mapping the human gene, tonight our special series on the new frontier in medical science, "Genomics: From Code to Cash."

BAY: First, more on our top story: another Nasdaq wipeout. It's as if the last two trading sessions never happened. The Nasdaq's heady gains all but erased by today's near-200 point drop. Investors slammed dot.coms and biotechs, pushing the index back down near correction territory.

The Nasdaq slid 188 points, its third biggest point drop ever, a loss of nearly 4 percent. Crumbling biotechs also hurt the Russell 2000 small-cap index. It fell nearly 4 1/2 percent. But investors were looking for somewhere to put their money and again that meant the blue chips. The Dow industrials jumped 85 points to close at 10,680.

The division between the Dow and the Nasdaq has become a common theme this year, but as Susan Lisovicz reports, that gap is closing quickly.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Investors dumped Nasdaq stocks within an hour of the open and never looked up. The sell-off accelerated into a nearly 4 percent rout and the composite's third worst one-day point loss ever.

KEITH MULLINS, SALOMONSMITH BARNEY: It was bloody. As soon as the markets started to roll, the last week's losers just continued to accelerate their losses and the biotechs really led the way down, but they were followed by a lot of the technology stocks as well.

LISOVICZ: Triggering the fall, bad news from business software maker MicroStrategy, the biggest loser on the Nasdaq shed more than 140 points on word it will restate two years of operating results and report a loss instead of a profit. Other victims included: Rambus down nearly 77 points, JDS Uniphase losing more than $8, and big tech names like Microsoft and Oracle also fell.

Adding to the down mood, a bearish article in "Barron's" predicting the burnout of more than 200 Internet companies, including CDNow, Drugstore.com and iVillage, all Nasdaq stocks. But the session wasn't a total wash. Intel gained 5 1/8 and Dell added more than a buck, and some observers think others will soon return to favor.

AL GOLDMAN, A.G. EDWARDS: The tech stocks will not drop down to levels where everybody would like them to go so they can buy them comfortably. This is a group that everybody wants to own. A lot of money has missed it and therefore I think the low in the Nasdaq will be sooner rather than later.

LISOVICZ: Another sector that's pulling the Nasdaq to its lows, biotechs, still reeling from last week's massive sell-off, especially companies working on genetic research.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LISOVICZ: It was just two weeks ago when the Nasdaq closed above 5,000 for the first time, and to giddy investors there was even talk about the Nasdaq catching up to the Dow -- not anytime soon with this kind of selling. The Nasdaq is down nearly 7 percent from that high set just 10 sessions ago.

I am Susan Lisovicz reporting live from the Nasdaq market site. VARNEY: Well, that drop in MicroStrategy stock was more like a meltdown really. The company lost $13 billion in market value and it was a decline of about 60 percent, a swift and severe judgment by investors after the company said it would restate earnings to comply with SEC regulations.

Bruce Francis reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): MicroStrategy's CEO Michael Saylor grabbed headlines just five days ago with his plans to donate $100 million to establish an online university. But now it's Saylor who is getting a lesson in accounting.

MicroStrategy is restating its revenues and results to conform with SEC rules. The company will also postpone a secondary offering of shares. The result, a take-no-prisoners sell-off. More than 60 percent of the company's recently gained market value vanished in a single session.

BERT HOCHFELD, JOSEPHTHAL & CO.: In order to produce the financial results that the investment community demanded to sustain the share price valuation, the company engaged in what I can only describe as highly questionable practices .

FRANCIS: Instead of the more than $200 million in revenues and 15 cents a share profit initially reported for last year, now MicroStrategy says it took in about $150 million and actually lost as much as 51 cents a share. MicroStrategy's problem: prematurely counting revenue and profits on long-term contracts.

JAY STRUM, KAY, SCHOLER: The goods would be provided over time, the services would be provided over time. But they're recognizing all the revenue today even though they're going to incur a substantial amount of the costs later on. That violates the basic principle of accrual accounting.

FRANCIS: Those contracts are with a range of companies from Eddie Bauer to MCIWorldCom. MicroStrategy's software helps its clients sift through customer data to develop better marketing programs.

CEO Michael Saylor blamed his company's accounting problems on a fast-growing business. In a statement he said, "As MicroStrategy has entered new markets, our business model has evolved very rapidly. As a result, the business relationships we have entered into have become more financially complex." No one feels the pain more than Saylor, his one-day paper loss is greater than $6 billion.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: But Saylor's stake at MicroStrategy is still worth $3.8 billion. So there still may be room for that pledge of $100 million for that online university -- Willow and Stuart. VARNEY: Yes, but look, the accounting practices that they employed, are they employed in a similar way by other high-tech start- up companies in which case it would be the tip of the iceberg?

FRANCIS: I think you're exactly right, Stuart, that we are going to see a lot of more scrutiny at accounting practices. There are companies that are under lots of pressure to show they have got real revenues, real profits, and there is a lot of aggressive accounting going on out there.

VARNEY: Bruce Francis, thanks very much.

Well, there were in fact some haves and have not's in the tech sector today. As smaller-cap stocks did indeed tumble, big-cap names performed rather well and they included: Intel, Hewlett-Packard, IBM, Motorola, Micron Technology, all of them went up.

BAY: Coming up, 3Com beats the street and sets out a major restructuring.

VARNEY: A look at 3Com's latest plans as it gets used to life without Palm. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: A new face for 3Com on top of strong profit results, the stock is up a point and a half in after-hours trading after the networking company beat third quarter profit estimates by two cents a share, but the company announced even bigger news at a late meeting with analysts.

Greg Clarkin joins us now with more. He's outside the Plaza Hotel here in New York City. Greg, what do you have?

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Stuart, I'll tell you, a few weeks ago 3Com spun off its Palm division and since then Wall Street analysts have been wondering just what is next for this company? Well, 3Com executives are in New York today. They have been meeting with analysts here at the Plaza for the last three hours, where they're going over details of a dramatic restructuring.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CLARKIN (voice-over): 3Com is launching a vast restructuring, exiting some businesses, taking big charges and cutting thousands of jobs. 3Com is selling its dial-up modem business and it will simply stop making networking equipment for large corporations, a battle it had been losing to Cisco Systems.

DAVID POWERS, EDWARD JONES: Ultimately, I think a more focused strategy is more appropriate, and 3Com's strengths really lie in low- cost, high volume manufacturing, which is more suitable toward the consumer and small to medium-sized business markets.

CLARKIN: There will be big charges, $200 million to $300 million spread over the next two quarters to coverage the changes, and big job cuts, up to 3,000 jobs could be cut, close to 25 percent of 3Com's work force, but many workers will shift to the companies buying 3Com units.

In the wake of the recent spin-off of 3Com's Palm unit, analysts say 3Com was left with low growth, low-margin businesses.

PATRICK HOUGHTON, SUTRO CORP.: They do need to show some kind of pretty significant changes within the company to show where the growth story is going to be going forward.

CLARKIN: 3Com believes the growth is in the small and medium- sized business market, an area Cisco does not dominate. 3Com also announce a number of other moves, including a push into providing consumers with equipment for high-speed Web access.

All the moves are designed to convince investors 3Com is a growth story. The stock has been choppy in recent sessions on speculation of a restructuring, and Wall street was waiting to see just what the company's next move would be.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CLARKIN: Now selling the modem business is a major retreat for 3Com. This was a business that was bought from U.S. Robotics amid much fanfare back in 1997 for $9 billion. Unfortunately, the speed at which those modems connect to the Internet topped out shortly after that, and this unit has been a drag on the company's bottom line -- Stuart, Willow.

VARNEY: Well, Greg, there has been some criticism of 3Com, that it lacked focus. Do you think that this restructuring plan is designed to address that concern about focus?

CLARKIN: It definitely is, Stuart. All day long today, analysts were saying they wanted to see this company really stop trying to be all things to all people in the networking business and focus on one area, and it looks like they've chosen the area that analysts were really very enthusiastic about. That is the middle- and small-sized businesses, as well as consumers.

VARNEY: Greg Clarkin covering 3Com from the Plaza Hotel in New York. Thanks, Greg.

BAY: In other corporate headlines tonight, Lehman's Brothers' quarterly profits more than doubled to a record. Lehman earned $541 million on revenue of $2.2 billion. Despite the blowout quarter, Lehman's stock fell more than 3 1/2. But it has run up sharply over the past few weeks.

The consolidation continues in the regional banking business. National Commerce Bank Corp. is buying CCB Financial for $1.9 billion in stock. The combined company will have more than 300 branches in the Southeast. National Commerce stock fell more than 3. The company is paying a 25 percent premium for CCB based on Friday's close. CCB's stock rose almost one. And the 40-day strike by Boeing's engineers is officially over. The workers returned to their jobs today, after the union's rank and file approved a new three-year contract. Now Boeing must get back up to speed. The company missed at least 15 plane deliveries during the strike. Boeing's stock fell fractionally.

VARNEY: And checking some of tonight's other stock price movers, Walt Disney up more than 2 1/2 points to a 52-week high. Schroeder & Co. upgraded the entertainment giant to its recommended list. It also raised its price target to $47 a share, citing a turnaround in earnings growth.

Hewlett-Packard soared more than six. Xerox and HP have settled all six patent infringement lawsuits against each other. The company said they reach an amicable settlement but would not disclose the details.

Priceline.com sank more than 12 1/4 on a report that several hotels may launch a Web site to compete with Priceline by centralizing their offerings to consumers. "Barron's" said the major airlines are also talking about a site, which could spell trouble for the name- your-own-price e-tailer. But Priceline said the story is not new, and that the Web sites only effect online travel agencies.

BAY: Positive comments from one analysts helped push chips higher today. Merrill Lynch repeated its buy rating on Cyprus Semiconductor. It cited strength in the cell phone market and raised its 2000 profit estimates by 18 cents a share. Shares of Cypress Semiconductor gained 3 1/2.

Intel soared more than five, the most active stock on the Nasdaq. Today, Intel introduced a new Pentium III chip to help boost audio, video and 3-D graphics over the Internet.

Motorola, Analog Devices and STMicroelectronics moved higher as well.

VARNEY: Just ahead on MONEYLINE, he's been credited with nothing less than saving the global economy from collapse.

BAY: But if Alan Greenspan hikes interest rates tomorrow, will it earn him more foes than friends on Wall Street?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's "MONEYLINE Focus,: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, the man so often praised by Wall Street and main street for protecting this record economic expansion. But that praise lately has given way to criticism and second-guessing. Tomorrow he and Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates for the fifth time in less than a year.

And as Peter Viles reports, Greenspan faces lots of questions about his latest war on inflation.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): When he was cutting interest rates 16 months ago, investors loved him. He was even credited with saving the world from financial ruin. But now Alan Greenspan's war on inflation is growing messy and increasingly unpopular, partly because no one really knows what, if anything, Greenspan is trying to do to the stock market.

ROBERT SHILLER, AUTHOR, IRRATIONAL EXUBERANCE: He seems to be a little contradictory. He says at times things that make you think he thinks the market is overpriced. But when asked explicitly about it, he backs down and says, my opinion is no better than anyone else's. So it's hard to understand how he views the stock market as a feed into monetary policy.

VILES: Greenspan has said he believes the wealth effect from the stock market is contributing to the economy's strength. Even after Monday's loss the Nasdaq is up 71 percent since Greenspan started raising rates last June. But the Doe is down slightly in the same period, and some blame Greenspan fro the unusual split in the markets.

"Business Week" writes, quote, "The bubble that the Fed has repeatedly warned against is being nurtured by the Fed's own policy of targeting stocks and wealth."

And "The Wall Street Journal" says confusion over exactly what Greenspan is trying to do is, quote, "injecting fear, uncertainty and nervousness into the market."

But Merrill Lynch economist Bruce Steinberg argues Greenspan may be succeeding in slowing the market. He points out the overall market, as measured by the Wilshire 5000, while up 12 percent since the Fed started tightening, has leveled off recently, while the economy continues to sprint ahead.

BRUCE STEINBERG, MERRILL LYNCH: What they're really concerned about ultimately is that from their point of view growth is just too fast right now. First quarter growth is probably going to be around 6 percent, and the Fed thinks that the speed limit on the economy is probably around 3 3/4 percent.

VILES: In 12 years as Fed chairman, Greenspan has raised rates 23 times and has weathered plenty of criticism.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: In 1994, for example, when the Fed raised rates six times, Greenspan was accused of, quote, "taking away the punch bowl before the party had even started." Now clearly that criticism was wrong, because the "party," the longest expansion in U.S. history, is still going strong -- Willow, Stuart.

BAY: Peter, I would gather the party sure is growing strong -- six percent growth?

VILES: That's what Merrill Lynch said today, and that is very strong growth. BAY: And very unusual at this time in the cycle.

VILES: Yes.

VARNEY: It's unheard of, isn't it?

VILES: This early in the year, this late an expansion, very unusual.

VARNEY: Got it -- Peter Viles.

BAY: Peter Viles, thank you.

VARNEY: All right, still to come: biotech burnout? As investors begin to hit the sector hard we begin our series on the newest wave in medicine.

BAY: It's called genomics, and it's being used to fight everything from cancer to arthritis -- but should you be investing in it?

Our report, up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: A brutal sell-off today in the very sector that has led the Nasdaq to record highs this year: biotechs. The Nasdaq biotech index sank 12 percent, although it is still up 23 percent in 2000.

It was a week ago today that air was first let out of the sector following an agreement between the U.S. and Britain to make genetic sequencing information public.

Here's today's damage: Amgen and Biogen both tumbled more than five points. Abgenix got slammed. It was down 112 1/2. I'm reading that correctly, yes: 112 1/2.

Also down sharply, genomic stocks like InCyte Pharmaceuticals and Celera. These stocks have tumbled from their 52-week highs, some of them down more than 50 percent.

BAY: Since that international agreement, the debate about the promise of genomics has grown louder. Just what is it and why are investors rushing to cash in on this new frontier in science?

Tonight, we begin our special four-part series "The Promise of Genomics: From Code to Cash." Our first report is from Steve Young on the business of mapping the human gene and how it works.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Ground zero of the genomics revolution: It doesn't look very different from many other biology labs, but this is Curagen, one of about two dozen publicly traded biotech companies contributing to something that would have been considered science fiction just five or 10 years ago: nothing less than cataloging the 3 to 4 billion bits that make up DNA, the genetic blueprint. It contains 23 pairs of chromosomes in the double helix found in all of us, and on those chromosomes, 100,000 to 150,000 human genes that make disease-fighting proteins.

MATT GELLER, CIBC OPPENHEIMER: Genomics is really the study of what the underlying building blocks that make up life is. What are the underlying building blocks that make up life? What is the secret code that evolution has figured out over billions of years to encode life?

YOUNG: Armed with that information, pharmaceutical companies believe they'll be able to expand the number of ways medical drugs can work in the body from 450 mechanisms to 2,500 and possibly as many as 10,000 potential candidates.

(on camera): The question is which are the good targets, the meaningful targets, the targets that will make drugs. That's the key question, the question that will take time.

JONATHAN ROTHBERG, CHAIRMAN & CEO, CURAGEN: Scientists who work in the field of genomics will be able to make drugs based on that knowledge against diseases such as cancer, auto-immunity, arthritis: diseases that account for the majority of suffering and diseases which we couldn't solve before.

YOUNG (voice-over): The genomics companies like to say genes make drugs and drugs make money. But biotech has fallen short of its dreams before, and even those bullish on genomics urge caution.

GELLER: Usually your first draft is not a drug. It isn't necessarily deliverable, either in a pill or an injectable form. It may not last long enough. It may have terrible side effects.

RICHARD VAN DEN BROECK, CHASE HAMBRECHT & QUIST: I think before you start seeing a real wave of these drugs coming, I think we're probably about two years away from that, but it will be a steadily building trickle that turns into something more of a torment.

YOUNG: In some ways, Curagen looks like a 19th century textile mill or a 20th century auto assembly plant. But in this 21s century information factory, computerized robots analyze, or sequence, samples to reveal their four most basic DNA components labeled A, C, G and T.

The deluge of data would seem like gibberish produced by a monkey on a typewriter if it weren't for a new speciality, bioinformatics. It uses computer science and information technology to mine the information in the genome.

ROTHBERG: We're actually formed at the intersection of information technology and biotechnology. Our first adviser, it surprises people, was actually from Intel Corporation.

YOUNG: After cataloging the gene, scientists have to understand the protein associated with it.

TODD NELSON, DAIN RAUSCHER WESSELS: Think of genes as sentences but sentences that are only constituted by four letters. And it's the order of those letters that go together -- that go together, excuse me, that allow you to describe what the protein does.

YOUNG: The true believers say genomics will be able to pick drugs that minimize side effects based on a person's own genetic makeup. They say researchers will be able to weed out drugs that are going to fail earlier, focus on winners and move them along faster.

The private companies cataloging the human genome are racing with each other and a $3 billion federally funded project. The first draft of the human genome is expected to be completed by this summer. Then comes the harder job of functional gene analysis.

(on camera): The decoding of the human genome isn't the end, but it is the beginning of a whole new era.

Steve Young, CNN Financial News, New Haven, Connecticut.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: Beginning of an era and certainly extremely complex, not just the science but the business of it as well. So don't miss the second part of our genomics series.

VARNEY: Which is called "Mapping the Future."

We're going to look at the companies at the forefront of this state-of-the-art science and what their research could mean for the future of medicine.

BAY: That is tomorrow right here on MONEYLINE. But up next, "Ahead of the Curve": some of what you need to know tonight before the markets open tomorrow.

VARNEY: You're watching MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: You can probably sum up the action on Wall Street tomorrow in just two words, interest rates. Federal Reserve policy- makers meet in Washington and they are widely expected to raise short- term rates by a quarter percentage point. Look for that decision to come around 2:00 p.m. Eastern.

Also, the government releases the latest trade numbers for January, and look for profit reports tomorrow from Goldman Sachs, National Discount Brokers and Micron Technology.

BAY: That is MONEYLINE for this Monday. I'm Willow Bay.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney. We thank you for joining us and good night from New York.

"CROSSFIRE" is next.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60X0-Y2H1-JCBN-014J-00000-00Nasdaq sheds 10% in three days in tech sell-off; Tesla tanks after S&P 500 snub2020-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisNasdaq sheds 10% in three days in tech sell-off; Tesla tanks after S&P 500 snub

The three major U.S. indexes posted steep, across-the-board losses on Tuesday as technology shares continued to fuel a sell-off that snapped a five-week winning streak on Wall Street and slashed 10% off the Nasdaq composite in three days. The Dow Jones industrial average shed 632.42 points, or 2.3%, to close at 27,500.89. The Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped 95.12 points, or 2.8%, to settle at 3,331.84, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq tumbled 465.44 points, or 4.1%, to end at 10,847.69. After an uptick that analysts say is atypical of September, U.S. markets plummeted Thursday and Friday, dragged down by the tech giants ahead of the long holiday weekend. The markets were closed on Labor Day. Big Tech lost big on Tuesday: Amazon gave up 4.4%, Facebook shed 4.1% and Google parent Alphabet fell 3.6%. Biotechnological firm Moderna, which is working on a coronavirus vaccine candidate, lost nearly 13.2%.Â  (Amazon chief executive Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post.)Â  Investors also are grappling with questions about U.S.-China trade, stymied coronavirus relief talks and growing worries about the November election, said Michael Farr, president of Farr, Miller & Washington.

"Each of these factors could imperil the narrative that has been baked into stock prices, which is a relatively quick economic rebound."Â  Tesla shares plunged 21.1% Tuesday after the S&P 500, in a surprise move, passed on the carmaker. Investors in the high-flying electric car company had been banking on Tesla joining the benchmark index - its share price has been rising all summer. And the company's stock has rocketed more than 350% from the beginning of the year. In Tesla, which has garnered a passionate fan base, akin to a consumer electronics company or a comic book media property, many longtime investors see an industry-defining pioneer, whose vision for an all-electric future has forced larger, more established automakers to play catch up. The company boosted its prospects on Wall Street further by posting earnings of more than $100 million in July, its fourth consecutive quarter of profitability, a first for Tesla. Optimistic investors continued to pour money into the company, sending its market capitalization above corporate giants such as Home Depot and Intel. And in another summer milestone, Tesla surpassed the market value of Toyota, seizing the crown of the most valuable carmaker in the world, despite selling fewer than 400,000 vehicles last year, compared with Toyota's 10.74 million. But investors' hopes were dashed when S&PDow JonesIndices, the company that oversees the S&P 500, announced late Friday that it would not add Tesla to its widely tracked index. Instead, the e-commerce site Etsy, tech maker Teradyne and pharmaceutical company Catalent, will join the S&P 500 effective Sept. 21. The index will delete tax preparation company H&R Block, department store chain Kohl's and beauty brand Coty. The planned reorganization comes eight days after a major shake-up with the Dow, which dumped Exxon, Pfizer and Raytheon for Amgen, Honeywell and Salesforce. Adding Tesla had been "viewed as almost a consensus move based on all the metrics that Tesla was likely to get into the S&P 500 club this time around," Dan Ives, an analyst at Wedbush Securities said in a note to clients after the S&P's decision. Its omission "thus will have a negative knee jerk investor reaction."Â  Ives said Tesla's profitability and earnings forecast were likely the deciding factors for excluding the company. But the snub for Tesla boosters was confounding. "In a nutshell Tesla not getting into the S&P 500 will be a head scratcher to the bulls that viewed this as virtually a lock given all the parameters met," he said. "The market was undoubtedly surprised by the S&P 500 Index Committee's decision not to include Tesla this quarter, despite announcing its fourth quarter of profitability and solidifying its eligibility for inclusion," said Nicole Tanenbaum of Chequers Financial Management. But the committee that makes the selections may have been focused on more than simply meeting the bottom line criteria, she said. Tesla's reliance on selling regulatory pollution credits to boost its profits and the uncertainty around its earnings stream may have weighed on the decision to leave the company out of the index, she added. In 2019, more than $11.2 trillion in assets were benchmarked to the S&P 500, according to an estimate from S&PDow JonesIndices. A special S&P committee determines which companies populate the index based on a variety of factors, but meeting the necessary criteria does not guarantee inclusion. S&P said in a news release Friday that it was also changing the lineup to its mid- and small-cap indexes. As for the three companies that did make the list, Tanenbaum said there's an arguable logic behind their additions. "Despite the companies smaller sizes, each has delivered a consistent track record of profitability," she said. The three companies that were deleted from the S&P 500 will drop down into the lower capitalization index, the S&P MidCap 400. Â

urn:contentItem:60SY-T571-JCSC-J1Y6-00000-00Nasdaq sheds 10 percent in three days in tech sell-off; Tesla tanks after S&P 500 snub2020-09-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:19ZLexisNexisNEWSNasdaq sheds 10 percent in three days in tech sell-off; Tesla tanks after S&P 500 snubHamza Shaban

The three major U.S. indexes posted steep, across-the-board losses on Tuesday as technology shares continued to fuel a sell-off that snapped a five-week winning streak on Wall Street and slashed 10 percent off the Nasdaq composite in three days. The Dow Jo... The three major U.S. indexes posted steep, across-the-board losses on Tuesday as technology shares continued...

The three major U.S. indexes posted steep, across-the-board losses on Tuesday as technology shares continued to fuel a sell-off that snapped a five-week winning streak on Wall Street and slashed 10 percent off the Nasdaq composite in three days. The Dow Jo...

The three major U.S. indexes posted steep, across-the-board losses on Tuesday as technology shares continued to fuel a sell-off that snapped a five-week winning streak on Wall Street and slashed 10 percent off the Nasdaq composite in three days. The Dow Jones industrial average shed 632.42 points, or 2.3 percent, to close at 27,500.89. The Standard & Poor’s 500 index dropped 95.12 points, or 2.8 percent, to settle at 3,331.84, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq tumbled 465.44 points, or 4.1 percent, to end at 10,847.69. After an uptick that analysts say is atypical of September, U.S. markets plummeted Thursday and Friday, dragged down by the tech giants ahead of the long holiday weekend. The markets were closed on Labor Day. Big Tech lost big on Tuesday: Amazon gave up 4.4 percent, Facebook shed 4.1 percent and Alphabet fell 3.6 percent. And biotechnological firm Moderna, which is working on a coronavirus vaccine candidate, lost nearly 13.2 percent. (Amazon chief executive Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post.) Investors also are grappling with questions about U.S.-China trade, stymied coronavirus relief talks and growing worries about the November election, said Michael Farr, president of Farr, Miller & Washington. “Each of these factors could imperil the narrative that has been baked into stock prices, which is a relatively quick economic rebound.” Tesla shares plunged 21.1 percent Tuesday after the S&P 500, in a surprise move, passed on the carmaker . Investors in the high-flying electric car company had been banking on Tesla joining the benchmark index — its share price has been rising all summer. And the company’s stock has rocketed more than 350 percent from the beginning of the year. In Tesla, which has garnered a passionate fan base, akin to a consumer electronics company or a comic book media property, many longtime investors see an industry-defining pioneer, whose vision for an all-electric future has forced larger, more established automakers to play catch up. The company boosted its prospects on Wall Street further by posting earnings of more than $100 million in July, its fourth consecutive quarter of profitability, a first for Tesla. Optimistic investors continued to pour money into the company, sending its market capitalization above corporate giants like Home Depot and Intel. And in another summer milestone, Tesla surpassed the market value of Toyota, seizing the crown of the most valuable carmaker in the world, despite selling fewer than 400,000 vehicles last year, compared to Toyota’s 10.74 million. But investors’ hopes were dashed when S&PDow JonesIndices, the company that oversees the S&P 500, announced late Friday it would not add Tesla to its widely tracked index. Instead, the e-commerce site Etsy, tech maker Teradyne and pharmaceutical company Catalent, will join the S&P 500 effective Sept. 21. The index will delete tax preparation company H & R Block, department store chain Kohl’s and beauty brand Coty. The planned reorganization comes just eight days after a major shake-up with the Dow , which dumped Exxon, Pfizer and Raytheon for Salesforce, Amgen and Honeywell. Adding Tesla had been “viewed as almost a consensus move based on all the metrics that Tesla was likely to get into the S&P 500 club this time around,” Dan Ives, an analyst at Wedbush Securities said in a note to clients after the S&P’s decision. Its omission “thus will have a negative knee jerk investor reaction.” Ives said Tesla’s profitability and earnings forecast were likely the deciding factors for excluding the company. But the snub for Tesla boosters was confounding. “In a nutshell Tesla not getting into the S&P 500 will be a head scratcher to the bulls that viewed this as virtually a lock given all the parameters met,” he said. “The market was undoubtedly surprised by the S&P 500 Index Committee’s decision not to include Tesla this quarter, despite announcing its fourth quarter of profitability and solidifying its eligibility for inclusion,” said Nicole Tanenbaum of Chequers Financial Management. But the committee that makes the selections may have been focused on more than simply meeting the bottom line criteria, she said. Tesla’s reliance on selling regulatory pollution credits to boost its profits and the uncertainty around its earnings stream may have weighed on the decision to leave the company out of the index, she added. In 2019, more than $11.2 trillion in assets were benchmarked to the S&P 500, according to an estimate from S&PDow JonesIndices. A special S&P committee determines which companies populate the index based on a variety of factors, but meeting the necessary criteria does not guarantee inclusion. S&P said in a news release Friday it was also changing the lineup to its mid- and small-cap indexes. As for the three companies that did make the list, Tanenbaum said there’s an arguable logic behind their additions. “Despite the companies smaller sizes, each has delivered a consistent track record of profitability,” she said. The three companies that were deleted from the S&P 500 will drop down into the lower capitalization index, the S&P MidCap 400.
